questions.text: Which term refers to the practice of instilling a particular point of view in people's minds and inhibiting their independent thought?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Health Propaganda

Explanation:

  • Health Propaganda refers to the practice of instilling a particular point of view in people's minds and inhibiting their independent thought. It involves disseminating information (may be false or exaggerated) that is designed to influence people's opinions and behaviors, often appealing to emotions rather than reason.

Incorrect Options:

Health Promotion (Option B): Health promotion involves activities aimed at improving overall health and well-being.

Health Awareness (Option C): Health awareness is about raising knowledge and understanding of health issues among individuals and communities.

Health Education (Option D): Health education involves providing people with accurate information and skills to make informed health decisions. It encourages active thinking and reasoning, aiming to develop reflective behavior and individual judgment.

questions.text: A woman develops edema, visual disturbances, and heart failure after consuming a food item. What is the most likely adulterant?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Sanguinarine

Explanation:

  • Sanguinarine is a toxic alkaloid found in Argemone oil, which is derived from the seeds of the Argemone Mexicana plant, which is a common weed in mustard fields, and its seeds can accidentally get mixed with mustard seeds during oil extraction.
  • Consumption of mustard oil contaminated with Argemone oil leads to a condition known as epidemic dropsy. It can present as:
    • Sudden bilateral non-inflammatory pitting edema.
    • Diarrhoea
    • Dyspnoea
    • Cardiac defects
    • Glaucoma

Incorrect Options:

BOAA (Option B): BOAA is a neurotoxic amino acid found in the seeds of the Lathyrus sativus plant and leads to neurolathyrism.

Pyrrolizidine (Option C): Pyrrolizidine alkaloids are hepatotoxic compounds found in various plants. Chronic exposure leads to veno-occlusive disease of the liver, causing hepatomegaly, jaundice, and ascites

Aflatoxin (Option D): Aflatoxin causes aflatoxicosis, which typically results in liver damage, hepatocellular carcinoma, and acute hepatic failure.

questions.text: What percentage of data falls within one standard deviation of the mean in a normal distribution?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- 68%

Explanation:

  • In a normal distribution, about 68% of the data falls within one standard deviation of the mean.

A Gaussian/bell-shaped curve showing normal distribution forms when the point of coincidence is equal to mean = median = mode ~ Normal distribution

In a standard normal distribution

  • Mean = Median = mode = 0
  • Standard deviation = 1
  • Total area under the curve = 1

If we draw the following line

  • Redline cuts the base at the distance of 1 standard deviation.
  • Pink line at +/- 2 standard deviation.
  • Green line at +/- 3 standard deviation.
  • The tail of the curve never touches the baseline.

Area under the curve

Observation covered

Mean +/- 1 SD

68.3% ~ 68% of observation

Mean +/- 2 SD

95.4% ~ 95% of observation (Option B ruled out)

Mean +/- 3 SD

99.7% ~ 99% of observation (Option D ruled out)

Mean +/- ∞SD

100% of observation

98% (Option C): 98% of the data in a normal distribution falls within 2 and 3 SD (~2.33 SD) of the mean.

questions.text: What is the growth rate if the crude birth rate is 19 and the crude death rate is 7?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- 1.2%

Explanation:

To determine the growth rate of a population, we use the following formula:

Growth Rate = Crude Birth Rate − Crude Death Rate

Given:

  • Crude Birth Rate (CBR) = 19
  • Crude Death Rate (CDR) = 7

Growth Rate=19−7=12 per 1000 people

To express this as a percentage:

Growth Rate= 12/1000 x 100 = 1.2%

questions.text: Which pneumoconiosis is caused by exposure to cotton dust?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Byssinosis

Explanation:

Byssinosis: Common among workers exposed to cotton, flax, or hemp dust, primarily in the textile manufacturing industry.

Bagassosis (Option B): an occupational lung disease caused by inhaling bagasse (sugarcane dust). Caused by Thermoactinomyces sacchari with ymptoms include breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, slight fever, and acute diffuse bronchiolitis. Chest X-ray may show lung mottling or shadowing and impaired pulmonary function.

Anthracosis or Coal Workers' Pneumoconiosis (aka "black lung disease" ) (Option C): This condition affects workers in coal mining due to inhalation of coal dust.

Silicosis (Option D): Often occurs in workers exposed to silica dust in industries like mining and quarrying.

questions.text: In a family, Mr. X is 69 years old, and his wife, Mrs. X, is 58 years old. They have a 30-year-old son, his 28-year-old wife, and a 5-year-old grandchild. Calculate the dependency ratio for this family.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 0.66

Explanation:

  • The dependency ratio is the average number of economically dependent individuals per 100 economically productive individuals in a specific country, territory, or geographic area at a given time.
  • To calculate the dependency ratio, we use the formula:

Dependency Ratio = (2 / 3) × 100

Dependency Ratio = 66.67% ≃ 0.66

questions.text: What level of prevention is being addressed by administering an injection of benzathine penicillin to a patient with rheumatic heart disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C) Secondary:

Explanation:

  • Secondary prevention aims to detect and address a disease early before it causes significant complications. Administering benzathine penicillin to a patient with rheumatic heart disease falls under secondary prevention as it is taken to prevent further complications and worsening of the condition, which is already present but not yet leading to serious complications.

Level of Prevention

Goals

Examples

Primordial (Option A ruled out)

To prevent the establishment of risk factors
  • Lifestyle modification
  • Health promotion

Primary (Option B ruled out)

Interventions to prevent the onset of disease
  • Vaccinations
  • Health education
  • Family planning
  • Use of mosquito nets
  • Pre-placement examination

Secondary (Option C)

Early detection and prompt treatment of disease to prevent complications
  • Screening tests (e.g., mammograms, PAP smears)
  • Self-examinations
  • Health camps with screening
  • DOTS for TB; ART for HIV; MDT for leprosy.

Tertiary  (Option D ruled out)

Interventions to manage and reduce complications of existing disease to prevent disability or death
  • Rehabilitation
  • Physical therapy
  • Chronic disease management programs
  • Reconstructive surgery

questions.text: What physiological response is most likely to occur in a person exposed to high temperatures while exercising vigorously to maintain internal body temperature within a narrow range?

choices.text: Sweating and vasodilation in the skin
Shivering and vasoconstriction in the skin
Increased production of heat by the liver
Decreased heart rate (HR) and respiratory rate (RR)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sweating and vasodilation in the skin

Explanation:

  • When exercising vigorously in high temperatures, the body needs to dissipate heat to maintain a stable internal temperature.
  • Sweating helps cool the body through evaporative cooling, while vasodilation (widening of blood vessels) in the skin increases blood flow to the surface, allowing more heat to be released into the environment.

Shivering and vasoconstriction in the skin (Option B): are responses typically seen in cold environments. Shivering generates heat through muscle contractions, and vasoconstriction (narrowing of blood vessels) helps to retain heat. These mechanisms are not relevant in hot conditions.

Increased production of heat by the liver (Option C): The liver produces heat as a byproduct of metabolic processes, but this is not a primary response to high temperatures during vigorous exercise. The body focuses on cooling mechanisms rather than increasing heat production in such conditions.

Decreased heart rate (HR) and respiratory rate (RR) (Option D): During vigorous exercise, both heart rate and respiratory rate typically increase to meet the higher oxygen demands of the muscles. A decrease in HR and RR would not be expected under these conditions; instead, they would rise to support increased physical activity.

questions.text: What is the recommended area per worker in a factory, considering that any height above a specified limit is not taken into account?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- 500 cubic feet

Explanation:

  • According to the Factory Act of 1948, the recommended minimum space per worker is 500 cubic feet.
  • This regulation is in place to ensure that workers have enough space to work comfortably and safely, reducing the risk of accidents and health issues that can arise from overcrowding.

Factory Act

Definition

An establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used or 20 or more workers where power is not used.

Applicability

Applies to all of India and covers all factories, including perennial and seasonal factories.

Age Restrictions

 
  • Prohibits employment of children below 14 years of age.
  • 15-18 year olds need fitness certificate for factory work from a certified surgeon

Hours of Work
  • Work limited to 48 hours/week or 9 hours/day; max 60 hours/week with overtime.
  • Adolescents: max 4.5 hours/day.
  • Women and adolescents: work hours 6 am to 7 pm.

Leave
  • Grants 1 day of leave per 15 days of work for adolescents
  • 1 day per 30 days of work for adults.
  • Permits accumulation of leaves up to 40 days for adolescents and 30 days for adults.

Health & Safety
  • Mandates a minimum of 500 cubic feet of space per worker.
  • Requires 1 safety officer per 1000 workers.

Welfare

Stipulates 1 welfare officer per 500 workers, 1 canteen per 250 workers, and 1 crèche per 30 women workers.

questions.text: Which of the following components is absent in smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Troponin

Explanation:

  • Troponin is absent in smooth muscle.
  • In striated muscles, troponin is a calcium-binding protein that regulates muscle contraction.
  • In smooth muscle, this function is performed by calmodulin, another calcium-binding protein. Calmodulin binds calcium and activates myosin light-chain kinase, which then phosphorylates myosin and facilitates contraction.

Characteristic features of Smooth muscles and Skeletal muscles:

Smooth muscles

Skeletal muscles

Spindle-shaped, single nucleated cells.

Multiple nucleated cells.

Neuromuscular junction is not present.

Proper neuromuscular junction is present.

Caveolae is present.

T-tubule is present.

Predominantly, calcium channels are present.

Predominantly, sodium channels are present.
  • Actin and myosin are present but not properly organised. (Options A and B)
  • Tropomyosin is present and plays a role in regulating the interaction between actin and myosin. (Option C)

 

Actin and myosin are properly organised.

A dense body is present.

The Z- line is present.
  • Calmodulin is present, and Titin is absent.
  • Troponin is absent

 

Troponin and Titin are present.

questions.text:
A patient arrives at the emergency department unconscious. An arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals the following results:


	pH: 7.1
	PCO2: 23 mmHg
	PO2: 98 mmHg
	HCO3: 16 mEq/L


What do these ABG results indicate about the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Metabolic acidosis

Explanation: To determine the type of acid-base disturbance, let's break down the ABG results:

  • pH: A pH of 7.1 indicates acidemia (a lower-than-normal pH)
  • HCO3 (Bicarbonate): The bicarbonate level is 16 mEq/L, which is lower than the normal range (22-26 mEq/L). Low bicarbonate levels typically indicate a primary metabolic problem.
  • PCO2 (Partial Pressure of Carbon Dioxide): The PCO2 level is 23 mmHg, which is lower than the normal range (35-45 mmHg). This indicates that the body is compensating for the primary metabolic disturbance by increasing respiratory rate to blow off CO2.
  • Metabolic Acidosis: The low pH (acidosis) combined with low HCO3 suggests a primary metabolic acidosis. The decreased HCO3 is consistent with metabolic acidosis. The low PCO2 is a compensatory response to metabolic acidosis, where the body is trying to reduce CO2 to help counteract the acidosis.

Metabolic Alkalosis (Option B): This would be characterized by a high pH and high HCO3. This is not the case here, as the pH is low and HCO3 is low.

Respiratory Acidosis (Option C): This would be characterized by a low pH and high PCO2, not a low PCO2. The bicarbonate level would not be as low in a primary respiratory acidosis.

Respiratory Alkalosis (Option D): This would show a high pH and low PCO2, but the bicarbonate level would be normal or compensatory high. In this case, the pH is low, and HCO3 is also low.

questions.text: Heart of sewage disposal plant:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Aeration tank

Explanation:

  • The aeration tank is the heart of sewage treatment. In this stage, the effluent from the primary sedimentation tank is subjected to aerobic oxidation, promoting the growth of microorganisms that break down organic pollutants in the sewage.

Sewage treatment plant:

  • Primary treatment involves screening, a grit chamber, and a plain sedimentation tank.
    • The process is anaerobic digestion.
  • Secondary treatment involves either the trickling filter or the activated sludge process.
    • The process involves aerobic oxidation
    • The activated sludge process is an easier method as it requires less process and involves an aeration tank. This process is essential for effectively reducing biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) and improving the quality of the treated effluent.
    • Trickling filter is a biological filter that uses microorganisms to remove organic matter and nitrogen from wastewater .
  • Sedimentation tank is stage three of sewage treatment.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are components of the sewage treatment plant, but they are less essential as compared to the aeration tank.

questions.text: Which ion is primarily involved in the function of O2-sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Potassium (K+)
Explanation:

  • The ion primarily involved in the function of O₂-sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors is Potassium (K⁺).
  • These channels play a crucial role in oxygen sensing within the carotid bodies, which are the main chemoreceptor sites for detecting changes in blood oxygen levels.
  • When oxygen levels drop, the O₂-sensitive potassium channels close, leading to cell depolarization and the subsequent release of neurotransmitters that signal the brain to increase respiration and blood pressure to maintain oxygen homeostasis​

Sodium (Na⁺) (Option B): is not directly involved in the O2-sensitive channels. They play a different role in other cellular processes but are not the key ions for oxygen sensitivity in peripheral chemoreceptors.

Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) (Option C): is involved in acid-base balance and buffering, not directly in the function of O2-sensitive channels.

Chloride (Cl⁻) (Option D): does not play a direct role in the functioning of O2-sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding an increase in Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR)?

choices.text: Increase in the resistance of the afferent arteriole
Decrease in the resistance of the efferent arteriole
Increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Increase in renal perfusion

Explanation: Increasing renal perfusion (blood flow to the kidneys) enhances the amount of blood reaching the glomeruli, which typically increases the GFR.

Arteriole Change

Effect on Resistance

Effect on Glomerular Hydrostatic Pressure

Effect on GFR

Effect on RPF

Afferent Arteriole Constriction

Increases

(Option A)

 

Decreases

Decreases

 

Decreases

Afferent Arteriole Dilation

Decreases

Increases

Increases

Increases

Efferent Arteriole Constriction- Mild

Increases

Increases

Slight increase

 

Decreases

Efferent Arteriole Constriction- Severe

Increases

Increases
  • Initially increases GFR then ultimately decreases.
  • Severe efferent arteriole constriction reduces renal blood flow and increases filtration fraction, concentrating plasma proteins in the glomerular capillaries and elevating glomerular colloid osmotic pressure.
  • This counteracts the effect of increased hydrostatic pressure, ultimately reducing GFR

Decreases

Efferent Arteriole Dilation

Decreases

(Option B)

 

Decreases

Decreases

Increases

 

Increase in the resistance of the afferent arteriole (Option A): Increasing the resistance of the afferent arteriole reduces the blood flow into the glomerulus, which decreases the GFR.

Decrease in the resistance of the efferent arteriole (Option B): Decreasing the resistance of the efferent arteriole would lead to increased outflow from the glomerulus, which typically reduces the GFR, not increases it.

Increase in Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure (Option C): An increase in the hydrostatic pressure within Bowman’s capsule would oppose filtration and thus decrease the GFR.

questions.text: Which protein does calcium bind to during smooth muscle contraction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Calmodulin

Explanation:

  • In smooth muscle contraction, calcium binds to calmodulin, which then activates myosin light-chain kinase (MLCK). This activation is crucial for muscle contraction.

Mechanism of smooth muscle contraction:

  • Smooth muscle can maintain contraction with less energy expenditure than skeletal muscle (Latch-bridge mechanism).
  • Relaxation: Occurs when Ca²⁺ is pumped out of the cell or back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, and myosin is dephosphorylated.

Troponin (Option B): is a calcium-binding protein found in skeletal muscle, not smooth muscle. In skeletal muscle, calcium binds to troponin to initiate contraction.

Topoisomerase (Option C): is an enzyme that helps manage DNA supercoiling during replication and transcription. It does not interact with calcium during muscle contraction.

Actin (Option D): is a filamentous protein that forms the backbone of the thin filaments in muscle fibers. While actin interacts with myosin for muscle contraction, it does not bind directly with calcium.

questions.text: Paris green dust is commonly used to kill which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anopheles larva

Explanation:

  • Paris green dust is a type of pesticide primarily used for its larvicidal properties. It is particularly effective in controlling the larvae of mosquitoes, such as Anopheles larvae.

Anti-larval measures against mosquito larvae:

Environmental measures

Chemical control

Biological control

Yield permanent results and source reduction.

E.g.

  • Filling drains and ditches.
  • Levelling of ground.
  • Proper drainage of breeding areas.
  • Intermittent irrigation.
  • Changing water alkalinity.

Using larvicides

E.g.

1. Physical:

  • MLO (Mosquito larvicidal oil): 200L/hectare

2. Chemical:

  • Paris green
  • Temephos (Abate): 200L/hectare

3. IGR (insect growth regulators):

  • Inhibit chitin formation, moulding and adult maturation.
  • Pyriproxyfen and Diflubenzuron

Larvivorous Fishes:

1. Gambusia and Poecilia fish

2. Bacillus thuringiensis (used in polluted waters)

3. Toxorhynchites splendens

(predator mosquito for Aedes and Anopheles)

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: Paris green is not effective against houseflies, bedbugs, and cockroaches.

questions.text: Which among the following cannot be studied using case-control study?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cause to effect

Explanation:

  • Cause to effect cannot be studied using case-control studies and it is studied using a cohort study.
  • In case-control studies, researchers start with individuals who already have the outcome of interest (cases) and compare them to individuals without the outcome (controls).
  • This retrospective design makes it challenging to establish causality because the exposure may have occurred before or after the disease developed, leaving the relationship unclear.
  • Additionally, since participants are not followed over time, the study cannot confirm whether the exposure directly caused the outcome.
  • Thus, case-control studies are more suited for identifying associations rather than proving causal relationships.

Case-Control study:

Advantages

Disadvantages

  • Less time taken.
  • Inexpensive.
  • Minimal ethical problems.
  • Multiple exposure was studied.
  • Rare diseases can be studied.
  • Attrition bias not present
  • Forms the rationale for prevention and control programmes based on risk factors.
  • Selection bias.
  • Recall bias.
  • Interviewer bias.
  • Cannot measure incidence: Only provides estimation of relative risk.
  • Cannot differentiate between causes and associated factors

Incorrect Options:

Effect to cause (Option A): Case-control study precedes backward from effect to cause, hence it is also called effect to cause study.

Rare Disease (Option B): Rare Diseases can be studied using case-control.

Odds ratio (Option C): Odds ratio is used to analyze and interpret the case-control study.

questions.text: Air humidity and dew point temperature of the air is measured using which of the following instruments?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Sling psychrometer

Explanation:

  • Air humidity is the moisture content of air.
  • It is measured using a sling psychrometer shown in the image below.

Air humidity measuring instruments

A. Hygrometer

B. Sling psychrometer

  • Wet and dry thermometers are mounted side by side

C. Assman psychrometer

  • Can be used even in strong sunshine

D. Dry and wet bulb hygrometer

  • Most widely used
  • Same readings in both (dry and wet) bulbs indicate 100 per cent saturation with moisture

Incorrect Options:

Kata thermometer (Option B): Kata thermometer is used to measure low air velocity and cooling power of air.

Barometer (Option C): A barometer is used to measure atmospheric pressure.

Dial thermometer (Option D): Dial thermometer is used to monitor temperatures in solutions or samples.

questions.text: A 7 year old boy is brought to the OPD. He fell on his outstretched arm while riding on his cycle. Clinical examination findings are presented in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Dorsal displacement supracondylar fracture of humerus
Malunion of a supracondylar fracture of humerus

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Malunion of a supracondylar fracture of humerus

Explanation:

The image shows a cubitus varus deformity, with a reversal of the carrying angle of the arm. Malunion of a supracondylar humerus fracture can result in cubitus varus or gunstock deformity in which the normal carrying angle of the arm is reversed and the forearm deviates to the midline when the elbow is extended.

Supracondylar Fractures

Mechanism of injury

Fall on outstretched hand (FOOSH)

Location

Humerus fractures just above the condyles.

Displacements

The distal fragment of the humerus is usually displaced by

  • Posterior shift (Due to Impaction)
  • Posterior Tilt
  • Proximal shift
  • Medial shift/ Tilt
  • Internal rotation

Types
  • Type 1: Undisplaced fracture
  • Type 2: Partially displaced fracture with displacement of only anterior cortex
  • Type 3: Completely displaced anterior and posterior cortex.

Clinical Presentation
  • Severe elbow pain, swelling, deformity, and loss of function may occur, and neurological symptoms like weakness in wrist flexion or the "hand of benediction" sign may also occur if the median nerve is affected.
  • Unusual posterior prominence of the olecranon in the backward tilt (S-shaped deformity)
  • The skin around the fracture has a dimpled appearance (Dimple sign)

X-ray Findings
  • Three bony parts relationship is maintained.
  • Fat Pad or Sail sign: A translucent shadow-like appearance representing anterior and posterior fat pads.
  • Disturbed tear drop sign: An abnormal appearance of the fat pad, suggesting the presence of an injury, such as a fracture or joint effusion.

 

 

  • Fishtail sign: The ends of the proximal fragment are slightly widened and serrated, resembling a fishtail.
  • Crescent sign: The normal radiolucent gap of the elbow joint is replaced by a crescent-shaped shadow from the capitulum overlapping the olecranon, indicating varus or valgus tilt of the distal fragment.

Management

Based on the type of fracture

  • Undisplaced fracture: Immobilisation in above-elbow plaster slab with the elbow in 90-degree flexion.
  • Displaced fractures
    • Closed reduction with percutaneous K-wire fixation. (for Type 2 fracture)
    • Open reduction internal fixation with K-wire. (for Type 3 fracture)
  • In Late presentation with swelling
    • Dunlop traction (skin)
    • Smith traction (skeletal)

Complications
  • Early complications
    • Vascular injury (commonly Brachial artery)
    • Nerve injury (commonly Anterior Interosseous nerve)
  • Delayed complications
    • Cubitus varus or Gunstock deformity (Malunion) (Option C)
    • Volkmann's Ischemia and compartment syndrome.
    • Elbow stiffness
    • Myositis ossificans.

Dorsal displacement supracondylar fracture of humerus (Option A) occurs when the dorsal fragment is displaced either posteromedially or posterolaterally. It does not cause a varus deformity.

Undisplaced supracondylar fracture (Option B) there is no displacement of the posterior and anterior cortex. It does not cause a varus deformity.

Proximal humerus fracture (Option D) commonly involves the head of the humerus and cause a varus deformity.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Newborn

  • Navjaat Sishu Suraksha Karyakaram is a 2-day training provided to healthcare workers/medical officers in newborn care and resuscitation.

Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram(NSSK)
  • A training program launched by the Indian Government to equip doctors and nurses with essential newborn care skills, specifically addressing birth asphyxia.
  • The ultimate goal is to reduce newborn mortality and morbidity.

Goals/Objectives
  • Reduce Neonatal Mortality Rate: Decrease India's Neonatal Mortality Rate to single digits by 2030.
  • Improve Newborn Care Quality: Enhance the quality of newborn care.
  • Prevent Perinatal Asphyxia-Related Issues: Reduce morbidity and mortality linked to perinatal asphyxia.

Strategies

  • Capacity Building: Equip healthcare providers with necessary knowledge and skills.
  • Essential Newborn Care and Resuscitation Training.
  • Updated Curriculum and Training Methodology
  • Standardized Equipment and Supplies: Provide clean, functional equipment.
  • Effective Knowledge and Skill Transfer: Improve practical application of training.
  • Focus on "Golden Minute": Quick assessment and resuscitation. Promoting Clean Birth Practices: Adhere to WHO's "six cleans". Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC). Promotion: Encourage KMC for low birth weight babies.
  • Timely Immunization: Ensure vaccination before discharge.
  • Educate parents on newborn care.
  • Effective Neonatal Transport: Establish protocols for the safe transport of sick newborns.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in the left knee region. He reports that the pain is often worse at night and mentions that he has been taking Aspirin to relieve the pain. An X-ray of the knee is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Osteoid osteoma

Explanation:

Based on the provided X-ray image and the clinical history of a 30-year-old male with night pain relieved by Aspirin, the likely diagnosis is Osteoid Osteoma.

Osteoid Osteoma

A small, benign bone tumor composed of osteoid and woven bone with a surrounding halo of reactive bone

Demographics

Sex: Males > Females

Age: Young patients, but rare under 5 years and over 30.

Location

The diaphysis of long bones, especially the proximal tibia, and femur.

It can also occur in the spine, particularly the posterior arches.

Pathophysiology

The nidus releases prostaglandins which cause the characteristic pain that relieves on taking NSAIDs

Symptoms

Characterized by pain, often worse at night (Night crises), and relieved by NSAIDs (Therapeutic test).

When near joints, it may cause stiffness and effusion.

In the spine, it can lead to muscle spasms and scoliosis.

Radiology

X-Ray:

Dense sclerosis with a small, rounded area of osteolysis, often obscured by the surrounding sclerosis.

The characteristic lesion is less than 1.5 cm in diameter with a sclerotic margin and radiolucent nidus.

 

Isotope bone scans (Best investigation) are positive

Histology

Consists of a mesh of woven bone, osteoblastic rimming, osteoclasts, and dilated capillaries.

The mature osteoid forms the nidus, surrounded by dense, reactive bone and soft tissue with inflammatory changes.

Treatment

CT-guided radiofrequency ablation.

Surgical excision of the nidus (gold standard)

Chondroblastoma (Option A) is a benign tumour affecting the epiphysis. It is usually asymptomatic. X rays show a clear osteolytic lesion in the epiphysis.

Skeletal TB (Option C) also presents with increased pain in the nights, but this patient does not have any other symptoms characteristic of tuberculosis.

Osteosarcoma (Option D) is a malignant bone tumour that affects the metaphysis. X rays show sunburst appearance.

questions.text: Which muscle is attached to lesser trochanter?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Psoas major muscle

Explanation:

Hip flexors, including their origin, attachment, and function:

Hip Flexor Muscle

Origin

Attachment

Function

Iliopsoas (Psoas major + Iliacus)
  • Psoas major: Transverse processes of T12-L5 vertebrae
  • Iliacus: Iliac fossa of the pelvis
  • Both muscles combine and attach at the lesser trochanter of the femur
  • Primary hip flexor
  • Flexion of the hip joint
  • Assists in trunk flexion (psoas)

Rectus Femoris
  • Anterior inferior iliac spine (AIIS) and acetabulum
  • Tibial tuberosity via the patellar tendon
  • Flexion of the hip
  • Extends the knee

Sartorius
  • Anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS)
  • Medial surface of the tibia (Pes anserinus)
  • Flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation of the hip
  • Flexion of the knee

Tensor Fasciae Latae (TFL)
  • Anterior part of the iliac crest
  • Anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS)
  • Iliotibial band (ITB), which attaches to the lateral condyle of the tibia
  • Flexion and abduction of the hip
  • Medial rotation of the hip

Pectineus
  • Pectineal line of the pubis
  • Pectineal line of the femur
  • Flexion and adduction of the hip

Adductor Longus
  • Pubic bone near the pubic symphysis
  • Medial linea aspera of the femur
  • Flexion of the hip (when the hip is in extension)
  • Adduction of the hip

Psoas minor (Option B)

  • Inserted into the illiopectinal eminence
  • Innervated by the anterior rami of L1, 2
  • Flexes the thigh

Obturator internus (Option C)

  • Inserted into greater trochanter of the femur
  • Innervated by the nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1)
  • Laterally rotates extended thigh and abducts flexed hip

Piriformis (Option A)

  • Inserts superiorly into the tip of the greater trochanter.
  • Innervated by the branches of anterior rami (S1, S2)
  • Laterally rotates extended thigh and abducts flexed hip

questions.text: All of the following is seen in the terrible triad of elbow, except.

choices.text: Fracture of the coronoid process of ulna

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Fracture of the olecranon

Explanation: All of the following are components of the "terrible triad of the elbow" except fracture of the olecranon.

Terrible Triad of the Elbow: It refers to a specific injury pattern involving three components, commonly seen in elbow dislocations, particularly after trauma:

  • Posterior elbow dislocation (Option A ruled out)
  • Fracture of the radial head (Option B ruled out)
  • Fracture of the coronoid process (Option D ruled out)
  • Mechanism of Injury: Typically results from a fall on an outstretched hand with the elbow slightly flexed. A valgus twist can lead to a posterolateral dislocation.
  • Treatment: The standard treatment involves reduction under anaesthesia, followed by immobilisation in an above-elbow cast.

questions.text: Stages of the demographic cycle with the same birth rate but variable death rate are?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Stage 1 + stage 2

Explanation:

  • Stage 1 (High Stationary) and Stage 2 (Early Expanding) have the same birth rate, i.e., both have a high birth rate.
  • However, the death rate differs:
    • Stage 1: High death rate.
    • Stage 2: Declining death rate (due to improved healthcare, sanitation, and nutrition).

Since the birth rate remains high in both stages but the death rate decreases in Stage 2, the correct answer is Stage 1 + Stage 2.

According to the demographic transition model, a country goes through 5 phases.

Stages

Birth rate

Death rate

Population

High stationery

High

High

Population is stable

Early expanding

High

Starts declining

Population rapidly expands

Late expanding

Starts declining

Keeps declining

Population still grows (birth > death)

Low stationery

Low

Low

Stable population

Declining

Low

Lower

Population declines (death > birth)

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C & D are incorrect

questions.text: A patient with pneumonia provides a BAL sample, as shown below. What is the likely pathogen responsible, and what is the relative management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pneumocystis Carinii, Cotrimoxazole

Explanation:

  • In HIV-positive patients or immunocompromised individuals, Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly known as Pneumocystis carinii) is a common pathogen responsible for Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). The diagnosis is often made with a bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) sample, where the characteristic cystic forms of the organism can be observed under microscopy or identified through staining techniques (such as silver stain or direct fluorescent antibody staining).

Cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is the first-line treatment for Pneumocystis pneumonia.

Pneumocystis jirovecii

Morphology
  1. Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped, 1-5 µm in size
  2. Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase, 5-8 µm in size
  3. Cyst - thick-walled, spherical, containing up to 8 intracystic bodies and up to 8 µm in size

Risk factors
  • HIV: CD4 < 200
  • Primary immunodeficiency states
  • Transplant recipients
  • Hematological malignancies

Clinical features

Transmitted by respiratory droplets and is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, life-threatening pneumonia develops.

PCP - Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia

  • Dyspnoea
  • Dry cough
  • Fever
  • Weight loss
  • B/L interstitial pneumonia causing bilateral infiltrates

Diagnosis
  • GMS / Giemsa stain- mc used
  • Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains can demonstrate trophozoites - cyst wall is black with a methenamine silver stain.

 

Crushed Ping Pong ball (also called Helmet/Hat or Cup and Saucer appearance).

  • The β-d-glucan test has proven to be quite useful for rapid diagnosis of Pneumocystis pneumonia with a high degree of sensitivity and specificity.

Treatment
  • The cornerstone for both prevention and treatment is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
  • Alternative therapies have been used in AIDS patients; they include pentamidine, trimethoprim-dapsone, clindamycin-primaquine, atovaquone, and trimetrexate.

Incorrect Options:

Mucormycosis, Terbinafine (Option A): Mucormycosis is caused by Mucor species and typically affects immunocompromised patients, but it is usually treated with Amphotericin B, not terbinafine.

Aspergillus, Amphotericin B (Option B): Aspergillus species can cause lung infections, especially in immunocompromised patients, but the presentation here points more to Pneumocystis jirovecii than to Aspergillus. Amphotericin B would be used for Aspergillus, but it's not the correct treatment for Pneumocystis.

Candida, Itraconazole (Option D): Candida can cause fungal infections in immunocompromised patients, but it is more commonly associated with mucosal infections or disseminated infections, not pneumonia that would present with findings typical of Pneumocystis pneumonia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of diphtheria toxin?

choices.text: ADP phosphorylation of EF-2 - Decreasing protein synthesis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) ADP phosphorylation of EF-2 - Decreasing protein synthesis

Explanation:

  • Diphtheria toxin is produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae and inhibits protein synthesis in host cells through the ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2). This modification prevents EF-2 from functioning properly in the process of translation, thereby halting protein synthesis. The result is cellular death, and this mechanism is primarily responsible for the tissue damage observed in diphtheria, particularly in the respiratory system.

Diphtheria Toxin:

Aspect

Details

Production and Structure
  • DT is a protein exotoxin produced by the toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • Consists of two fragments(Bipartite), A and B, with a molecular weight of approximately 62,000 daltons.

Role of Lysogenic β-phage
  • The tox gene is carried by a lysogenic β-phage.
  • Only phage-infected strains produce toxin; nontoxigenic strains can become toxigenic if infected.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae remains localized at the infection site, with only the toxin entering circulation, causing toxaemia but not bacteremia.

Mechanism of Action
  • Fragment B binds host cell receptors, facilitating fragment A entry into the cytoplasm.
  • Fragment A catalyses ADP-ribosylation of EF-2, halting protein synthesis.

Potency
  • The lethal dose for a 250g guinea pig: is 0.0001 mg.
  • The estimated lethal dose for humans: 130 ng/kg body weight.

Systemic Effects
  • DT spreads via blood, causing myocarditis and neuritis.
  • Myocarditis is potentially fatal.

Factors Affecting Production
  • Influenced by environmental factors: alkaline pH (7.8-8.0), oxygen, and iron concentration in the growth medium.
  • High production with low iron availability (0.1 mg/l); iron addition inhibits production (0.5 mg/l).

Toxoid Formation
  • Treatment with formalin (0.2-0.4%), and incubation at 37°C for 4-6 weeks converts DT to toxoid.
  • Toxoid lacks toxicity but induces an immune response; used in vaccines.

Immunity
  • Immunity is primarily mediated by antitoxin antibodies neutralizing DT.

Incorrect Options:

Increasing cAMP (Option B): This is the mechanism of action for toxins like the cholera toxin or the pertussis toxin, not diphtheria toxin.

Increasing cGMP (Option C): This is typically seen in other bacterial toxins (e.g., E. coli enterotoxins), but not in diphtheria.

Decreasing 60s ribosome (Option D): While protein synthesis is affected by diphtheria toxin, it does not directly decrease the 60S ribosome, but rather modifies EF-2, which is necessary for the elongation step in protein synthesis.

questions.text: Infection in humans occurs by ingestion of quadrinucleate cysts through contaminated food or water. Which of the following is likely the cause of this infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Entamoeba Histolytica

Explanation:

  • Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that causes amoebiasis (also known as amoebic dysentery). It is transmitted through the ingestion of quadrinucleate cysts found in contaminated food or water. These cysts are ingested and then transform into trophozoites in the intestines, where they can cause symptoms ranging from mild diarrhea to severe dysentery and, in some cases, liver abscesses.
  • E.histolytica causes amoebic dysentery and a wide range of other invasive diseases, including amoebic liver abscesses.

Morphology: Has three stages:

  1. Trophozoite
  2. Precyst
  3. Cyst

Life Cycle:

  • Host: Single host, i.e. man.
  • Infective form: Mature quadrinucleate cyst
  • Mode of transmission: E. histolytica is transmitted by
    • Feco-oral route (most common)
    • Sexual (anogenital or orogenital) contact
    • Very rarely by vectors (mechanical transmission from faeces).
  • Development in Human Intestine:
    • Small intestine: Undergoes excystation
    • Large intestine: Multiplication and colonization.
  • Manifestations:
    • Asymptomatic cyst passers
    • Amoebic dysentery
    • Invasive amoebiasis
  • Encystation: When the lesions start healing, and the patient improves, trophozoites transform into cysts and then into cysts in the large intestine, which are liberated in faeces. These cysts are infective.

Giardia lamblia (Option A): The life cycle of Giardia lamblia involves ingestion of cysts from contaminated food or water. These cysts transform into trophozoites in the small intestine, multiply, and eventually form new cysts that are excreted in the feces to infect new hosts. This causes giardiasis.

Cryptosporidium parvum (Option C): This protozoan causes cryptosporidiosis, typically transmitted through contaminated water, but it does not involve quadrinucleate cysts.

Cyclospora cayetanensis (Option D): This parasite causes cyclosporiasis, which is also transmitted via contaminated food or water, but its cysts are not quadrinucleate.

questions.text: Which of the following is the diagnostic test for monkeypox?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) PCR

Explanation:

  • Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is the most commonly used and accurate diagnostic test for monkeypox. PCR tests can detect the DNA of the monkeypox virus in clinical samples, such as lesions, blood, or respiratory secretions, allowing for a precise diagnosis.

Monkeypox infections
  • The monkeypox virus belongs to the Orthopoxvirus genus.
  • Monkeypox is a rare zoonotic infection first recognized in captive monkeys in 1958.

Transmission
  • Infection likely occurs through direct contact with wild animals.
  • The exact primary reservoir host remains unidentified, but species such as squirrels, rabbits, and rodents can be infected.

Clinical features
  • Symptoms resemble those of smallpox but are generally milder.
  • Fever and rash.
  • Lymphadenopathy is a prominent feature in most cases, unlike in smallpox or chickenpox.

Complications
  • Respiratory distress
  • Secondary bacterial infections

Vaccination

The vaccinia vaccine can offer protection against monkeypox or lessen its severity.

Human-to-Human transmission
  • Transmission between humans is considered limited.
  • Estimates suggest that only about 15% of close contacts of infected individuals become infected.

Diagnosis
  • The CDC recommends the collection of two specimens, each from multiple lesions from different locations.
  • Confirmed via isolation in viral culture or by PCR for mpox virus DNA from a patient specimen.

Incorrect Options:

ELISA (Option A): While ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) can be used to detect antibodies or antigens, it is not the gold standard for diagnosing monkeypox. It may be used to detect antibodies in some cases but is not as definitive as PCR.

Hemagglutination assay (Option B): This test is used for detecting viruses like influenza or other viruses that cause red blood cell agglutination. It is not commonly used for diagnosing monkeypox.

Hybrid Capture assay (Option D): This is primarily used for detecting viral DNA, such as for HPV (Human Papillomavirus) infections, and is not used for monkeypox.

questions.text: Which test is used in the detection of long term glucose tolerance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) HbA1C

Explanation:

  • HbA1C (Glycated hemoglobin) is the test used to assess long-term glucose tolerance and the average blood sugar levels over the past 3 months. It reflects the percentage of hemoglobin that has glucose attached to it, providing an indicator of overall blood sugar control.

Incorrect Options:

Fasting blood glucose (Option A): This measures blood sugar levels after fasting for at least 8 hours. It is useful for diagnosing diabetes but does not provide a long-term view of glucose tolerance.

Random blood glucose (Option B): This measures blood glucose at any time of the day, regardless of when the person last ate. It is useful for diagnosing diabetes, but again, it does not provide a long-term assessment.

CBC (Complete Blood Count) (Option D): This is a blood test that measures various components of the blood, such as red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. It is not related to glucose metabolism.

questions.text: The below slide represents a gomori methenamine silver stained slide with acute angle branching and septate hyphae. What is the organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aspergillus

Explanation:

  • The description of acute angle branching and septate hyphae seen on a Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stained slide is characteristic of the Aspergillus species. Aspergillus is a genus of fungi that often causes infections in immunocompromised individuals, particularly in the lungs (e.g., aspergillosis). The hyphae of Aspergillus are septate (divided into segments) and form acute angle branching (typically at a 45-degree angle).

Morphology of different fungi

Fungi

Morphology 

Microscopy 

Aspergillus

Acute angle dichotomous branching hyphae + septate h hi yphae

Mucor and Rhizopus species

(Option D)

Broad, aseptate hyphae branching at 90 degree or more

Candida

(Option B)

Single-cell with or without pseudohyphae


Blastomycosis (Option A): The organism responsible is Blastomyces dermatitidis, which does not have acute angle branching. It typically presents as broad-based budding yeast in tissues, not septate hyphae.

questions.text: The image illustrates which vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Niacin (Vitamin B3) Deficiency

Explanation:

  • The patient’s presentation with diarrhea, dermatitis (lesions on the neck resembling Casal's necklace), and likely dementia indicates pellagra, a condition caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency.
  • Maize lacks adequate niacin and tryptophan (a precursor of niacin), predisposing individuals to pellagra when consumed as a staple without proper processing or supplementation.
Niacin (Vitamin B3)
Chemical Structure
  • Niacin: Pyridine-3-carboxylic acid.
  • Niacinamide: Acid amide derivative.
  • Active tissue form: Niacinamide
Coenzyme Forms and Functions
  • NAD+: Generates 2.5 ATPs in oxidative phosphorylation.
  • NADPH: Used in reductive biosynthesis (e.g., fatty acid synthesis).
  • Provides ADP-ribose for protein modification (ADP-ribosylation).
Synthesis and Metabolism
  • 60 mg of tryptophan = 1 mg niacin (requires pyridoxal phosphate-dependent kynureninase).
  • Niacin attaches to ribose phosphate, forming a mononucleotide, then combines with AMP to form dinucleotides.
Deficiency Causes
  • Dietary Deficiency: Staple diets like maize (bound niacin) or sorghum (leucine inhibits niacin conversion).
  • Enzyme Defects: Pyridoxal deficiency inhibits kynureninase activity.
  • Drugs: Isoniazid inhibits pyridoxal phosphate formation.
  • Congenital Disorders: Hartnup disease (impaired tryptophan absorption and increased urinary excretion).
  • Carcinoid Syndrome: Excess tryptophan used for serotonin synthesis.
Clinical Condition
  • Pellagra: Niacin or tryptophan deficiency causing "rough skin".
  • Symptoms (3 Ds): Dermatitis (Casal’s necklace), Diarrhea (may involve blood/mucus), Dementia (irritability, poor memory, delirium).
Sources
  • Richest: Dried yeast, rice polishing, liver, peanuts, cereals, legumes, meat, fish.
  • 50% requirement met by tryptophan conversion.
RDA
  • Adults: 20 mg/day; Additional 5 mg during lactation.
Therapeutic Uses
  • Lowers serum cholesterol and Lp(a) by reducing free fatty acid flux from adipose tissue.
Toxicity
  • Excess (>50 mg/day): Vasodilation, itching, liver damage.

 

Vitamin A Deficiency (Option A): This typically leads to issues such as night blindness and xerophthalmia (dry eyes), but it does not cause the symptoms shown in the image.

Vitamin E Deficiency (Option B): Vitamin E deficiency can result in neurological problems and muscle weakness, but it does not cause the symptoms depicted in the image.

Vitamin C Deficiency (Option C): This leads to scurvy, which is characterized by bleeding gums, joint pain, and skin issues, but is not associated with the symptoms shown in the image.

questions.text: Which of the following uses CRISPR-Cas9 technology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) DNA Editing

Explanation:

  • CRISPR cas9 is used in editing parts of the genome by removing, adding or altering sections of the DNA sequence. It is currently the simplest, most versatile and precise method of genetic manipulation.

C-clustered

R-regulatory

I-interspaced

S-short

P-palindromic

R-repeats

 

  • NHEJ and HEJ are the two mechanisms employed by the CRISPR-Cas9 System. It is a powerful tool for inducing precise double-stranded breaks in DNA.

 

CRISPR-Cas9 System

  • Components:
    • Guide RNA (gRNA): Directs the Cas9 enzyme to a specific DNA sequence.
    • Cas9 Enzyme: Induces double-stranded breaks (DSBs) at the target site.
  • Repair Mechanisms:
    • Non-homologous end Joining (NHEJ): This technique directly ligates broken DNA ends without a template, often leading to small insertions or deletions. It can also cause gene knockout by disrupting the coding sequence.
    • Homologous End Joining (HEJ): Uses a homologous template for precise repair of Double strand breaks and enables accurate gene knock-in or correction of mutations.

 

Post-transcriptional Modification (Option B): This process involves changes to RNA after it has been transcribed from DNA, such as splicing, capping, and polyadenylation. It does not involve CRISPR-Cas9 technology, which primarily targets DNA rather than RNA.

DNA Induction (Option C): This term is not commonly used in the context of CRISPR-Cas9 technology. CRISPR-Cas9 is focused on directly editing DNA sequences rather than inducing changes.

DNA Editing Solution (Option D): While CRISPR-Cas9 is a powerful tool for DNA editing, the term "DNA Editing Solution" is vague and not specific to the CRISPR-Cas9 system itself.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for the reversal of anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Neostigmine

  • Neostigmine is the most commonly used medication for the reversal of neuromuscular blockade.

Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that increases acetylcholine levels by blocking the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, enhancing nerve transmission.

Uses:

  • Myasthenia Gravis: Improves muscle strength by enhancing neuromuscular transmission.
  • Reversal of Neuromuscular Blockade: Reverses muscle paralysis from certain anesthetics after surgery.
  • Postoperative Urinary Retention: Stimulates bladder function.
  • Anticholinergic Toxicity: Helps treat toxicity from anticholinergic drugs.

Side Effects:

  • Muscarinic effects: Bradycardia, hypotension, excessive salivation, nausea, diarrhea.
  • Nicotinic effects: Muscle weakness, twitching, respiratory issues (in overdose).
  • Cholinergic Crisis: Overdose can cause severe muscle weakness and respiratory distress.

Incorrect Options:

Atropine & Glycopyrrolate (Options B and C) are used to manage bradycardia and to reduce secretions and are not used for reversing neuromuscular blockade

Midazolam (Option D): Benzodiazepine is not used as a reversal agent.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with agitation, confusion, and gait abnormalities. What vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Methylcobalamin (Vitamin B12) deficiency

Explanation:

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to neurological symptoms such as gait abnormalities, confusion, and agitation. It often causes a condition known as Subacute Combined Degeneration (SACD) of the spinal cord. This condition includes:
    • Sensory neuropathy: Tingling and numbness in the extremities.
    • Motor neuropathy: Weakness and gait disturbances.
    • Cranial nerve involvement: Potentially affecting cognitive functions and causing confusion.

 

Features of Chronic Alcoholism

Vit. B12 Deficiency

(Option C)
  • Chronic alcohol use can lead to functional vitamin B12 deficiency, even if blood tests show normal levels.
  • Alcohol interferes with vitamin B12 absorption and metabolism.
  • Vitamin B12 is essential for DNA synthesis and maintaining healthy nerves and red blood cells.
  • Symptoms of B12 deficiency include fatigue, weakness, numbness, and balance problems.
  • Alcohol can damage the liver, which might cause falsely high B12 levels in blood tests, making diagnosis challenging.

Folate Deficiency

(Option B ruled out)
  • Folate (vitamin B9) deficiency is common in chronic alcoholics, affecting 6-80% of them.
  • Alcohol disrupts folate by impairing its absorption, transport, and liver storage.
  • Poor diet in alcoholics worsens folate deficiency.
  • Folate is crucial for making red blood cells and DNA.
  • Deficiency can cause megaloblastic anaemia and neurological issues like peripheral neuropathy and cognitive problems.

Hypoglycemia

 
  • Chronic alcohol consumption can cause low blood sugar (hypoglycemia), especially if not eating enough.
  • Alcohol produces a high NADH/NAD+ ratio in the cytoplasm, the high NADH level favours the conversion of pyruvate to lactate, leading to lactic acidosis.
  • Deficiency of pyruvate leads to inadequate formationof oxaloacetate which blocks gluconeogenesis
  • This results in low blood sugar levels.
  • Symptoms of alcohol-induced hypoglycemia include confusion, irritability, and, in severe cases, loss of consciousness.

Nicotinamide (Vitamin B3) Deficiency (Option A): Deficiency in Vitamin B3 can lead to pellagra, characterized by the "three D's": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.

Tyrosinase (Option D): Tyrosinase is an enzyme involved in melanin production, not a vitamin. It is not related to the symptoms described.

questions.text: Which of the following intravenous anesthetics functions as an NMDA receptor antagonist?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Ketamine

Explanation:

  • Ketamine is an NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptor antagonist.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Inhibits N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor (NMDA) receptors (Option A), affecting the CNS.
  • Induces dissociative anesthesia, making patients appear conscious but unable to process sensory input.
  • Influences endogenous analgesic pathways.
  • High lipid solubility (5 to 10 times that of thiopental) and low protein binding (12%).
  • S(+) isomer (Ketanest) is 3 to 4 times more potent as an analgesic with fewer psychomimetic effects.
  • S(+) ketamine causes cognitive impairment and reduced reaction time despite its analgesic properties.
  • S(+) isomer has higher NMDA affinity and potency.

Pharmacokinetics

  • Absorption: Primarily given intravenously or intramuscularly; peak levels in 10-15 minutes.
  • Distribution: Highly lipid-soluble; rapid brain uptake with a 10-15 minute distribution half-life.
  • Biotransformation: Metabolized in the liver to active metabolites; tolerance develops with repeated use.
  • Excretion: Renally excreted; elimination half-life of about 2 hours.

Incorrect Options:

Propofol and Thiopentone (Options B and C) are direct GABA-A receptor agonists that enhance GABA’s effects.

Midazolam (Options D) is a benzodiazepine, increases GABA's effect by modifying the receptor to make it more responsive to GABA.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency leads to Laryngismus stridulus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Vitamin D

Explanation:

  • Vitamin D deficiency is responsible for Laryngismus stridulus

Laryngismus stridulus:

Aspect

Details

Etiology
  • Hypocalcemia (rickets, hypoparathyroidism)
  • GERD
  • Viral infections
  • Allergies
  • Stress/emotions
  • Cold air, smoke
  • Rare: neurological issues

Symptoms
  • Sudden stridor
  • Breath-holding
  • Cough/choke
  • Cyanosis
  • Anxiety
  • Normal between attacks
  • No fever (unless infection)

Investigations
  • Serum calcium, phosphate, vitamin D
  • Chest X-ray
  • Laryngoscopy (if needed)
  • pH probe (for GERD)
  • Allergy tests

Treatment
  • Acute:
  • Calm child
  • Humidified air
  • Oxygen if needed
  • Upright position
  • Underlying cause:
  • Correct calcium/vitamin D
  • Treat GERD
  • Avoid allergens
  • Supportive care for infections
  • Psychological support

Prevention
  • Adequate nutrition (vitamin D, calcium)
  • Manage triggers
  • Parental education

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & D: Vitamin K, E and A deficiencies do not lead to Laryngismus stridulus.

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations is associated with Vitamin A deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bitot's spots

Explanation

  • Bitot's spots are characteristic of Vitamin A deficiency. They appear as triangular, foamy, white or yellowish spots on the conjunctiva, typically found on the lateral side of the eye and are a result of keratinization of the conjunctiva.

                                         Bitot's spots

 

Causes for Vitamin A Deficiency :

  • Decreased intake.
  • Obstructive jaundice: Defective absorption.
  • Liver cirrhosis: Reduce synthesis of RBP (retinol binding protein).
  • Severe malnutrition: Lack of amino acids for RBP synthesis.
  • Chronic nephrosis: RBP excretion through urine.

 

Vitamin A Deficiency Manifestations :

1) Ocular manifestations :

  • Vitamin A deficiency is the most significant preventable cause of blindness, especially in children below 5 in developing countries.
  • Early Signs:
    • Loss of sensitivity to green light.
    • Difficulty adapting to dim light.
    • Night blindness.
  • Prolonged Deficiency:
    • Xerophthalmia:
      1. Dry, thick, keratinized conjunctiva and cornea. If untreated, it leads to corneal ulceration and ultimately results in blindness due to the formation of opaque scar tissue.
      2. WHO grading of xerophthalmia:

XN
  • Night blindness.

X1
  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis.
  • X1B: Bitot spots.

X2
  • Corneal xerosis.

X3
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration, less than one-third.
  • X3B: Corneal ulceration, more than one-third.

XS
  • Corneal scar.

XF
  • Xerophthalmic fundus.

 

  • Bitot's Spots
  • Keratomalacia: When xerophthalmia persists for a longer time, it progresses to keratomalacia (corneal softening)
     

2) Immune Function:

  • Deficiency increases susceptibility to infections.
  • Infection reduces retinol-binding protein synthesis, lowering vitamin A levels and impairing immune responses.

3) Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions:

  • Follicular Hyperkeratosis (Phrynoderma): Causes rough skin due to hyperkeratinization of the follicular epithelium.
  • Keratinizing Metaplasia: Affects respiratory, gastrointestinal, and genitourinary tracts.
  • Epithelium is atrophied.

4) Other General Manifestation :

  • Growth retardation due to defective synthesis of chondroitin sulfate.
  • Decreased protein synthesis.

 

Vogt's striae (Option A): These are associated with keratoconus, not Vitamin A deficiency. Vogt's striae are streaks in the cornea seen in this condition.

Arlt's line (Option C): This is associated with trachoma, an infectious disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, not Vitamin A deficiency. Arlt's line is a horizontal line found on the inner surface of the eyelid.

Horner's dots (Option D): These are associated with vernal keratoconjunctivitis, not Vitamin A deficiency. Horner's dots are small, discrete, grayish-white spots found on the conjunctiva.

questions.text: What is the name of the staging system used for Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Radkowski’s

Explanation:

  • Radkowski’s classification is used for Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma:

I A

Involvement limited to the nose or naso-pharynx

I B

Extension into one or more sinuses

II A

Minimal extension into pterygopalatine fossa

II B

Occupies the entire pterygopalatine fossa with or without erosion of the orbital арех

II C

Involvement of the infratemporal fossa with or without extension to the cheek or posterior to pterygoid plates

III A

Erosion of the skull base (the middle cranial fossa/base of the pterygoids), minimal intracranial extension

III B

Erosion of the skull base, extensive intracranial extension with or without cavernous sinus invasion


Incorrect Options:

Option B -TNM staging: TNM staging is not used for Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma

Option C - Ann Arbor staging system: Ann Arbor staging system is used for Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Option D - Dukes criteria: Dukes criteria is used for Infective endocarditis.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is used in a tube for collecting blood samples specifically for measuring alcohol concentration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sodium fluoride + Potassium dichromate

Explanation

  • Sodium fluoride is an antiglycolytic agent that inhibits the breakdown of glucose, and Potassium dichromate is a reagent that stabilizes the sample for accurate alcohol concentration measurement. This combination is specifically used for alcohol testing because it prevents the metabolism of alcohol in the sample.

 

Blood Collection Tubes

Tube Type

Additives & Mechanism

Key Applications

Coagulation Tube

Sodium citrate binds calcium (Factor IV) to prevent clotting; anticoagulation reversed by adding calcium.
  • Used for coagulation studies.
  • Must be filled completely.

 

Serum Tube
  • Glass/silica activates clotting (Factor XII).
  • Some include gel separators to prevent cellular contamination.
  • Used for clinical chemistry, immunology, and serology.

 

Heparin Tube

Sodium/lithium heparin inhibits thrombin and Factor Xa to prevent clotting.
  • Common in biochemical tests.

 

EDTA Tube

EDTA chelates calcium irreversibly, preventing clotting.
  • Preferred for hematology.
  • Stable for enzymatic studies.

Glycolytic Inhibitor Tube

Sodium fluoride inhibits glycolysis; may also include citrate, oxalate, or EDTA to prevent clotting.
  • Used to measure glucose and lactate levels.

 

Heparin + EDTA (Option A): Both heparin and EDTA are anticoagulants, they are not specifically used for preserving blood samples for alcohol concentration measurement. They lack the ability to inhibit glycolysis, which can alter alcohol levels in the sample.

Heparin (Option C): Heparin is an anticoagulant used to prevent blood clotting, but it is not suitable for alcohol concentration tests as it does not preserve the sample for this specific purpose.

Sodium citrate (Option D): Sodium citrate is an anticoagulant used mainly for coagulation studies, but it is not used for measuring blood alcohol concentration.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient presents with pellagra-like skin eruptions during the spring season for the past 5 years. Laboratory tests reveal normal levels of 5-Hydroxyindoleacetic Acid (HIAA), high aminoaciduria, and normal urinary indole levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hartnup disorder

Explanation

  • The patient's presentation is consistent with Hartnup disease (Pellagra-like dermatosis), a rare inborn error of metabolism. This condition is associated with impaired transport of monoamine monocarboxylic amino acids across the brush border epithelium of the intestine and renal tubules.

 

Hartnup disorder

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Pathogenesis

Mutation in SLC6A19 gene; Impaired transport of neutral amino acids across intestinal and kidney brush border epithelium

Clinical features
  • Photosensitivity
  • Pellagra-like rash (Decreased Niacin due to tryptophan deficiency)
  • Neurologic symptoms (ataxia, emotional instability) - Decreased serotonin due to tryptophan deficiency

Biochemical defect

Deficiency of nicotinamide synthesis

Diagnosis
  • Aminoaciduria (neutral amino acids) in urine and plasma
  • Demonstrate SLC6A19 defect

Treatment
  • Administration of nicotinamide/nicotinic acid
  • Protection from sunlight

 

Carcinoid tumor (Option A): Carcinoid tumors cause increased serotonin production, which is metabolized to 5-HIAA and excreted in urine. The normal 5-HIAA levels in this patient rule out carcinoid syndrome.

Nutritional pellagra (Option B): Nutritional pellagra is caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency and is characterized by the "4 Ds": diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and death. However, this patient has high aminoaciduria, which is not typical of nutritional pellagra.

Essential fructosuria (Option D): It is caused by a deficiency of fructokinase, leading to the excretion of unmetabolized fructose in the urine. It does not cause pellagra-like symptoms or high aminoaciduria.

questions.text: Which of the following are symptoms of Gradenigo syndrome?

choices.text: Ear discharge, retro-orbital pain, and diplopia
Nasal discharge, retro-orbital pain, and diplopia
Ear discharge, retro-orbital pain, and headache
Retro-orbital pain, Diplopia, and hearing loss

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Ear discharge, retro-orbital pain, and diplopia

Explanation:

  • Gradenigo Syndrome: Classic triad:
    • External rectus palsy (VIth nerve palsy).
    • Deep-seated ear or retro-orbital pain (Vth nerve involvement).
    • Persistent ear discharge.
  • Gradenigo syndrome is a rare but serious complication of middle ear infections (specifically otitis media).
  • It happens when the infection spreads to the petrous part of the temporal bone.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C & D: These are not the correct triad of Gradenigo syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following post-translational modifications is common to collagen, hemoglobin, and immunoglobulins?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Subunit aggregation

Explanation

  • Subunit aggregation refers to the assembly of protein subunits into a functional multimeric structure. This process is seen in hemoglobin, collagen, and immunoglobulins.

 

Hydroxylation (Option A): This is a post-translational modification involving the addition of hydroxyl groups to amino acids. While hydroxylation is important in collagen synthesis, it is not a common modification for hemoglobin and immunoglobulins.

Poly A tail addition (Option C): This is a post-transcriptional modification that involves adding a polyadenine tail to the 3' end of mRNA. It helps in mRNA stability and translation efficiency but does not pertain to the protein structures in question.

DNA mismatch repair (Option D): DNA mismatch repair is a genomic maintenance process that corrects errors in DNA replication. It is unrelated to protein post-translational modifications.

questions.text: Which structure does the anterior ethmoidal sinus drain into?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Middle meatus

Explanation:

  • Anterior ethmoidal sinus drains into the middle meatus.

Anterior ethmoidal sinus:

Aspect

Details

Definition
  • Air-filled cavities within the ethmoid bone
  • Part of the ethmoidal sinus system

Location
  • Between the nasal cavity and the orbit
  • Anterior group of ethmoidal air cells (compared to middle/posterior groups)

Drainage Pathway

Drains into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity via the infundibulum and hiatus semilunaris

Innervation

Supplied by the anterior ethmoidal nerve, a branch of the nasociliary nerve (from CN V1 – ophthalmic division)

Blood Supply

Anterior ethmoidal artery (branch of ophthalmic artery)

Clinical Relevance
  • Can be involved in sinusitis (especially if drainage is blocked)
  • Close to orbit and anterior cranial fossa — risk of orbital cellulitis or intracranial spread if infected

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C & D: The anterior ethmoidal sinus does not drain in these sinuses.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of chronic alcoholism presents with skin lesions. His diet primarily consists of polished rice. Based on his symptoms and dietary history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Beriberi

Explanation

  • Beriberi is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which is common in individuals with chronic alcoholism and diets lacking in unpolished grains.
  • The Aleurone layer of cereals (food grains) is a rich source of thiamine. Therefore, whole wheat flour and unpolished hand-pound rice have better nutritive value than completely polished refined foods.
  • When the grains are polished, the aleurone layer is usually removed.

 

Deficiency:

Dry beriberi:

  • CNS manifestations are more common
  • Pain, paresthesia and loss of reflexes
  • Peripheral neuritis with sensory disturbances

Wet beriberi:

  • Wet beriberi is characterized by cardiovascular symptoms such as breathlessness, palpitations, and peripheral oedema.
  • Distended neck veins observed
  • High output cardiac failure (Option C)

 

Biochemical parameters:

  • Thiamine deficiency affects the enzyme transketolase, which is involved in the pentose phosphate pathway.
    • Measuring transketolase activity in red blood cells is a specific test for thiamine deficiency and can confirm the diagnosis. (Option C)
    • Erythrocyte transketolase activity is reduced; this is the earliest manifestation seen even before clinical disturbances.
  • Recommended Daily Allowance of Thiamine is 1–1.5 mg/day.

 

Phrynoderma (Option A): Phrynoderma, also known as follicular hyperkeratosis, is associated with vitamin A deficiency. While it can present with skin changes, it is not typically linked to chronic alcoholism or a diet primarily consisting of polished rice.

Beriberi (Option B): Polished rice lacks thiamine, leading to symptoms such as skin lesions, neuropathy, and cardiac issues in severe cases.

Psoriasis (Option C): Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterized by well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales. It is not related to diet or chronic alcoholism.

Eczema (Option D): Eczema, or atopic dermatitis, is a hypersensitivity reaction presenting with pruritic, inflamed skin. It is unrelated to nutritional deficiencies or chronic alcoholism.

questions.text: Gastric lavage is contraindicated in which of the following poisonings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Hydrocarbons

Explanation:

  • Hydrocarbons (such as gasoline, kerosene, or other petroleum products) are highly dangerous if aspirated into the lungs. They can cause severe chemical pneumonitis and aspiration pneumonia, so gastric lavage is contraindicated in hydrocarbon poisoning.

Gastric Lavage in Poisoning Management

  • Gastric lavage is a procedure to remove ingested poison by introducing and withdrawing fluids through an orogastric tube. Its effectiveness depends on timing, proper technique, and patient-specific considerations.

Timing and Effectiveness

  • Most effective within 1 hour of ingestion (Option A ruled out)
  • Can be beneficial up to 4-6 hours in select cases
  • Beyond 6 hours, poison likely passes into the intestines, reducing lavage efficacy

Procedure Steps

Step

Details

Patient Positioning

Trendelenburg: Head down to prevent aspiration

Left lateral decubitus: Reduces chance of poison entering the duodenum

Tube Placement Confirmation

Inject air and listen for gastric bubbling sounds

Watch for coughing or bubbles (indicates misplacement in trachea)

Fluid Administration

Fluid is administered and aspirated using a syringe attached to the tube

Fluid Selection

Tap water for most cases

Normal saline for infants

Specific solutions (e.g., potassium permanganate) may be used for certain poisons

Residual Fluid

Leave a small amount of fluid to neutralize remaining poison

Contraindications

  • Corrosive Poisoning: Avoid except for carbolic acid (phenol) to prevent perforation
  • Convulsant Poisons: Risk of triggering seizures (e.g., strychnine)
  • Comatose Patients: High aspiration risk
  • Volatile Poisons/Hydrocarbons: May cause aspiration pneumonitis (Option C)
  • Risk of Hemorrhage/Perforation: Avoid if esophageal varices or recent surgery present
  • Additional Contraindications to Emetics
    • Severe heart or lung diseases
    • Advanced pregnancy
    • CNS depression or seizures

Complications

Complication

Details

Aspiration

Occurs in ~10% of cases. Risk of lung injury

Esophageal/Gastric Perforation

Can be life-threatening

Tube Misplacement

Misplaced into trachea, causing complications

Bleeding

Can occur with improper technique or pathology

Alternatives to Gastric Lavage

Alternative

Description

Emetics

Induce vomiting in conscious patients

Dilution

Large water intake to dilute corrosive substances

Endoscopic/Surgical Removal

Used for toxic foreign bodies or drug packets

questions.text: Most common organ involved in seat-belt injury is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Hollow viscus

Explanation:

  • The most common organ involved in seat belt injury ideally is the mesentery.
  • Since the given options do not contain mesentery the best option here is hollow viscus.

Explanation:

  • Illustration shown is seat belt injury - Mesentery is most commonly affected due to seatbelt injuries.

Seat belts:

  • Restraints the body against severe deceleration and hence preventing impact from windscreen, steering wheel and other obstruction. Though it slows down deceleration, it can jam at a certain point leading to injuries.
  • Follows Inertia-reel mechanism.
  • Primarily of two types:
    • Shoulder diagonal (most commonly used in vehicles)
    • Lap strap (aircrafts)

Seat Belt injuries:

Patterned contusion (known as Seat belt sign)
  • Drivers: starts from the right shoulder
  • Passengers: starts from the left shoulder

Intra-abdominal (deceleration- compression)
  • Mesentery - most commonly affected (Option D)
  • Small intestine: DJ flexure (primary),Ileocaecal junction (secondary)
  • Liver, Spleen, Pancreas(Option A, B and C)

Vertebral injuries (distraction- compression)
  • Distraction(separation of joint): seen on posterior side
  • Compression: seen on anterior side
  • Chance fracture: fracture involving all 3 columns of spine

Seat belt syndrome
  • Seat belt sign + intra-abdominal injuries + vertebral injuries

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the OPD with painful genital ulcers along with painful bubos. And he had a history of multiple sexual partners. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chancroid

Explanation:

The patient's presentation of multiple painful genital ulcers with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy is highly suggestive of chancroid, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Chancroid:

  • Caused by Haemophilus ducreyi manifests as multiple ulcers in the genital area, characterized by their non-indurated nature, undermined edges, greyish slough, and tendency to bleed on touch.
  • Individuals with chancroid may develop unilateral, painful lymphadenopathy.
  • The suppurative lymphadenopathy observed in chancroid is termed bubo.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Gram staining reveals Gram-negative bacilli arranged in chains, often referred to as "railway tracks" or "school of fish" appearance.
    • Culturing specimens on Mueller Hinton Agar supplemented with chocolate horse blood aids in the identification of Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • Treatment:
    • Azithromycin is administered orally in a single dose of 1 gram
    • OR intramuscular injection of Ceftriaxone at a dosage of 250 mg (single dose)

 

Ulcer

Lymph Node

 

Syphilis - treponema Pallidum

(Option D)

Painless genital ulcer called a chancre

Non-tender and rubbery in consistency.

 

Donovanosis- Klebsiella granulomatis

(Option B)

Painless, beefy red ulcers known as granulomas

Pseudo-bubo (enlarged and tender but occurs due to inflammation and not infection)

Herpes Simplex

(Option C)

Grouped vesicles or shallow erosions

Multiple, enlarged and inflamed.

Lymphogranuloma Venerum

(Chlamydia)

Solitary and painless.
  • Swollen, inflamed, and fluctuant lymph nodes containing purulent material.
  • Palpable groove or furrow that may be felt in the inguinal region due to the enlargement and fusion of the inguinal lymph nodes. (Groove of Greenlat)

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents with complaints of multiple soft, pedunculated masses scattered across his torso and limbs. The parents mention that the child has recently developed some difficulty in reading and learning. Upon examination, the child has hyperpigmented macules with irregular borders on his back, and the ocular exam shows the findings below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) NF1

Explanation:

The child presents with:

  • Multiple soft, pedunculated masses → Likely neurofibromas
  • Hyperpigmented macules with irregular borders → Café-au-lait spots
  • Ocular findings (likely Lisch nodules on iris examination)
  • Learning difficulties

These findings are characteristic of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1), an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17, which encodes neurofibromin (a tumor suppressor protein).

Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1)

  • Incidence: 1 in 3,000 live births.
  • Inheritance:
    • 50% of cases are inherited from a parent.
    • 50% due to spontaneous mutations.
  • Genetics: Autosomal dominant loss-of-function mutations in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17q11.2. The gene encodes neurofibromin, which inhibits the oncogene Ras.

Diagnosis Criteria (Two or more required)

Feature

Description

Café-au-lait macules (CALMs)

>5 mm in prepubertal, >15 mm in postpubertal.

6 or more needed for diagnosis

Axillary/Inguinal Freckling

Multiple hyperpigmented areas, 2-3 mm in diameter.

Iris Lisch Nodules

Hamartomas in the iris, best seen with a slit-lamp.

2 or more needed for diagnosis

Neurofibromas

Two or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neurofibroma.

Osseous Lesion

Sphenoid dysplasia or cortical thinning of long bones.

Congenital pseudarthrosis of the tibia.

Optic Gliomas

CNS tumor affecting the optic nerve.

 

Family History

First-degree relative with an NF1 diagnosis based on these criteria.

Management

  • Regular Monitoring:
  • Treatment Considerations:
    • Avoid routine brain/optic tract imaging unless symptomatic.
    • Selumetinib: Effective in children with inoperable plexiform neurofibromas.
  • Neuropsychological and Educational Support.

Genetic Counseling

  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant; over 50% of cases are de novo mutations.
  • Molecular Testing:
    • Useful in cases with unclear clinical diagnosis or severe disease.
    • Prenatal/preimplantation diagnosis may be considered.
