NF2 (Neurofibromatosis Type 2) (Option A): NF2 is associated with bilateral vestibular schwannomas, hearing loss, and juvenile cataracts, rather than café-au-lait spots and Lisch nodules. It is caused by a mutation in the NF2 gene (Merlin protein) on chromosome 22.

TSC1 (Tuberous Sclerosis Complex 1) (Option B): TSC1 is associated with hamartomas, facial angiofibromas, hypopigmented “ash-leaf” macules, and cortical tubers, not café-au-lait spots and neurofibromas. It is due to a mutation in the TSC1 gene (hamartin) on chromosome 9.

TSC2 (Tuberous Sclerosis Complex 2) (Option C): Similar to TSC1, TSC2 presents with hypopigmented macules, facial angiofibromas, and neurological issues like epilepsy but is due to a mutation in the TSC2 gene (tuberin) on chromosome 16.

questions.text: Unknown substance consumption leading to tachycardia and red-colored halo is seen with?
questions.solution:
Correct Options: C) LSD

Explanation:

  • Tachycardia and visual hallucinations of red-colored halo are indicative of consumption of LSD.
  • LSD - Lysergic acid Diethylamide: Acid blotter or paper stamp or taken as fumes.
  • Obtained from rye fungus (ergot).
  • Increases serotonin level in the brain (only psychological dependence).
  • Associated with the trip (most common)
  • Good trip
    • Visual hallucinations and illusions
  • Bad trip
    • Anxiety
    • Panic attacks
  • Flashback phenomenon is seen (re-experiencing the past experience).


Incorrect Options:

Cannabis (Option A) (marijuana) use typically does not cause significant tachycardia. While cannabis can induce visual hallucinations in some individuals, they are more commonly associated with LSD and other hallucinogens.

Crack/ cocaine (Option B) use is known to cause tachycardia due to its stimulant effects on the central nervous system. Cocaine can sometimes induce tactile hallucinations of bugs crawling on the skin (formication).

Heroine (Option D) use is more commonly associated with symptoms such as sedation, respiratory depression, and pinpoint pupils (miosis).

questions.text: Bubo is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) LGV

Explanation: A bubo is an enlarged, tender, and suppurative lymph node commonly associated with Lymphogranuloma Venereum (LGV), a sexually transmitted infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis

Lymphogranuloma venerum (LGV):

  • It is a sexually transmitted disease caused by serovars L1-L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis (M/C strain causing LGV: L2).
  • It occurs in sexually active adults of all ages. It can cause LGV-associated proctitis in homosexuals, associated with HIV and hepatitis C co-infection.
  • The incubation period of LGV is around 3-30 days, and the disease presents in three stages, described in the table below:

Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

3-30 days

Days-weeks

Years after a chronic, untreated infection

Small papule/pustule/
Non-indurated ulcer at the site of inoculation which heals spontaneously with no scarring.
  • Lymphatic involvement of nodes that drain the primary lesion.
  • Classic form: Tender unilateral or bilateral inguinal and/or femoral adenopathy (Groove sign of Greenblatt).
  • The lymph nodes may coalesce to form a bubo or abscesses that may rupture spontaneously with the development of
    Fistulae or sinus tracts.
  • There may be systemic features such as malaise and fever.

Lymphatic obstruction due to chronic inflammation leads to fistula formation, strictures, and disfiguring conditions such as genital elephantiasis and esthiomene, which refers to hypertrophic enlargement with ulceration of the external genitalia.

 

Diagnosis of LGV can be confirmed by the Nucelic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT). Antibody detection by real-time PCR can also be done. Treatment includes:

  • First line: Doxycycline 100mg BD x 21 days.
  • Second line: Erythromycin 500mg 4 times a day x 21 days.
  • Third line: Azithromycin 1g weekly once x 21 days.

 

 

Ulcer

Lymph Node

 

Syphilis - treponema Pallidum

(Option C)

Painless genital ulcer called a chancre

Non-tender and rubbery in consistency.

 

Donovanosis- Klebsiella granulomatis

(Option D)

Painless, beefy red ulcers known as granulomas

Pseudo-bubo (enlarged and tender but occurs due to inflammation and not infection)

Herpes Simplex

(Option B)

Grouped vesicles or shallow erosions

Multiple, enlarged and inflamed.

Lymphogranuloma Venerum

(Chlamydia)

Solitary and painless.
  • Swollen, inflamed, and fluctuant lymph nodes containing purulent material.
  • Palpable groove or furrow that may be felt in the inguinal region due to the enlargement and fusion of the inguinal lymph nodes. (Groove of Greenlat)

questions.text: The most common organ injuries in air blast shock waves will be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Lungs

Explanation:

  • The most common organ injured in an air blast shock wave is the tympanic membrane (TM); given that the options do not contain TM, the next best answer is the lung.
  • Blast lung is a primary blast injury. The shock wave causes immediate lung injury, characterized by the rupture of alveolar capillaries.

Blast Injury:

Extent of Damage

  • Greater damage compared to bullet injuries due to complex blast waves.
  • Explosion pressure wave exceeds 1000 pounds per square inch, involving incident and reflected pressure.

Factors Causing Damage

  • High-pressure wave impact.
  • Mechanical, chemical, and thermal injuries.
  • Inhalation of toxic gases and smoke.

Types of blast injuries:

 

Air Blast Injuries

Underwater Blast Injuries

Most commonly injured:

Tympanic membrane (ear) - Rupture and middle ear damage are common
  • Tympanic membrane (ear) - More likely to occur when the head is submerged.
  • Gastrointestinal tract - When the head is not submerged.

Most severely injured:

Lungs - Blast lung injury is a common cause of delayed mortality and can cause pulmonary contusion, air embolism, and other damage

Gastrointestinal tract - Underwater blasts can cause more severe GI injuries due to pressure effects on hollow organs


Intestine, kidney, and heart (Options A, C, and D) are not the most common injuries in air blast

questions.text: Which of the following structures is responsible for balance and hearing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Vestibule

Explanation:

The vestibule is a part of the inner ear which is responsible for hearing and balance.

The vestibular system is divided into

1. Peripheral: made of membranous labyrinth (SCC, utricle, and saccule) and vestibular nerve

  • Membranous labyrinth:
    • It is present in the labyrinth/inner ear enclosed by the bony labyrinth.
    • The lateral wall of the vestibule (central chamber) of the bony labyrinth has the oval window (Option C)
    • The medial wall has two recesses,
      • A spherical recess that carries the saccule (Option A)
      • An elliptical recess that carries the utricle
    • The opening of the aqueduct of the vestibule is located below the elliptical recess which has the endolymphatic duct.
    • The posterosuperior part of the vestibule has 5 openings of semicircular canals (Option B).
  • Vestibular nerve:
    • Central processes of the vestibular or Scarpa’s ganglion forms the vestibular nerve.
    • Transmits the signals from hair cells in the inner ear to the vestibular nuclei

2. Central: made of the nuclei (superior, medial, lateral, descending nuclei) and fiber tracts in CNS.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Semicircular canal: The semicircular canals are responsible for maintaining balance.

Option B - Cochlea: The cochlea is responsible for hearing.

Option D - Organ of Corti: The organ of Corti is a sense organ of hearing located on the basilar membrane in scala media.

questions.text: The condition shown in the image below is seen in which vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Niacin

Explanation:

The condition described in the image is Pellagra, which is caused by niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency.

Pellagra is characterized by the classic triad of symptoms:

  • Dermatitis
    • Bright red erythema- in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet)
    • Casal’s necklace- ↑pigmentation around the neck
  • Diarrhoea, and
  • Dementia.

Causes of pellagra :

  • Dietary Deficiency- Maize and Sorghum based diet
  • Impaired Tryptophan Metabolism
    • Factors Affecting Tryptophan to Niacin Conversion:
      • Vitamin B6 Deficiency
      • Medications: Isoniazid (INH), OCPs
      • Hormonal Influences: Estrogen metabolites hinder tryptophan metabolism.
      • Genetic Disorders: Inherited conditions like Hartnup disease can impede tryptophan absorption in the intestines and reabsorption in the kidneys
  • Carcinoid Syndrome
  • Other Contributing Factors:
    • Alcoholism: Interferes with nutrient absorption, including niacin and tryptophan.
    • Malabsorption Syndromes

Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) Deficiency (Option A): Causes cheilitis, glossitis, irritability, and peripheral neuropathy, but not the characteristic photosensitive rash.

Cobalamin (Vitamin B12) Deficiency (Option B): Leads to megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, and glossitis, but not pellagra.

Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) Deficiency (Option D): Presents with angular cheilitis, glossitis.

questions.text: A fracture has occurred at the cribriform plate area of the ethmoid bone. The patient can present with which symptom?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) CSF Rhinorrhoea:

Explanation:

  • The most common cause of CSF rhinorrhea is trauma, and the most common site of CSF leak (CSF Rhinorrhoea) is the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone, which is the weakest part of the bone.

Common Sites of CSF Rhinorrhea

Anterior cranial fossa

Middle cranial fossa

Temporal bone fracture
  • Cribriform plate(most common)
  • Roof of ethmoid air cells
  • Frontal sinus

Sphenoid sinus(following trauma)

CSF reaches the middle ear, escaping through the eustachian tube into the nose(CSF otorhinorrhea)

Aetiology

  • Trauma (Most common): Accidental or surgical (e.g., sinus surgery, nasal polypectomy, skull base surgery).
  • Inflammations: Mucocoeles, fungal infections, osteomyelitis, sinus polyposis.
  • Neoplasms: Benign and malignant tumours invading the skull base.
  • Congenital: Meningocele, meningoencephaloceles, gliomas with skull base defects.
  • Idiopathic: Spontaneous leaks with no known cause.

Investigations for CSF Rhinorrhea

  • Handkerchief test (Halo sign): Simple bedside test; CSF forms clear halo around blood spot.
  • Beta-2 transferrin: Gold standard biochemical test; highly specific for CSF.
  • High-Resolution CT (HRCT): Identifies bony defects in skull base.
  • CT Cisternography: Contrast-enhanced; precise localization of active CSF leaks.
  • MRI Cisternography: Non-invasive; useful for identifying meningoceles/encephaloceles.
  • Fluorescein Test: Intrathecal dye injection; helps in intraoperative leak localization.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & D: Hearing loss, visual loss, and diplopia are not the symptoms of trauma (fracture) to the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone.

questions.text: Which of the following courts has the authority to commute a death sentence?

choices.text: Session court and additional session court

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) High court

Explanation:

  • High courts have the authority to review and hear appeals against death sentences imposed by lower courts. During the appeal process, a high court can confirm, reverse, or modify the sentence based on the merits of the case under article 226 and 227.
  • If a high court finds that the death sentence was unjustly imposed, it has the power to commute the sentence to life imprisonment or another lesser sentence.

Courts of Law

Level

Court/Judge

Maximum Imprisonment

Maximum Fine

1 (Highest)

Supreme Court

Any period, including death sentence

Any amount

2

High Court

Any period, including death sentence

Any amount

3

District and Sessions Court (Option D)

Any period, including death sentence (needs confirmation by High Court)

Any amount

4

Assistant Sessions Judge (Option A and B)

Up to 10 years

Any amount

5

Chief Judicial/Chief Metropolitan Magistrate

Up to 7 years

Any amount

6

First Class Judicial/Metropolitan Magistrate

Up to 3 years

Up to ₹ 10,000

7 (Lowest)

Second Class Judicial Magistrate

Up to 1 year

Up to ₹ 5,000

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive hearing loss that has been worsening over the past few years. Audiometry confirms conductive hearing loss, and a diagnosis of otosclerosis is made. What is the surgical treatment of choice for her condition?

choices.text: Stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis

Explanation:

  • Stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis is the surgical treatment of choice for Otosclerosis

Stapedotomy vs. Stapedectomy

Procedure

Description

Complications

Stapedotomy

Small opening made in the stapes footplate; a prosthesis is inserted.

Lower complication rates; preferred by many otologists.

Stapedectomy

Complete removal of the stapes bone; replaced with a prosthetic device.

Higher risk of complications.

 

Incorrect Options:


Options B, C & D: Stapedotomy, Stapes mobilization, and Lemperts Fenestration operation are the surgical management of Otosclerosis, but the treatment of choice is Stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant female presents to the emergency department with a BP of 220/120mm Hg, along with headache, seizure, and blurred vision. Which of the following is the preferred intravenous medication for the management of hypertension in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) IV Labetalol

Explanation:

  • The patient’s presentation is suggestive of a hypertensive crisis.
  • IV Labetalol is the preferred intravenous medication for the management of hypertension in pregnancy due to its efficacy and safety profile.
  • It is a non-selective beta-blocker, which has both alpha and beta-blocking effects, leading to vasodilation and a subsequent reduction in blood pressure.
  • Initial IV dose: 10–20 mg, then 20–80 mg every 10–30 mins up to 300 mg.
  • Continuous IV infusion: 1–2 mg/min.
  • Fewer side effects than alternatives and less tachycardia.

Incorrect Options:

IV nitroglycerine (Option B) is a vasodilator that can reduce blood pressure by causing venodilation, which decreases preload. It is not typically the first choice for pregnant women.

IV hydralazine (Option C) is a vasodilator that is reserved for cases with cardiac/renal dysfunction in pregnancy. It is used as a second-line drug to control hypertension in pregnancy.

IV sodium nitroprusside (Option D) is a potent vasodilator used in hypertensive crisis, but it is not a first-line drug preferred in pregnancy.

questions.text: To perform MTP for a mentally challenged female, consent is obtained from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Legal guardian

Explanation:

  • In cases where a mentally challenged female is unable to provide consent for a medical procedure such as Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP), the consent of her legal guardian is typically required.

Options A, C and D are incorrect

questions.text: Which drug is used to test for Myasthenia Gravis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Edrophonium

Explanation:

A myasthenic crisis is characterized by severe muscle weakness that responds to edrophonium administration, while a cholinergic crisis does not improve with this drug.

  • Edrophonium Test: Used to diagnose Myasthenia Gravis (MG)
  • Principle: Edrophonium inhibits the enzyme acetylcholinesterase (AChE), which normally breaks down acetylcholine (ACh) at the neuromuscular junction. By inhibiting AChE, edrophonium increases acetylcholine levels, allowing it to interact more with the available acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) in the muscle, temporarily improving neuromuscular transmission and muscle strength in MG.

Test Procedure:

  • Initial Dose: Administer 2 mg IV of edrophonium.
  • Evaluation: After 30 seconds, observe for improvement in muscle strength (e.g., in extraocular muscles, speech, or arm strength).
  • Positive Test: If the patient shows improvement in muscle strength, the test is considered positive for MG and is terminated.
  • Additional Dose: If no response occurs, give an additional 8 mg IV and observe again.
  • Negative Result: If there is no improvement, MG is unlikely, but further testing may be needed to confirm the diagnosis

Incorrect Options:

Pyridostigmine (Option A) is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that is specifically used to increase acetylcholine activity at the neuromuscular junction and is used for the long-term treatment of Myasthenia Gravis rather than for diagnosis.

Neostigmine (Option B) is also an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor and is used for the long-term treatment of Myasthenia Gravis rather than for diagnosis.

Atropine (Option D) is a muscarinic antagonist used to treat bradycardia (low heart rate), and it is not involved in the diagnosis of Myasthenia Gravis.

questions.text: Which of the following is punishable under the MTP Act?

choices.text: Non-entry in MTP-register, not sending report to DDHS

questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Non-entry in MTP-register, not sending report to DDHS

Explanation:

  • Failure to maintain proper records or report abortions to the appropriate authorities can lead to legal consequences.
  • Specifically, non-entry in the MTP register and failure to send a report to the District Deputy Health and Family Welfare Officer (DDHS) are considered punishable offenses under the MTP Act.

Incorrect Options:

MTP done up to 24 weeks (Option A) The Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act allows for abortions to be performed up to 24 weeks of gestation under certain conditions, such as when there is a risk to the life or physical or mental health of the woman, or if there is a substantial risk that the child would be born with physical or mental abnormalities.

Done by government-authorized center (Option B) The MTP Act permits abortions to be performed by registered medical practitioners (RMPs) in government-approved facilities, as well as by private practitioners in registered private clinics.

Done by experienced RMP (Option C) Under the MTP Act, abortions can be performed by registered medical practitioners (RMPs) who have undergone training and certification in the provision of abortion services

questions.text: Which drug can be used to treat both HIV and Hepatitis B?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tenofovir

Explanation:

  • Tenofovir is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that is used to treat both HIV and Hepatitis B virus infections. It works by inhibiting the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is essential for the replication of both HIV and HBV.

Tenofovir (Nucleotide analogue RTI)

MOA
  • No phosphorylation is required (Option A)
  • Competitively inhibits viral reverse transcriptase
  • Incorporates into HIV DNA, causing chain termination (due to incomplete ribose ring)

Types
  • Tenofovir disoproxil: short-acting, more side effects
  • Tenofovir alafenamide: long-acting

Uses
  • DOC for HIV
  • DOC for Hepatitis B virus + HIV
  • HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (in combination with emtricitabine)

Side effects
  • Nephrotoxic (Acute renal failure)
    • Regular creatinine and phosphorus monitoring.
    • Avoid with NSAIDs
  • Fanconi syndrome (causes damage to PCT of nephron)
    • Leads to phosphate loss
    • Hypophosphatemic rickets, osteoporosis
  • Hepatitis B exacerbation with abrupt discontinuation

Contraindication
  • Renal disease (High creatinine)
    • Replace tenofovir with Zidovudine or Abacavir
  • Child < 10 years
  • Weight < 30 kg

Incorrect Options:

Dolutegravir (Option A) is an integrase transfer inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV. However, it is not used for Hepatitis B.

Zidovudine (Option C) is an NRTI used in the treatment of HIV, but does not have activity against Hepatitis B because it specifically targets reverse transcriptase of HIV and is not effective against the reverse transcriptase enzyme of Hepatitis B.

Ritonavir (Option D) is a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV. It is mainly used to boost the effects of other protease inhibitors through CYP3A inhibition, but it does not have activity against Hepatitis B.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in GERD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Domperidone

Explanation:

  • The primary treatment of GERD includes proton pump inhibitors and prokinetic agents. Domperidone is a prokinetic agent used in the treatment of GERD.
  • It helps to close the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), thereby reducing the reflux of stomach contents into the esophagus.

Incorrect Options:

Ondansetron (Option A) is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist, primarily used to prevent nausea and vomiting, especially in chemotherapy or post-surgical patients. It does not treat GERD.

Loperamide (Option C) is an antidiarrheal agent used to treat diarrhea, but it does not treat GERD.

Diphenoxylate (Option D) is also an antidiarrheal agent and does not have any direct role in managing GERD.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action (MOA) of Rivaroxaban?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Inhibition of Factor Xa

Explanation:

  • Rivaroxaban is an oral factor Xa inhibitor. It works by inhibiting factor Xa, which is an important component in the coagulation cascade.
  • It is used for various indications, including prevention and treatment of deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and prevention of stroke and systemic embolism in patients with atrial fibrillation.

Type

Mechanism of Action

Drugs

Direct Thrombin Inhibitors

Inhibit thrombin (factor IIa) directly without cofactors.

(Option A)

Hirudin derivatives: Hirudin, Lepirudin.

Non-hirudin (Synthetic): Argatroban, Bivalirudin.

Indirect Thrombin Inhibitors

Enhance antithrombin III activity to inhibit thrombin indirectly.

(Option C)

 

 

Unfractionated Heparin: Heparin

Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH): Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin

Ultra Low Molecular Weight Heparin (ULMWH): Fondaparinux, Idraparinux, Danaparoid (not commonly used)

Inhibition of platelet aggregation (Option D): Platelet aggregation is primarily mediated by platelet receptors (like the ADP receptor or thromboxane A2), and drugs that inhibit platelet aggregation include aspirin and P2Y12 inhibitors (like clopidogrel). Rivaroxaban works on the coagulation cascade by inhibiting Factor Xa and not through platelet inhibition.

questions.text: Which of the following is the half-life of lithium in adults?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 24 hours

Explanation:

  • In healthy adults, the half-life of lithium is approximately around 24 hours.
  • The half-life of lithium is 12 hrs in the young and 36 hours in the elderly (or longer due to a reduced GFR).

Pharmacokinetics of Lithium

Salt

Lithium carbonate or citrate.

Route of administration

Oral or IV

Half-life
  • Healthy adults: 24 hours.
  • Young: 12 hrs in the young
  • Older: 36 hours in the elderly (or longer due to a reduced GFR).

Metabolism

It is not metabolized in the body; it remains unchanged in the system.

Excretion

Excreted unchanged in all body secretions

  • Maximum in the urine
  • Sweat, saliva and breast milk

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred treatment for Plasmodium falciparum malaria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT)

Explanation:

  • The preferred treatment for Plasmodium falciparum malaria is Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT).
  • According to current guidelines, Artesunate is the preferred initial treatment for severe or complicated malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.
  • It has been shown to reduce parasite burden and mortality in severe malaria cases rapidly.
  • Other options like quinine and artemether are also effective, but artesunate is generally favoured due to its faster onset of action and superior efficacy in severe malaria.
  • Chloroquine is not recommended for the treatment of severe malaria, as Plasmodium falciparum is resistant to chloroquine, making it ineffective. (Option A)

Complicated malaria is a life-threatening form of malaria caused by P. falciparum. Treatment is given parenterally.

  • DOC: IV Artemisinin
  • 2nd: IM artemether/arteether
  • 3rd: IV Quinine in 5% dextrose (quinine is hypoglycemic)

Primaquine (Option C) disrupts the parasite's electron transport chain; it is used as a radical cure for malaria caused by P. vivax and P. ovale (targets hypnozoites).

Doxycycline (Option D) is used for malaria prophylaxis or in combination with other antimalarials for treatment, but it is not the preferred first-line treatment for Plasmodium falciparum malaria.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice (DOC) for treating morning sickness in pregnant women?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6)

Explanation:

  • The first-line treatment for morning sickness is Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6), either alone or in combination with doxylamine (an antihistamine)
  • Morning sickness, or nausea and vomiting during pregnancy, is a common condition that affects many pregnant women, particularly in the first trimester.

Incorrect Options:

Domperidone (Option B) is a prokinetic drug that can help with nausea and vomiting, but it is not the first-line treatment for morning sickness.

Ondansetron (Option C) is a serotonin 5-HT3 receptor antagonist and is used to treat nausea and vomiting, particularly in chemotherapy-induced nausea. However, it is generally not recommended as the first-line treatment for morning sickness during pregnancy.

Metoclopramide (Option D) is another antiemetic and prokinetic drug used to treat nausea and vomiting. It can be used for morning sickness in pregnancy, but it is not considered first line in the management of morning sickness.

questions.text: Which of the following structures contain Ostmann fat pad?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Eustachian tube

Explanation:

  • The nasopharyngeal end of the eustachian tube contains the Ostmann pad of fat.
  • Purpose: closure of the Eustachian tube and protection from nasopharyngeal secretions

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D do not contain the Ostmann pad of fat.

questions.text: A patient with low mood, no mood to eat, always sleeping, and low energy presented to you with such symptoms for 2 months. She had similar symptoms 5 months ago, which subsided with medications. Identify the disorder.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Recurrent depressive disorder

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with low mood, loss of appetite, excessive sleep, and low energy for the past 2 months, along with a history of a similar episode 5 months ago that resolved with medication.
  • This pattern is consistent with Recurrent Depressive Disorder, which is characterised by two or more depressive episodes with a minimum of 2 months between episodes.

Incorrect Options:

Depression (Option A) involves sadness, anhedonia, low energy, fatigue, sleep issues, guilt, poor concentration, negative thoughts, and suicidal ideation. Diagnosed when five or more symptoms occur over two weeks, with at least one being a depressed mood or loss of interest, and a normal period of 2 months between episodes.

Dysthymia (Option C), also known as Dysthymic Disorder or Persistent Depressive Disorder, involves chronic, mild depressive symptoms that persist most of the day, nearly every day. According to DSM-5, it is diagnosed when depressive symptoms last for 2 or more years (or 1 year for children), with no symptom-free periods exceeding 2 months.

Cyclothymia (Option D), according to DSM-5, is characterised by depressive and hypomanic symptoms lasting at least 2 years (or 1 year for children), with symptoms present for at least 50% of the time during this period.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a defence mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Replacement

Explanation:

Replacement is not a recognised defence mechanism.

  • Defence mechanisms are unconscious strategies used by the ego to cope with internal conflicts between the id (instinctual desires) and the superego (moral standards).
  • These mechanisms help protect the individual from anxiety and emotional discomfort.
  • Examples include Sublimation (channelling unacceptable impulses into socially acceptable activities), Displacement (redirecting emotions to a safer target), and Altruism (helping others to reduce personal distress).

Defence mechanisms are classified as:

Narcissistic

Immature

Neurotic defences

Mature defences
  • Projection
  • Denial
  • Blocking
  • Acting out
  • Regression
  • Introjection
  • Projective identification
  • Passive aggressive
  • Somatisation
  • Inhibition
  • Intellectualisation
  • Isolation of affect
  • Displacement (Option B ruled out)
  • Dissociation
  • Undoing
  • Rationalisation
  • Reaction formation
  • Repression
  • Altruism (Option D ruled out)
  • Anticipation
  • Asceticism
  • Sublimation (Option A ruled out)
  • Suppression
  • Humor
  • All the mechanisms are unconscious except suppression.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with deafness presents for evaluation and is diagnosed with 50dB hearing loss. Which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this hearing loss?

choices.text: Ossicular fixation with an intact tympanic membrane
Ossicular fixation with a damaged tympanic membrane

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Ossicular fixation with an intact tympanic membrane

Explanation:

  • The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of otosclerosis. It occurs as ossicular fixation with an intact tympanic membrane.
  • Pure-tone Audiometry in otosclerosis
    • Diagnoses and characterizes hearing loss.
    • Initial low-frequency conductive loss progresses to flat maximal loss as stapes become fixed.
    • Carhart effect may reduce bone conduction thresholds, noticeable at 2 kHz.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not responsible for the patient’s presentation.

questions.text: A patient was taking metronidazole for diarrhoea. He attended a party where he consumed alcohol. Following this, he developed red rashes, itching all over his body, and a headache. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Disulfiram-like reaction

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms of red rashes, itching, and headache after consuming alcohol while on metronidazole suggest a Disulfiram-like reaction.
  • This occurs when metronidazole interacts with alcohol, causing symptoms such as flushing, nausea, sweating, and headache, similar to the effects of disulfiram (Antabuse), which is used to discourage alcohol consumption.

 

  • When alcohol is ingested by someone taking disulfiram, it inhibits the enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to the accumulation of acetaldehyde in the blood, which causes unpleasant symptoms.
    • Flushing
    • Headache
    • Nausea & vomiting
    • Sweating
    • Palpitations, chest pain, and dizziness
    • Dyspnea
    • Hypotension and circulatory collapse

Drugs causing disulfiram-like reaction: (Mnemonic- CGMP)

They are contraindicated in active drinkers.

  • Chlorpropamide
  • Cephalosporins (mnemonic- PMTX):
    • CefoPerazone
    • CefaMandole
    • CefoTetan
    • CefoXitin
  • Griseofulvin
  • Metronidazole
  • Procarbazine

Methanol poisoning (Option A) occurs as a result of drinking contaminated beverages with methanol and presents as drowsiness and a reduced level of consciousness. It is not associated with metronidazole.

Cheese reaction (Option C) occurs when monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) block the breakdown of tyramine from foods like aged cheese, causing a surge in norepinephrine release. This leads to symptoms such as severe headaches, palpitations, and high blood pressure. The treatment for this reaction includes phentolamine, an alpha-blocker, to help manage the symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with the curtain falling sign?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Retinal detachment

Explanation:

  • Curtain falling in front of the eye is seen in case of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.
  • Retinal detachment refers to the separation of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium.

Etiology:

  • Age: most common in 40-60 years.
  • Sex. More common in males (M:F - 3:2).
  • Myopia. About 40% cases of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment are myopic.
  • Aphakia and pseudophakia.
  • Trauma. It may also act as a predisposing factor.
  • Senile posterior vitreous detachment (PVD): It is associated with retinal detachment in many cases.
  • Retinal degenerations predisposed to retinal detachment: Lattice degeneration, Snail track degeneration, Acquired or degenerative retinoschisis, and Focal pigment clumps.

Retinal detachment can be classified into three types:

  1. Rhegmatogenous or primary retinal detachment
  2. Tractional retinal detachment
  3. Exudative retinal detachment

Type of Retinal Detachment

Clinical Features

Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment
  • Floaters (dark spots) due to rapid vitreous degeneration.
  • Photopsia (flashes of light) caused by retinal irritation from vitreous movements.
  • Gradual visual field loss, initially localized, progressing to total vision loss as detachment spreads.
  • Dark veil/Curtain falling sign/cloud in front of the eye, particularly when detachment reaches the posterior region.
  • Sudden, painless vision loss in large, central detachment.
  • Retinal breaks may be round, horseshoe-shaped, slit-like, or large anterior dialysis.
  • Vitreous pigments (tobacco dusting or Shaffer sign) are seen in the anterior vitreous with posterior vitreous detachment.
  • Old retinal detachment shows retinal thinning, subretinal demarcation lines (high water marks), and secondary intraretinal cysts.

Tractional Retinal Detachment
  • Gradual, progressive visual loss
  • Typically painless
  • No associated flashes or floaters
  • Vitreoretinal bands present
  • No retinal breaks
  • Detached area - concave and localized
  • No shifting fluid

Exudative Retinal Detachment
  • Painless and sudden or gradual visual loss
  • No photopsia, holes/ tears, folds and undulations.
  • Smooth and convex with pigmentary disturbances
  • Rounded and fixed with neovascularization on the tumor summit.
  • Shifting fluid - changing the position of the detached area with gravity - hallmark feature.

questions.text: Which of the following is the normal conjunctival flora?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Staph Epidermidis

Explanation:

  • The normal conjunctival flora is Staph Epidermidis
  • Staph Epidermidis is the most common organism which is responsible for Acute Onset Endophthalmitis.

Acute endophthalmitis:

Definition
  • Inflammation of inner structures of the eye (uveal tissue and retina) with exudates in the vitreous, anterior, and posterior chambers. It spares sclera.
  • Acute bacterial endophthalmitis happens 1-7 days post intraocular surgery.

M/C causative organism
  • Staphylococcus epidermidis (Option B)

Presentation

  • Severe ocular pain
  • Redness
  • Lacrimation
  • Photophobia
  • Loss of vision
  • Red and swollen lids
  • Conjunctival chemosis
  • Circumcorneal congestion
  • Cloudy cornea
  • Ring infiltration
  • Yellow necrotic wound edges
  • Hypopyon
  • Oedematous and muddy iris
  • Yellow pupil reflex due to purulent exudation
  • Vitreous exudation which causes amaurotic cat's-eye reflex
  • Raised intraocular pressure initially

Treatment

  • Intravitreal antibiotics:
    • First choice: Vancomycin 1 mg + Ceftazidime 2.25 mg
    • Second choice: Vancomycin 1 mg + Amikacin 0.4 mg
  • Topical antibiotics
  • Systemic antibiotics
  • Steroid Therapy
  • Supportive Therapy
  • Vitrectomy - if no improvement in 48-72 hours or if severe infection with vision reduced to hand movements close to the face
  • If blind - no perception of light - Evisceration.

Options A, C & D: Staph aureus, Strep. Pneumonia and H. influenzae are disease causing bacteria and do not form the normal conjunctival flora

questions.text: A patient has sudden loss of vision and there is no fundus glow. There is no history of trauma, what could be the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vitreous hemorrhage

Explanation:

Vitreous Hemorrhage (VH):

  • Seen as blood floating in the vitreous, occluding the view of the retina.
  • Secondary to proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is a cause of severe vision loss in diabetic patients.
  • Absence of fundus glow is a feature of Vitreous hemorrhage
  • In PDR, fibrovascular tissue lies flat on the retina or attaches to the posterior vitreous, leading to vitreous traction, retinal separation, and vessel rupture. This is the most common cause of VH in adults.

Options B, C & D: Acute anterior uveitis, Optic neuritis and Acute congestive glaucoma can also cause sudden loss of vision but there is no loss of fundus glow.

questions.text: What diagnosis is suggested by having different refractive powers (+5D in one eye and +1D in the other eye)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Anisometropic amblyopia

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the child has two different refractive powers in both eyes; +5D in one eye and +1D in the other eye. Anisometropia is the difference between the refractive power of both eyes when > 2.5 D. Anisometropia can lead to Amblyopia

Amblyopia: Definition, Types, and Clinical Characteristics

Definition:

  • Partial, reversible vision loss in one or both eyes.
  • Absence of organic diseases of ocular media, retina, visual pathway
  • The eye appears normal, but vision is impaired.

Types of Amblyopia:

Type

Cause

Key Features

Strabismic Amblyopia

The brain suppresses input from one eye due to constant squint (strabismus).

Common cause; underdevelopment of vision in the deviated eye.

Stimulus Deprivation Amblyopia

Hindered vision due to obstruction from early life (e.g., congenital cataracts, ptosis, dense central corneal opacity).

Lack of visual stimulation affects normal development.

Anisometropic Amblyopia (Option C ruled out)

A significant difference in refractive error between eyes.

The brain favours the clearer eye, leading to amblyopia in the other.

Ametropic Amblyopia

High uncorrected refractive errors in both eyes.

Bilateral; is less severe compared to other types.

Meridional Amblyopia

Uncorrected astigmatism affecting specific visual meridians.

Affects one or both eyes depending on the astigmatism degree.

Refractive errors (Option A) While the condition involves refractive errors, the key point is the significant difference in refractive powers between the two eyes. This disparity leads to anisometropia, which can cause amblyopia. General refractive errors alone do not necessarily lead to amblyopia.

Malingering (Option D) refers to the deliberate faking of symptoms.

questions.text: A patient on antitubercular therapy (ATT) started experiencing visual problems. Which ATT drug is most likely responsible for this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ethambutol

Explanation:

  • Ethambutol is a first-line anti-tubercular drug that causes retrobulbar neuritis, decreased visual acuity and colour blindness.

Ethambutol

MOA

Inhibits arabinosyl transferases involved in arabinogalactan synthesis, thereby interfering with mycolic acid synthesis in cell wall

Mechanism of resistance

Mutation of embAB genes, which encodes the enzyme arabinosyl transferase, reducing its affinity for ethambutol

Uses

In the treatment of

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC)
  • Mycobacterium kansasii

Side effects
  • Painless loss of vision
    • Field defects due to retrobulbar neuritis (Option C)
    • Loss of visual acuity
    • Red-green colour blindness
  • Nausea, rashes, fever

Option A, B and D does not cause visual impairment.

questions.text: Which of the following do not represent the corrected refractive error?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Presbyopia

Explanation:

  • Presbyopia does not represent in the above given image
  • Presbyopia happens around the age of 40 years for an emmetropic person, less than 40 years in hypermetropic patients, and more than 40 years for myopic patients.
  • At 40 years, around +1 D spherical lens is used to correct it. With every year that passes, around 0.5 D increases happen.
  • The first image is of Myopia correction -It is done by concave lens
  • Second image is of Hyperopia correction -It is done by convex lens
  • Third image is of Astigmatism correction -It is done by cylindrical lens

Definition
  • Physiological insufficiency of accommodation is typically associated with aging.

Etio - Pathogenesis

Age-related factors:

  • Decreased elasticity of the lens capsule.
  • Sclerosis of the lens.
  • Possible decline in ciliary muscle power.

Premature causes:

  • Uncorrected hypermetropia
  • Chronic glaucoma

Symptoms
  • Difficulty in near vision
  • Asthenopic symptoms (eye fatigue)
  • Intermittent diplopia

Treatment Options

Optical Treatment:

  • Convex glasses based on age
  • Correct refractive error for distance first
  • Types of Glasses: Unifocal, bifocal, or progressive (varifocal).

Pharmacological therapy:1.25% Pilocarpine(FDA-approved)

Surgical options:

  • Conductive keratoplasty
  • LASIK (Monovision/presbyopic multifocal-LASIK)
  • Corneal inlays
  • Multifocal IOL placement following lens extraction

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P2 requests immediate postpartum contraception after an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. She expresses interest in an intrauterine device (IUD). What is the recommended timeframe for safe postplacental IUD insertion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 48 hours

Explanation:Post-placental IUD insertion can be safely performed within 48 hours of delivery. This timing allows for immediate postpartum contraception while the cervix is still dilated and the uterus is easily accessible.

  • IUD can be inserted immediately following placental delivery
  • The 48-hour window provides optimal timing for insertion
  • Specialized sponge holder is used for high fundal placement
  • Success rates show 88% retention during uterine involution

24 hours (Option A): While insertion is possible within 24 hours, the safe window extends up to 48 hours, making this timeframe unnecessarily restrictive.

6 weeks (Option C): Delaying contraception for six weeks increases the risk of unintended pregnancy in the immediate postpartum period.

12 weeks (Option D): This is beyond the recommended timeframe for post-placental IUD insertion and would require a separate insertion procedure.

questions.text: A 32-week pregnant woman presents with abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. The uterus is tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Abruptio placenta

Explanation: Abruptio placenta is a form of antepartum haemorrhage, where the bleeding occurs due to premature separation of the normally situated placenta.

Pathogenesis:

  • Bleeding occurs due to rupture of blood vessels in the decidua basalis.
  • There is an accumulation of blood in the decidua.
  • This causes the separation of the placenta, leading to
    • Further bleeding.
    • Thrombin generation from haemorrhage triggers the action of matrix metalloproteinases, inflammatory cytokines, and coagulation cascade (high risk of DIC).
    • Fetal distress.

Clinical features:

  • Vaginal bleeding
  • Abdominal pain
  • Uterine tenderness
  • Back pain.
  • Fetal distress.
  • Hypovolemic shock.

Uterine rupture (Option A): This condition typically requires a history of previous cesarean section and presents with palpable fetal parts through the abdominal wall. While it can cause pain and bleeding, the clinical presentation and risk factors don't align with this diagnosis.

Vasa praevia (Option C): This condition characteristically presents with painless bleeding that occurs when membranes rupture. The presence of pain and uterine tenderness makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Placenta praevia (Option D): This condition typically presents with painless, bright red vaginal bleeding without uterine tenderness. The presence of pain and tender uterus in this patient makes placenta praevia an unlikely diagnosis.

questions.text: Until what time after delivery can an Intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) be inserted postpartum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Within 48 hours

Explanation:Intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs) can be inserted postpartum effectively, preferably within 48 hours of delivery.

  • Immediate post-placental insertion is optimal
  • The 48-hour window allows for safe insertion while the cervix remains dilated
  • This timing aligns with the most preferred timing for postpartum IUCD insertion
  • Early insertion reduces the risk of unintended pregnancy in the postpartum period

Within 24 hours (Option A): While insertion is possible within 24 hours, the safe window extends up to 48 hours, making this timeframe unnecessarily restrictive.

Within 6 weeks (Option C): This represents post-puerperal insertion, which is not the optimal timing for postpartum IUCD placement.

Within 12 weeks (Option D): This extends well beyond the recommended timeframe for postpartum IUCD insertion.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is early cord clamping typically performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Rh-negative mother

Explanation:

  • Early cord clamping is performed in cases of Rh-negative mothers to prevent potential complications related to Rh incompatibility.
  • This approach helps to minimize the risk of hemolytic disease of the newborn by reducing the amount of fetal blood that can mix with the maternal circulation.
  • The appropriate timing of cord clamping varies based on clinical scenarios. Early cord clamping is specifically indicated in Rh-negative mothers to prevent allo-immunization.

Eclamptic patient (Option A): In cases of eclampsia, the priority is often to stabilize the mother and deliver the baby promptly. Early cord clamping is not specifically indicated in this situation; management focuses more on the mother's condition and the baby's immediate needs.

Diabetic patient (Option B): Early cord clamping is not a routine practice specifically for diabetic patients. The management of diabetic pregnancies often focuses on blood sugar control and monitoring, rather than the timing of cord clamping.

Preterm delivery (Option C): For preterm infants, delayed cord clamping is generally preferred to allow for optimal blood transfer from the placenta, which can be beneficial for the infant's health. Early cord clamping is usually not recommended in preterm deliveries unless there are specific complications.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with anaemia. Investigations show low serum iron and ferritin levels, along with increased TIBC. Which of the following is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Iron Deficiency Anemia (IDA)

Explanation:

The pattern of low serum iron and ferritin levels, along with increased TIBC (total iron-binding capacity), is characteristic of Iron Deficiency Anemia (IDA).

  • It is the most common nutritional disorder in the world.
  • It results in inadequate haemoglobin synthesis.
  • Causes:
    • Dietary lack
    • Impaired absorption
    • Increased requirement
    • Chronic blood loss
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Iron deficiency initially depletes iron stores (low ferritin) while maintaining normal serum iron and transferrin saturation. As depletion progresses, serum iron declines, leading to reduced haemoglobin synthesis.
    • Hypochromic microcytic anaemia develops once iron stores are exhausted, with low serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation, while total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) increases.
  • Clinical features include koilonychia, alopecia, atrophic glossitis, oesophagal webs, pica, malabsorption, fatigue, pale skin, shortness of breath, dizziness, headaches, tachycardia, cold extremities, and restless legs syndrome.
  • Histopathology:
    • Bone marrow aspiration: increased erythroid progenitors and a lack of stainable iron in macrophages, best assessed by Prussian blue staining.
    • Peripheral blood smears: Red cells are small (microcytic) and pale (hypochromic).
  • Diagnosis:

Iron Study

Interpretation in Iron Deficiency Anemia

Serum Ferritin

Low (< 30 ng/mL) (depleted iron stores). (Option A)

Serum Iron (Fe)

Low levels (Option A)

Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)

Increased TIBC (increased capacity of transferrin to bind iron in response to low iron stores). (Option A)

Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW)

Increased RDW

Bone Marrow Aspiration and Iron Staining

Confirmatory test

Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS) (Option B) is a group of disorders where the bone marrow produces dysfunctional blood cells, leading to cytopenias (anaemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia). It typically presents with multiple cytopenias, severe symptoms like infections or bleeding, and abnormal blood cell production. MDS often shows normal or elevated ferritin, not low iron and ferritin with high TIBC.

Aplastic Anemia (Option C) is a rare condition where the bone marrow fails to produce enough blood cells, leading to pancytopenia (low red and white blood cells and platelets). It typically presents with pancytopenia, not just anaemia, and ferritin is usually normal or slightly elevated, not low with high TIBC.


Anaemia of Chronic Disease (ACD) (Option D) occurs in chronic infections, inflammation, or kidney disease and is caused by impaired iron use and reduced red blood cell production. It typically presents with low serum iron and ferritin, but TIBC is decreased, not increased, due to iron sequestration and impaired utilisation in chronic inflammation.

questions.text: What is the most effective approach to managing mild nausea and vomiting in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Eat small, frequent meals

Explanation: For mild nausea and vomiting during pregnancy, dietary modifications are highly recommended. Eating small, frequent meals can help manage symptoms by preventing the stomach from becoming too empty, which can trigger nausea.

  • Small, frequent meals help maintain stable blood sugar levels
  • Consuming dry biscuits or crackers in the morning on an empty stomach is effective
  • This approach is safe and doesn't require medication
  • It addresses the underlying cause of nausea by preventing an empty stomach

Use domperidone (Option B): Domperidone is a medication used to treat nausea and vomiting but is generally not the first-line treatment for pregnancy-related nausea. It is not recommended as the primary approach due to safety concerns and availability of more effective treatments.

Increase fluid intake (Option C): While increasing fluid intake is important to prevent dehydration, it is not the primary method for managing nausea and vomiting. Hydration alone does not address the underlying causes of nausea and vomiting in pregnancy.

Use metoclopramide (Option D): Metoclopramide is used for moderate to severe nausea and vomiting but is not the first choice for mild symptoms. For more severe cases, medications such as doxylamine combined with pyridoxine, or other anti-emetics, might be considered.

questions.text: What is the ideal number of antenatal visits recommended during pregnancy according to Indian health care systems?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 13 visits

Explanation: The recommended or ideal number of antenatal visits according to Indian healthcare systems is at least 13 visits throughout pregnancy.

WHO Recommended Minimum ANC visits: 8

Govt. Of India Recommended Minimum ANC Visits: 4

Ideal number of visits: 13 or 14

1st Trimester: 1 visit. (within 12 weeks of gestation)

1st visit: <12 weeks

Upto 7 months: once every month

2nd Trimester: 2 visits. (weeks - 20 & 26)

2nd visit: 14-26 weeks

 

8th month: twice every month

3rd Trimester: 5 visits. (weeks - 30, 34, 36, 38 & 40)

3rd visit: 28-32 weeks

9th month: Once every week

 

4th visit: 36 weeks to term

 

6 visits (Option B), 8 visits (Option C), and 4 visits (Option D) are all inadequate according to the ideal recommendation of Indian health care guidelines, though they may represent minimum standards in different guidelines (WHO recommends 8, GOI recommends minimum 4).

questions.text: Based on the given ECG, identify which wall of the myocardium was affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anterior wall

Explanation:

  • The ECG demonstrates ST elevation in leads V2, V3, and V4 is indicative of an anterior wall myocardial infarction (MI)
  • The ECG shows ST segment elevation with a convex upward shape (Pardee sign) in the precordial leads, which is characteristic of acute anterior wall myocardial infarction supplied by the left anterior descending artery.

Infarct Localization based on ECG

Infarct Location

Affected Coronary Artery

Leads

Lateral Wall MI (Option D)

Left Circumflex Artery (LCx)

V5, V6, I, aVL

Septal Wall MI

Septal Branch of Left Anterior Descending Artery (LAD)

V1, V2

Anterior Wall MI (Option A)

Left Anterior Descending Artery (LAD)

V1-V4, I, aVL

Extensive Anterior Wall MI

Left Main Coronary Artery (LMCA)

V1-V6, I, aVL

Posterior Wall MI (Option C)

Posterior Descending Artery (PDA)

V1-V4 (ST depression), V7, V8, V9 (ST elevation)

Inferior Wall MI (Option A)

Right Coronary Artery (RCA)

Leads II, III, aVF

NSTEMI (Anterior Wall)

Left Anterior Descending Artery (LAD)

Often subtle changes in V1-V4

 

Inferior wall (Option A) involvement typically shows ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, which is not present in this ECG tracing. The absence of these changes rules out inferior wall MI.

Posterior wall (Option C) involvement would show ST depression in leads V1-V4 and ST elevation in leads V7, V8, and V9. This pattern is not seen in the current ECG.

Lateral wall (Option D) involvement would show changes in leads V5, V6, I, and aVL. While there may be some changes in these leads, they are not the predominant finding, and the primary area of involvement is clearly anterior.

questions.text: Which of the following is the disorder associated with hexanucleotide repeat?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Frontotemporal dementia

Explanation:

  • The disorder associated with hexanucleotide repeat is Frontotemporal dementia or Frontotemporal Lobar Degeneration (FTLD).
  • These are a heterogeneous group of disorders associated with focal degeneration of frontal and/or temporal lobes.
  • They are associated with cellular inclusions comprised of specific proteins; the two most common patterns are:

Features

FTLD-tau

FTLD-TDP

Inclusions

Cytoplasmic tau inclusions

Inclusions contain TDP-43 (RNA-binding protein)

Associated mutations

Associated with mutations in the MAPT gene (encoding tau)
  • Expansion of a hexanucleotide repeat in the 5′ region of C9orf72.
  • Mutations in the TARDBP gene (encoding TDP-43)
  • Mutations in the GRN gene

The below-mentioned disorders are Trinucleotide Repeat Disorders, where there is excessive repetition of trinucleotides.

  • In Introns/Non-coding region:
    • Fragile X syndrome: CGG (Option A ruled out)
    • Friedreich ataxia: GAA
    • Myotonic dystrophy: CTG (Option C ruled out)
  • In Exons/ Coding region:

Huntington's disease: CAG (Mnemonic- Hunter in a Cage) (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) due to contraceptive failure can be done up to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 20 weeks

Explanation: For cases of contraceptive failure, MTP can be performed for up to 20 weeks with approval from a single doctor.

  • MTP up to 20 weeks requires the opinion of one RMP.
  • MTP between 20-24 weeks requires two RMPs' opinions.
  • MTP up to 24 weeks is allowed only for rape survivors. (Option B)
  • Contraceptive failure allows MTP only up to 20 weeks.
  • After 24 weeks, MTP is permitted only for substantial fetal abnormalities, with medical board approval.
  • MTP can be performed at any time if it is immediately necessary to save the life of the pregnant woman

32 weeks (Option C): This is well beyond the legal limit for routine MTPs. Only cases with significant fetal anomalies can be considered beyond 24 weeks.

12 weeks (Option D): This is too restrictive and does not align with current guidelines for MTP in cases of contraceptive failure.

questions.text:
What is the diagnosis for the patient with the given ABG analysis report:

pH 7.17

Na= 139.7mEq.L

pCO2 25.7mmHg

K= 5.1mEq.L,

pO2 97mm Hg

Blood glucose 334mg/dL

SatO2 99%

HCO3 at 17.4mEq.L,

BE of -8.6
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Metabolic acidosis

Explanation:

The laboratory values demonstrate a metabolic acidosis characterized by a low pH with compensatory respiratory changes.

  • The pH of 7.17 is significantly below the normal range (7.35-7.45), indicating acidemia.
  • The decreased HCO3 of 17.4 mEq/L (normal 22-26 mEq/L) suggests a primary metabolic acidosis.
  • The pCO2 of 25.7 mmHg is lower than the normal range (35-45 mmHg), representing appropriate respiratory compensation.
  • The negative base excess of -8.6 further confirms the metabolic acidosis.
  • Additionally, the elevated blood glucose of 334 mg/dL suggests possible diabetic ketoacidosis as the underlying cause.

 

Metabolic acidosis

Definition
  • Primary decrease in HCO3⁻ or increase in H⁺ ions
  • Characterized by ↓ pH and ↓ HCO3⁻
  • Compensatory mechanism: ↓ PaCO2 through hyperventilation (Kussmaul breathing)

Types

High anion gap (AG > 12 mEq/L)

Normal anion gap (AG 6-12 mEq/L)

Causes

(Mnemonic: MUDPILES)

  • M: Methanol
  • U: Uremia (Renal failure)
  • D: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
  • P: Paraldehyde, Phenformin, Propylene glycol
  • I: Iron tablets, Isoniazid
  • L: Lactic acidosis
  • E: Ethylene glycol
  • S: Salicylates (late phase)

 

(Mnemonic: HARD UP)

  • H: Hyperalimentation (TPN)
  • A: Acetazolamide
  • R: Renal Tubular Acidosis
  • D: Diarrhea
  • U: Ureteral diversion
  • P: Pancreatic fistula
  • GIT fistulas

Clinical Features

General Features:

  • Lethargy
  • Confusion
  • Fatigue
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Deep, rapid breathing (Kussmaul)

 

Specific Features:

  • DKA: Fruity breath, polyuria, polydipsia
  • Uremia: Itching, volume overload
  • Lactic acidosis: Shock, hypotension
  • Toxic ingestion: Visual disturbances (methanol), oxalate crystals (ethylene glycol)

 

Approach to diagnose Metabolic pH abnormalities

 

Respiratory Acidosis (Option A) is characterized by elevated pCO2 with normal or elevated HCO3 levels. In this case, the pCO2 is low at 25.7 mmHg, and HCO3 is decreased. Respiratory acidosis typically occurs in conditions like COPD or severe respiratory depression.

Respiratory Alkalosis (Option B) presents with low pCO2 and normal to low HCO3, but the pH would be elevated, not decreased as seen in this case. This condition is often seen in hyperventilation or high altitude exposure.

Metabolic Alkalosis (Option D) shows elevated pH and increased HCO3 levels, which is opposite to the findings in this case where both pH and HCO3 are decreased. Metabolic alkalosis commonly occurs with prolonged vomiting or diuretic use.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is the best for assessing long-term control of diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Glycosylated Hemoglobin

Explanation:

  • Glycosylated Hemoglobin (HbA1c) is the gold standard for monitoring long-term glycemic control in diabetic patients. This test provides a reliable measure of average blood glucose levels over the preceding 2-3 months, corresponding to the lifespan of red blood cells.
  • HbA1c testing is particularly valuable because it is not affected by daily fluctuations in blood glucose levels and does not require fasting. The test measures the percentage of hemoglobin molecules that have glucose attached to them, providing a more stable and accurate reflection of overall glycemic control.
  • It provides a more comprehensive view of glucose levels compared to other tests, with a diagnostic threshold of ≥ 48 mmol/mol (6.5%), making it ideal for early detection, particularly in patients with risk factors like obesity and family history.

HbA1c evaluation:

  • < 5.7% : Normal
  • 5.7% - 6.5% : Pre-diabetic
  • > 6.5% : Diabetic

Other Investigations for Diabetes Mellitus:

Blood Glucose Tests:

  • Fasting Plasma Glucose (FPG)
    • Measures glucose after an overnight fast.
    • Diagnostic threshold: ≥ 126 mg/dL (7.0 mmol/L).
    • Simple, cost-effective, and widely available.
  • Random Plasma Glucose (RPG)
    • Measures glucose at any time, irrespective of meals.
    • Diagnostic threshold: ≥ 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L).
    • Useful for immediate diagnosis in symptomatic patients.
  • Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT)
    • Fasting glucose was measured, followed by a 75 g glucose drink, then re-measured after 2 hours.
    • Diagnostic threshold: ≥ 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L).
    • More time-consuming; identifies impaired glucose tolerance.

 

Glycated Albumin (Option B) measurement reflects average blood glucose levels over only 2-3 weeks due to albumin's shorter half-life of approximately 20 days. While useful for short-term monitoring, it doesn't provide the comprehensive long-term assessment that HbA1c offers.

Serum Fructosamine (Option C) testing, similar to glycated albumin, provides information about glycemic control over the previous 2-3 weeks. This test measures glycated plasma proteins and is sometimes used when HbA1c results may be unreliable, such as in patients with hemoglobinopathies.

Urine Sugar (Option D) testing is not reliable for assessing long-term glucose control as it is influenced by multiple factors including renal threshold, hydration status, and concurrent medications. Urine glucose appears only when blood glucose exceeds the renal threshold, making it an inadequate measure of overall glycemic control.

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1 woman at 41 weeks gestation is in active labor. She has a history of gestational diabetes and her previous baby weighed 4.2 kg. During delivery, the fetal head delivers normally, but afterward, despite gentle traction, the shoulders fail to deliver. During delivery, the head is delivered, but the shoulders become stuck. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Shoulder Dystocia

Explanation:

  • Shoulder dystocia occurs when the fetal shoulders fail to deliver shortly after the head has emerged, despite gentle pulling. This condition is typically diagnosed if the shoulders do not deliver within 60 seconds after the head.

  • Normal Delivery Time: Under normal circumstances, the shoulders should deliver within 20-25 seconds after the fetal head.

  • Incidence: Occurs in approximately 1% of all deliveries and can lead to significant neonatal morbidity and mortality.

  • Risk Factors:

    • Large babies (macrosomia) > 4 kg

    • Post-term pregnancy

    • Diabetic mothers

    • Anencephaly (due to absence of pituitary function leading to delayed labor onset and larger babies)

Cephalopelvic Disproportion (CPD) (Option A) occurs when the baby's head or body is too large to fit through the mother's pelvis. It is typically diagnosed before or during labor due to the lack of progress in labor rather than after the head is delivered.

Occipito-posterior Position (Option B) While occipito-posterior positioning can lead to a longer and more difficult labor but is not characterized by the shoulders getting stuck after the head is delivered.

Breech presentation (Option D) occurs when the baby is positioned with the buttocks or feet first rather than the head. This is identified before delivery and managed differently. It does not involve the head being delivered first followed by stuck shoulders.

questions.text:
Patient presents with fever, headache, and vomiting that have persisted for the past 2 weeks. On examination, nuchal rigidity is noted. The results of a lumbar puncture (LP) are as follows:


	Opening Pressure: Elevated
	Cells: Predominantly polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs)
	Sugar: 35 mg/dl
	Protein: 200 mg/dl
	Color: Slightly cloudy appearance


Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bacterial Meningitis

Explanation:

  • The findings indicate bacterial meningitis based on the CSF analysis such as elevated opening pressure, predominant PMNs, low glucose (35 mg/dl), elevated protein (200 mg/dl), and cloudy appearance.

CSF Findings in various types of meningitis:

Type

Opening Pressure

Predominant Cell Type

Protein

Glucose

Gross Appearance

Bacterial Meningitis

Elevated

Polymorphonuclear Neutrophils (PMNs)

Elevated

Decreased

Turbid

Fungal/Tubercular Meningitis

Elevated

Lymphocytes

Elevated

Decreased

Straw-colored (TB meningitis)

Viral Meningitis

Normal or Slightly Elevated

Lymphocytes

Normal or Slightly Elevated

Normal

Normal or

Turbid

 

 

Meningoencephalitis (Option A) involves inflammation of both meninges and brain parenchyma. While symptoms may overlap, the CSF profile with PMN predominance is more characteristic of bacterial meningitis. Meningoencephalitis typically shows mixed cellular response.

Viral Meningitis (Option B) presents with a different CSF profile including lower white cell count (50-500 cells) with lymphocytic predominance rather than PMNs. Glucose levels are usually normal, unlike the low levels seen here. The protein elevation is typically mild.

TB Meningitis (Option C) typically shows lymphocytic predominance, very low glucose levels, and protein levels often exceeding 250 mg/dl. The course is more chronic, and CSF is usually clear or straw-colored. TB meningitis also characteristically shows a cobweb clot formation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician expressing her desire to become pregnant in the next few months. She is currently not taking any medications or supplements and wants to know what preventive measures she should take before conception. Which vitamin is given to prevent neural tube defects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Folic acid

Explanation:

Deficiency of Folic Acid can lead to Neural Tube Defects (NTD).

Key Points About Folic Acid

  • Requirement: 400 mcg/day
  • If on anti-epileptics: Replacement dose - 4000 mcg/day (4 mg/day)
  • Neural Tube Defect (NTD) screening at 11-14 weeks: Only defects seen at this time on ultrasound (USG) are anencephaly and acrania

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) (Option A): While important for carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function, thiamine does not prevent neural tube defects. Its deficiency is associated with different conditions like Wernicke's encephalopathy.

Vitamin B3 (Niacin) (Option B): Niacin is involved in DNA repair and metabolism but has no role in preventing neural tube defects. It serves different metabolic functions in the body.

Vitamin B12 (Option D): Although vitamin B12 is essential for neurological function and red blood cell formation, it does not directly prevent neural tube defects. It works synergistically with folate but is not the primary preventive agent for NTDs.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G1P0 woman has been pushing for 2 hours with minimal progression. The obstetrician is considering outlet forceps assistance. On examination, the fetal head is visible at the vaginal opening. Outlet forceps are applied at which station?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Head on perineum

Explanation: Head on Perineum typically corresponds to station +5, where the fetal head is visible at the vaginal opening and ready for delivery. Outlet forceps are appropriate at this stage.

Operative Vaginal Delivery Prerequisites and Classification According to Station and Rotation:

 

Procedure

Criteria

Outlet forceps
  • Scalp is visible at the introitus without separating the labia
  • Fetal skull has reached pelvic floor
  • Fetal head is at or on perineum
  • Head is OA or OP or
  • Head is right or left OA or OP position but rotation ≤45 degrees

Low forceps (2 types)
  • Fetal station is ≥+2 cm but not on the pelvic floor, and:
  • (a) Rotation ≤45 degrees is required or
  • (b) Rotation >45 degrees is required

Midforceps
  • Fetal station is between 0 and +2 cm

Prerequisites
  • Engaged head
  • Vertex presentation
  • Known fetal head position
  • CPD not suspected
  • Fetal weight estimated
  • Experienced operator
  • Ruptured membranes
  • Completely dilated cervix
  • Adequate anesthesia
  • Emptied maternal bladder
  • No fetal coagulopathy
  • No fetal demineralization disorder
  • Informed consent completed
  • Willingness to abandon OVD

CPD = cephalopelvic disproportion; OA = occiput anterior; OP = occiput posterior; OVD = operative vaginal delivery.

Head 1/5th palpable per abdomen (Option A): This indicates that the fetal head is still significantly above the pelvic outlet, making it unsafe for outlet forceps application. At this level, the head is too high for outlet forceps, which could result in maternal or fetal trauma.

0 station (Option B): At this level, the fetal head is at the ischial spines, which is too high for outlet forceps. This position would require mid-cavity rather than outlet forceps if operative delivery is needed.

Station +2 (Option C): While this indicates descent below the ischial spines, it is still not advanced enough for outlet forceps. Outlet forceps require the head to be visible at the introitus with perineal distention.

questions.text: A patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus experiences hypoglycemia and sustains a fall. Due to incoherent speech, a CT scan is performed and reveals a substantial subdural hematoma (SDH) with a volume greater than 30 cc. What should be the immediate next step in management?

choices.text: Stabilize the patient and urgently seek a neurosurgical consultation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Perform a Craniotomy

Explanation:

  • The scenario presents a case of acute subdural hematoma with significant volume (>30 cc) requiring immediate surgical intervention. In acute SDH, CT imaging shows hyperdense (white) appearance, and when the volume exceeds 30 cc, there is a substantial risk of brain compression and herniation.
  • Emergency Craniotomy represents the definitive treatment in this setting, allowing for immediate evacuation of the hematoma to prevent further neurological deterioration and potential fatal complications.

 

Acute SDH vs Chronic SDH:

Feature

Acute SDH

Chronic SDH

Timing

0-72 hours

>3 weeks

Clinical Features
  • Rapid deterioration
  • Loss of consciousness
  • Focal deficits
  • High mortality
  • Gradual onset
  • Confusion
  • Headache
  • Gait disturbance
  • Better prognosis

Risk Factors
  • Severe trauma
  • Young adults
  • Coagulopathy
  • Elderly
  • Brain atrophy
  • Anticoagulation
  • Minor trauma

CT Findings
  • Hyperdense crescent
  • Immediate mass effect
  • Hypodense/mixed density
  • Bilateral in 20-30%
  • Gradual mass effect

Management
  • Emergency craniotomy
  • Reverse coagulopathy
  • ICU care
  • Burr hole drainage
  • Hold anticoagulation
  • May observe small ones

 

Administer Mannitol (Option A) is used to manage elevated intracranial pressure, but it is not the definitive treatment for a large subdural hematoma. While mannitol can temporarily reduce intracranial pressure, it does not address the underlying compression from the hematoma, which requires surgical evacuation.

Administer Aspirin and Clopidogrel (Option B) would be contraindicated in acute SDH as these antiplatelet agents could worsen the bleeding. In fact, if the patient was previously on these medications, they would need to be discontinued and potentially reversed depending on the clinical situation.

Stabilize the patient and urgently seek a neurosurgical consultation (Option D) while important, delays the definitive treatment needed in this case. Given the large volume of the hematoma and altered mental status, immediate surgical intervention through craniotomy is required rather than waiting for further consultation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 34 weeks gestation presents for routine prenatal care. Her blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg, and routine laboratory studies reveal a platelet count of 120,000/µL. She is asymptomatic and has no history of bleeding disorders.What is the most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Gestational Thrombocytopenia

Explanation: The most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy is gestational thrombocytopenia, characterized by platelet counts less than 150,000/µL. It accounts for approximately 70-80% of all cases of thrombocytopenia during pregnancy.

Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (Option A): ITP is an autoimmune condition causing platelet destruction but accounts for a much smaller percentage of pregnancy-related thrombocytopenia cases. It typically presents earlier in pregnancy and may require specific treatment.

HELLP Syndrome (Option C): This severe variant of pre-eclampsia includes hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets. The patient's normal blood pressure and absence of other symptoms make this diagnosis unlikely.

Pre-eclampsia (Option D): This hypertensive disorder can cause thrombocytopenia but is not the most common cause. The patient's normal blood pressure and absence of proteinuria exclude this diagnosis.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is Rescue Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) indicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Failed thrombolysis

Explanation:

  • Rescue PCI is specifically indicated when thrombolytic therapy fails to restore coronary blood flow in acute myocardial infarction.
  • This intervention becomes necessary when initial thrombolytic treatment is unsuccessful in dissolving the occluding blood clot, as evidenced by persistent symptoms, ongoing ST-segment elevation, or hemodynamic instability. The procedure serves as a secondary intervention to mechanically reestablish coronary perfusion when pharmacological reperfusion has failed.

 

2013 ACCF/AHA Guideline for the management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction. Reperfusion therapy for patients with STEMI. (CABG indicates coronary artery bypass graft; DIDO, door-in–door-out; FMC, first medical contact; LOE, Level of Evidence; MI, myocardial infarction; PCI, percutaneous coronary intervention; and STEMI, ST-elevation myocardial infarction)

 

Chronic stable angina (Option B) is characterized by predictable chest pain occurring with exertion or stress. While PCI may be performed for relief in cases where medical management has failed, it is not classified as rescue PCI. The intervention in stable angina is planned and elective rather than emergent.

Prinzmetal's angina (Option C) is caused by coronary artery spasm and typically responds to medical management with calcium channel blockers and nitrates. PCI is not usually indicated unless there is a significant fixed obstruction. The primary treatment focuses on managing vasospasm rather than mechanical intervention.

NSTEMI (Option D) management follows a different protocol where initial medical therapy is the standard approach, with PCI timing based on risk stratification and response to treatment. While PCI may be indicated in NSTEMI, it is not considered rescue PCI as it is part of the planned treatment strategy rather than a rescue measure after failed therapy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male complains of lower back pain with a 1-1.5 mm osteolytic lesion at the T10 vertebra. Histopathological findings are given below. Which of the following options is correct regarding this condition?

choices.text: Decreased Calcium levels in the blood

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Presence of Bence-Jones proteinuria

Explanation:

  • The scenario describing lower back pain with a 1-1.5 mm osteolytic lesion at the T10 vertebra and a histopathological image showing intracytoplasmic inclusions (Russell bodies) suggests Multiple Myeloma, which is characterised by the presence of Bence-Jones proteinuria.
  • It is caused by increased antibody production.
  • It is a plasma cell neoplasm associated with (Mnemonic: CRAB features with immune abnormalities)
    • C - Hypercalcemia (Option D ruled out)
    • R - Renal failure
    • A - Anaemia
    • B - Lytic bone lesions, and
    • Immune abnormalities.
  • The cells produce excess free light chains, either alongside complete immunoglobulins or independently. (Option C ruled out)
  • Due to their small size, free light chains (Bence Jones proteins) can pass through the glomeruli of the kidneys and appear in the urine. This is a diagnostic marker for multiple myeloma.

Inclusion Bodies Seen In Multiple Myeloma

Russel bodies:
  • Location: Intracytoplasmic
  • Composition:
    • Eosinophilic
    • Round
    • Dilated endoplasmic reticulum cisternae filled with condensed immunoglobulin.

.

Dutcher bodies
  • Location: Intranuclear.
  • Composition: Globular inclusions containing accumulated immunoglobulin.

Plasma Cell Variants In Multiple Myeloma

Mott cells

  • Contain Grape-like cytoplasmic droplets.
  • Composition: Inclusion bodies, fibrils, crystalline rods, and globules.

Flame cells
  • Appearance: Fiery red cytoplasm.
  • Cause: High concentration of immunoglobulin as bright red granules within the cytoplasm.
  • Often seen in IgA subtype myeloma.

 

 

Rouleaux formation
  • High levels of M protein in the blood cause red cells to stick to one another in linear arrays in smears, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation. (Option B ruled out)
  • It is also seen in s lupus erythematosus and early HIV infection.

​​ ​​ ​​ ​​ ​​

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of fatigue, pallor, and weakness. Laboratory tests reveal a low hemoglobin (Hb) level, but the reticulocyte count is normal. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pure Red Cell Aplasia

Explanation:

  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia is characterized by a selective deficiency in red blood cell production while other blood cell lines remain normal. The key diagnostic features in this case are the combination of low hemoglobin with a normal reticulocyte count, indicating an inadequate bone marrow response specific to the erythroid lineage. This selective depression of red blood cell production, with preservation of white blood cells and platelets, is the hallmark of PRCA.

 

Pure Red Cell Aplasia

Definition

A condition characterized by anemia, reticulocytopenia, and absent or rare erythroid precursor cells in bone marrow with normal white cell and platelet production

Classification

Congenital:

  • Diamond-Blackfan anemia
  • Diagnosed at birth or early childhood

Acquired:

  • Thymoma
  • MDS (5s- syndrome)
  • Cancer
  • Autoimmune conditions
  • Viral infections (especially B19 parvovirus)

Clinical Associations
  • Thymoma (most frequent)
  • Lymphoid malignancies
  • Autoimmune disorders
  • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
