  • Pregnancy

Pathophysiology
  • T-cell mediated immune response
  • Antibodies to erythropoietin
  • Neutralizing antibodies to B19 parvovirus
  • Direct chemical toxicity or immune destruction

Treatment

General Approach:

  • Identify and treat underlying cause
  • Regular monitoring of hemoglobin levels
  • Supportive care with transfusions

Specific Treatments:

  • Immunosuppression (corticosteroids, cyclosporine, ATG, azathioprine)
  • Intravenous immunoglobulin for B19 parvovirus infection
  • Thymectomy if thymoma present
  • Iron chelation as needed

 

Aplastic Anemia (Option A) presents with pancytopenia, affecting all blood cell lines (red cells, white cells, and platelets) due to bone marrow failure. The normal reticulocyte count in this case does not support aplastic anemia, which would show decreased counts across all cell lines.

Iron Deficiency Anemia (Option C) typically shows microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells with an elevated reticulocyte count as the bone marrow attempts to compensate for the iron deficiency. The normal reticulocyte count in this scenario makes iron deficiency less likely.

Hemolytic Anemia (Option D) is characterized by increased destruction of red blood cells, leading to an elevated reticulocyte count as the bone marrow responds to the increased demand. The normal reticulocyte count in this case does not support ongoing hemolysis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with ptosis, diplopia, and generalized muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. She has difficulty chewing and swallowing, especially in the evening. A Tensilon test is positive. Which investigation is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) SFEMG

Explanation:

The clinical presentation strongly suggests Myasthenia Gravis (MG) based on the classic triad of symptoms: ptosis, diplopia, and fatigable muscle weakness. The hallmark pattern of weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest, along with diurnal variation (symptoms worsening in the evening), is pathognomonic for MG. The positive Tensilon test further supports this diagnosis.

In confirming this diagnosis, Single Fiber Electromyography (SFEMG) is the most sensitive test, with a sensitivity of up to 99%. In cases where there is clinical suspicion of MG, as evidenced by fatigable muscle weakness and positive Tensilon test, SFEMG is done as the confirmatory diagnostic tool. Although SFEMG is highly sensitive, the more commonly done confirmatory test is Repetitive Nerve Stimulation (RNS).

Diagnosing Myasthenia Gravis (MG)

Diagnosis involves a comprehensive approach integrating clinical evaluation and specific diagnostic tests.

Clinical Evaluation: Recognizing the Signs

  • History:
    • Focus on the onset, progression, diurnal variation and fluctuating muscle weakness.
  • Physical Examination:
    • Assess muscle strength.
    • Identify characteristic signs:
      • Ptosis
      • Diplopia
      • Cogan's lid twitch sign
    • Rule out other neurological conditions.

Diagnostic Tests: Confirming the Suspicion

Test

Description

Tensilon Test
  • Administers edrophonium bromide intravenously.
  • May show transient muscle function improvement; not highly reliable.

Repetitive Nerve Stimulation (RNS)
  • Specialized nerve conduction study.
  • Reveals a decremental response in muscle strength with repeated stimulation, indicating impaired neuromuscular transmission.

Single Fiber Electromyography (SFEMG)
  • SFEMG techniques allow assessment of two important features of the motor unit: jitter and fiber density (FD).
  • SFEMG is the most sensitive clinical test for neuromuscular junction disease and is often abnormal in clinically unaffected muscles in patients with myasthenia gravis (MG) and Lambert-Eaton myasthenia (LEM).

Antibody Testing
  • Detects auto-antibodies related to MG.
  • Acetylcholine Receptor (AChR) Antibodies: Most common, block AChR function.
  • Muscle-Specific Kinase (MuSK) Antibodies: Disrupt AChR clustering and stabilization.

Thoracic CT Scan

Essential to rule out thymoma, especially in patients with negative AChR antibody tests.

 

CT scan of the chest (Option A) is used for evaluating thymus gland abnormalities such as thymoma, which occurs in approximately 10-15% of MG patients. While important in the overall evaluation, it is not the primary diagnostic test for confirming MG diagnosis.

Anti-acetylcholine receptor antibody test (Option C) is highly specific for MG and is positive in about 85% of generalized MG cases. However, SFEMG is more sensitive, particularly in seronegative cases where antibody tests may be negative despite clinical disease.

MRI of the brain (Option D) may be useful in ruling out other neurological conditions that can present with similar symptoms, such as multiple sclerosis or brainstem lesions. However, it does not provide specific diagnostic information for MG and is primarily used to exclude other conditions.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G1P0 woman presents for routine prenatal ultrasound at 18 weeks gestation. The ultrasonographer notes scalloping of the frontal bones creating a lemon-like appearance of the fetal skull. Which of the following conditions is associated with both the "lemon sign" and "banana sign" on a prenatal ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A) Neural Tube Defects (NTD) - Spina Bifida

Explanation:

  • The "lemon sign" and "banana sign" is a specific ultrasound finding indicative of spina bifida, a type of neural tube defect
  • Lemon sign refers to scalloping of the frontal bones, which creates a lemon-like appearance of the fetal skull
  • This finding, along with other features like the "banana sign" which indicates a curved cerebellum, suggests spina bifida

 

 

Anencephaly (Option B): This condition presents with the characteristic "frog eyes" sign on ultrasound due to absent cerebral tissue above the orbits. Neither lemon nor banana signs are associated with this condition. Anencephaly is a more severe form of neural tube defect that is typically diagnosed earlier in pregnancy.

Down Syndrome (Option C): This chromosomal condition is associated with different ultrasound markers including increased nuchal fold thickness, absent nasal bone, and shortened femur length. The lemon and banana signs are not characteristic features of Down syndrome. Diagnosis typically requires genetic testing such as amniocentesis or cell-free DNA testing.

Brachycephaly (Option D): This cranial shape abnormality presents with a shortened anteroposterior diameter of the skull and increased biparietal diameter, creating a rounded appearance. It does not produce the lemon or banana signs. Brachycephaly may be isolated or associated with various syndromes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of tuberculosis now complains of abdominal distension and pedal edema. On examination, his neck veins are prominent. His chest x-ray is given below. Which of the following findings will be likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) SBP falls from 80mmHg to 60mmHg

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation including distended neck veins (elevated JVP), abdominal distension, and pedal edema and chest X-ray findings of increased cardiothoracic ratio are consistent with cardiac tamponade. Also, given the history of tuberculosis, this is likely tuberculous pericarditis leading to tamponade.
  • In cardiac tamponade, there is typically a significant drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration (pulsus paradoxus), which in this case is represented by the fall in SBP from 80mmHg to 60mmHg (>10mmHg drop).

 

Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

A condition where the cardiac chambers are compressed by a tense pericardial effusion, limiting cardiac inflow. Fluid accumulation of as little as 200 ml to upwards of 2L may lead to cardiac tamponade development.

Clinical Features

Beck's triad

  • Jugular Venous Distension: Due to increased central venous pressure. Prominent x descent and an absent y descent.
  • Hypotension: Resulting from impaired cardiac output.
  • Muffled Heart Sounds: Caused by fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, dampening heart sounds.

Other features

Pulsus Paradoxus: Hallmark finding. A drop in systolic BP during inspiration, greater than 10 mm Hg.

Causes of Pulsus paradoxus:

  • Lung Conditions: Acute asthma, COPD, tension pneumothorax, pleural effusion, pulmonary embolism.
  • Heart Conditions: Cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis.

 

Pulsus biferiens (Option A) is a double-peaked pulse typically seen in aortic regurgitation and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. This finding is not characteristic of cardiac tamponade.

Kussmaul breathing (Option B) refers to deep and labored breathing seen in metabolic acidosis, particularly diabetic ketoacidosis. It is not a characteristic finding in cardiac tamponade.

Fine crepitations (Option D) are typically heard in pulmonary edema or pneumonia. In cardiac tamponade, the heart sounds are usually muffled, but crepitations are not a characteristic finding.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is tandem radiotherapy commonly used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cervical cancer

Explanation:

Tandem radiotherapy is predominantly used in the management of cervical cancer to deliver targeted internal radiation via brachytherapy.

Ovarian Cancer (Option B): Tandem radiotherapy is not commonly used. Treatment typically involves surgery and chemotherapy, with radiation being less common.

Choriocarcinoma (Option C): Tandem radiotherapy is not a standard treatment. Management often includes chemotherapy as the primary mode of treatment.

Endometrial Cancer (Option D): While radiation is used, tandem radiotherapy is not the standard approach. Treatment often involves surgery, and when radiation is used, it's typically EBRT or vaginal brachytherapy without tandems.

Management of Ca cervix

Stage

Criteria

Management

Ia1

<3 mm NO LVSI

Conization or extra fascial hysterectomy

Ia1

<3 mm with LVSI

• Radical trachelectomy

• Or radical hysterectomy + pelvic LAD

• Or SLN

IA2

≥3 mm <5 mm

• Radical trachelectomy

• Or radical hysterectomy + pelvic LAD

• Or SLN

IB1

≥5 mm <2 cm

• Radical trachelectomy

• Or radical hysterectomy + pelvic LAD

• Or SLN

IB2

≥2 cm <4 cm

Radical Hysterectomy + Pelvic LAD

IB3

≥4 cm

Chemoradiation

IIA1

<4 cm + upper vagina

Radical Hysterectomy + Pelvic LAD or Chemoradiation

IIA2

≥4 cm + upper vagina

Chemoradiation

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida has just delivered a healthy baby vaginally at 39 weeks gestation. The newborn has good muscle tone, is breathing spontaneously, and has normal skin color. The delivery team is preparing for umbilical cord clamping and discussing the optimal timing. What is the ideal time for umbilical cord clamping after birth?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C) Between 1-3 minutes after birth

Explanation:

Clamping the umbilical cord between 1-3 minutes after birth is considered the ideal time because:

  • It allows for significant transfer of blood from the placenta to the baby
  • Improves iron levels in the newborn
  • Supports better developmental outcomes
  • Enhances newborn health through improved blood volume
  • Reduces the risk of iron deficiency
  • Lower incidence of:
    • Necrotizing enterocolitis
    • Intraventricular hemorrhage

Immediately after birth (Option A) can prevent the baby from receiving additional blood from the placenta, potentially depriving the newborn of important nutrients and stem cells beneficial for early development.

Within 30 seconds of birth (Option B): While slightly better than immediate clamping, this timeframe still does not allow enough time for optimal blood transfer from the placenta, resulting in reduced iron stores.

More than 3 minutes after birth (Option D): While still beneficial, waiting longer than 3 minutes is generally unnecessary as most beneficial blood transfer occurs within the first 1-3 minutes, with no additional significant advantages.

questions.text: Which of the following is a derived / calculated value in Arterial Blood Gas analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bicarbonate

Explanation:

Bicarbonate concentration is a calculated value in arterial blood gas analysis, derived using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation based on measured PCO₂ and pH values.

The equation demonstrates how bicarbonate is formed when carbon dioxide dissolves in water to form carbonic acid, which then dissociates into hydrogen ions and bicarbonate:

PCO₂ + H₂O ⇌ H₂CO₃ ⇌ H⁺ + HCO₃⁻

Understanding bicarbonate levels is crucial for assessing acid-base disorders:

  • Elevated HCO₃⁻ occurs in metabolic alkalosis or as compensation in respiratory acidosis
  • Decreased HCO₃⁻ occurs in metabolic acidosis or as compensation in respiratory alkalosis

ABG components include the following:

  • pH = measured acid-base balance of the blood
  • PaO2 = measured the partial pressure of oxygen in arterial blood
  • PaCO2 = measured the partial pressure of carbon dioxide in arterial blood
  • HCO3 = calculated concentration of bicarbonate in arterial blood
  • Base excess/deficit = calculated relative excess or deficit of base in arterial blood
  • SaO2 = calculated arterial oxygen saturation (unless a co-oximetry is obtained, in which case it is measured)

 

pH (Option A) is directly measured in blood gas analysis using ion-selective electrodes that determine hydrogen ion concentration. It is not a calculated value but rather a primary measurement.

PO₂ (Option B) is directly measured using electrodes that detect oxygen partial pressure in the blood sample.

PCO₂ (Option C) is also directly measured, typically using a PCO₂ electrode that measures carbon dioxide partial pressure. Like pH and PO₂, it is a measured rather than calculated value.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause polyhydramnios?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Renal agenesis

Explanation:

Renal agenesis typically leads to oligohydramnios (low amniotic fluid), not polyhydramnios.

Amniotic Fluid Index:

Condition

AFI Range

Description

Normal

5-24 cm

Associated with normal fetal well-being.

Oligohydramnios

< 5 cm

Indicates lower-than-normal amniotic fluid volume and may lead to fetal growth restriction.

Polyhydramnios

> 24 cm

Indicates excessive amniotic fluid accumulation, increasing the risk of preterm labour, placental abruption, and umbilical cord complications.

 

Causes of Oligohydramnios and Polyhydramnios:

Causes

Polyhydramnios

Oligohydramnios

Fetal Factors
  • Fetal anomalies (e.g., anencephaly, esophageal atresia)
  • Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) (Option B)
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Esophageal atresia (Option C)
  • Neural tube defects (Option A)
  • Renal agenesis
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Fetal growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Amnion nodosum

Maternal Factors
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Cardiac disease
  • Renal disease
  • Maternal hypertension
  • Preeclampsia
  • Placental insufficiency

Placental Factors

Chorioangioma

Placental abruption

questions.text: Identify the edges of the lesion given in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rolled out

Explanation:

  • The given image shows rolled-out edges suggesting Basal cell carcinoma.

Morphologically, an ulcer has 4 parts:

  • Base: Surface on which ulcer rests (usually underlying muscles/bones)
  • Floor: Exposed surface of ulcer (usually seen as purulent discharge/granulation tissue/red and moist)
  • Margin: Junction between normal epithelium & ulcer
  • Edge: Area between margin & floor

Type of edges

Clinical conditions

Details

Sloping edge
  • Healing ulcer
  • Varicose ulcer
  • Inner part: Red (healthy granulation tissue)
  • Middle part: Blue (epithelial proliferation)
  • Outer part: White (scar/fibrous tissue)

Undermined edge
  • Tubercular ulcers

Disease process advances in the deeper plane (subcutaneous tissue), whereas (skin) epidermis proliferates inwards

Punched out edge
  • Arterial / Ischemic ulcers
  • Gummatous (syphilitic) ulcer
  • Trophic ulcer

Due to endarteritis

Raised & beaded edge

Rolled out /

Pearly white edge
  • Rodent ulcer- Basal cell carcinoma

Beads are due to proliferating active cells

 

Pearly white in appearance

Everted edge /

Rolled out edge
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

Due to the spill of proliferating malignant tissue over the normal skin

questions.text: Which of the following intestinal pathologies is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Celiac disease

 

Explanation:

Celiac Disease (also referred to as Gluten-sensitive Enteropathy or Celiac Sprue) is associated with Dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Celiac Disease

Definition

Autoimmune disorder triggered by ingesting gluten-containing foods in genetically susceptible individuals.

It is influenced by HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8.

Pathogenesis

Clinical features

Adults:

  • Commonly between the ages of 30 and 60.
  • More frequent in females
  • Silent celiac disease (positive serology and villous atrophy without symptoms)
  • Latent celiac disease (positive serology is not accompanied by villous atrophy)
  • It may be associated with chronic diarrhoea, bloating, chronic fatigue, or asymptomatic.
  • Anaemia (iron and vitamin malabsorption).
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis (itchy, blistering skin lesion) might be present. (Option C)

 

Pediatric cases:

  • Both sexes were affected equally.
  • It may present with malabsorption.
  • Begins after the introduction of gluten to the diet (6-24 months of age)
  • Manifestations include irritability, abdominal distention, anorexia, chronic diarrhoea, failure to thrive, weight loss, or muscle wasting.
  • It may also present as abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bloating, or constipation.
  • Extraintestinal complaints include arthritis or joint pain, aphthous stomatitis, iron deficiency anaemia, delayed puberty, and short stature.

Serum markers
  • IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminase (tTG): Most sensitive.
  • Anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA): Most specific.
  • IgG antibodies against gliadin (a component of gluten).

Histology

Biopsy of the second part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum:

  • Increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis).
  • Crypt hyperplasia (Increased mitosis).
  • Villous atrophy (Reduced mucosal surface area, causing malabsorption).
  • Inflammatory cell infiltration.

Ulcerative colitis (Option A) is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that affects the colon and rectum. It causes ulceration and inflammation of the inner lining of the colon, leading to symptoms like bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, cramping, and weight loss. The condition is characterised by periods of flare-ups and remissions and is believed to have an autoimmune origin.

Whipple’s disease (Option B) is a rare bacterial infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei. It primarily affects the small intestine, causing malabsorption, diarrhoea, and weight loss, and can also involve the joints, heart, nervous system, and lungs. It is characterised by PAS-positive macrophages in tissue samples.


Crohn’s disease (Option D) is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the GI tract, causing symptoms like abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and weight loss. It involves transmural inflammation and skip lesions. The exact cause is unknown, but it’s linked to an autoimmune response.

questions.text: Which among the following is associated with Cryoglobulinemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hepatitis C infection

Explanation:

Hepatitis C infection is associated with Cryoglobulinemia.

Cryoglobulinemia:

  • Cryoglobulins are proteins that precipitate from serum or plasma at low temperatures (<37°C).
  • They can be a mixture of immunoglobulin and complement components or immunoglobulins alone.
  • They deposit in medium and large-sized blood vessels throughout the body, causing endothelial injury and end-organ damage known as cryoglobulinemia.
  • It is often associated with
    • Hepatitis C virus infection
    • Hepatitis B virus infection
    • HIV
    • Autoimmune diseases ( mainly SLE and Sjogren’s syndrome)
    • Lymphoproliferative disorders.

Ovarian cancer (Option B) is a type of cancer that begins in the ovaries (female reproductive organs). It often goes undiagnosed in the early stages due to vague symptoms like abdominal bloating, pelvic pain, and early satiety. Risk factors include age, family history, and genetic mutations (such as BRCA1 and BRCA2).

Diabetes (Option C) is a chronic condition where the body can't properly regulate blood sugar. Type 1 is insulin deficiency due to an autoimmune response, while Type 2 is caused by insulin resistance, often linked to obesity. Symptoms include thirst, frequent urination, and fatigue. Treatment involves lifestyle changes and medication, with long-term risks to organs like the heart and kidneys.


Leukaemia (Option D) is a type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow, leading to the abnormal production of white blood cells. It is classified into acute and chronic forms, with acute leukaemia progressing rapidly and chronic leukaemia developing more slowly. Symptoms include fatigue, fever, frequent infections, easy bruising, and weight loss.

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident (RTA) with a crush injury presents with crepitus and a reddish-brown wound within 3 days after amputation. What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gas gangrene

Explanation:

  • Gas gangrene is caused by Clostridium species, typically after traumatic injuries, especially with crush wounds or amputation. It is characterized by crepitus (gas production), reddish-brown discoloration of the wound, and rapid progression within days.

Gas Gangrene

A rapidly progressive, potentially fatal condition characterized by widespread necrosis of muscles and soft-tissue destruction, often due to late-presenting missile wounds or crushing injuries.

Cause

Clostridium perfringens

Incubation period

<24 hours but ranges from 1 hour to 6 weeks

Sources and predisposing factors
  • Contaminated soil and feces.
  • Wounds with necrotic or foreign material.
  • Crush wounds, road traffic accidents, amputations.
  • Anaerobic environments in the wound.

Common sites of infection
  • Adductor region of the lower limb and buttocks.
  • Subscapular region in the upper limb.

Clinical features
  • Severe pain with limb swelling rapidly increases in severity.
  • Serosanguineous discharge.
  • Skin turns brown to blue-black with hemorrhagic bullae.
  • Sweet, sticky odor & Soft-tissue crepitus.

Complication

  • Septicaemia, toxemia, renal failure, liver failure.
  • Circulatory failure, DIC, secondary infections.
  • Death occurs in critically ill patients.

Investigation

  • X-ray: Gas in soft tissues.
  • Gram stain & blood culture: Large Gram-positive bacilli without neutrophils.
  • Biochemical profile: Metabolic acidosis, renal failure.
  • Peripheral blood smear: Haemolysis.
  • CT scan for chest or abdominal wounds.

Treatment

  • High-dose intravenous penicillin and clindamycin, along with 3rd generation cephalosporins, are given intravenously.
  • Polyvalent antiserums given intravenously.
  • All dead tissues are excised, and debridement is performed until healthy tissue bleeds.
  • Amputation done in severe cases
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy.

Prevention

  • Proper debridement of devitalized crushed wounds.
  • Devitalized wounds should not be sutured.
  • Adequate cleaning of wounds with H₂O₂ and normal saline.
  • Penicillin - As a prophylactic antibiotic.

Image

Incorrect Options:

Impetigo (Option B) is a superficial skin infection caused by Streptococcus or Staphylococcus bacteria, presenting as honey-colored crusts, but does not typically cause crepitus or involve deep tissue.

Tetanus (Option C) results from infection with Clostridium tetani, leading to muscle stiffness and spasms. While it follows a traumatic injury, it doesn’t typically present with crepitus or reddish-brown wound discoloration.

Cellulitis (Option D) is a bacterial skin infection that causes redness, swelling, and warmth, but it does not produce crepitus or reddish-brown wounds and typically develops over a longer period.

questions.text: Which of the following cells are located in the centre of the lumen in a venule?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) RBCs

Explanation:

  • Red blood cells (RBCs) are located in the centre of the lumen in a venule.
  • In venules with normal blood flow, red blood cells remain in the central axial column, while leukocytes are displaced toward the vessel wall.
  • They are responsible for transporting oxygen from the lungs to the tissues and returning carbon dioxide from the tissues to the lungs.

Lymphocytes (Option A) are white blood cells essential for immunity, comprising B cells (antibody production), T cells (immune regulation), and Natural Killer cells (targeting infected or cancerous cells). They originate in the bone marrow, circulate in the blood and lymph, and typically adhere to the endothelium of blood vessels rather than residing within the venous lumen.

Neutrophils (Option C) are white blood cells essential for bacterial defence. Produced in the bone marrow, they rapidly migrate to infection sites and eliminate pathogens via phagocytosis. During inflammation, like lymphocytes, they tend to localize near vessel walls rather than the lumen.


Platelets (Option D) are small cell fragments produced in the bone marrow that play a key role in blood clotting. They aggregate at injury sites to form clots and stop bleeding, typically found near vessel walls rather than in the centre of the lumen.

questions.text: Arrange the stages of wound healing in the correct sequence:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, remodeling

Explanation:

Wound healing occurs in four stages: hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, and remodeling.

  • Hemostasis:
    • Occurs immediately after injury: vasoconstriction, platelet aggregation, and clot formation.
    • Platelets release growth factors (e.g., TGF-β, PDGF, VEGF) that promote matrix deposition, chemotaxis, and angiogenesis.
    • Coagulation cascade leads to thrombin formation, stabilizing the platelet plug.
  • Inflammation:
    • Early Phase (Days 1-2): Neutrophils clear debris and fight infection. Vasoactive amines increase vascular permeability.
    • Late Phase (Days 2-3): Macrophages debride the wound, release growth factors, and promote fibroblast and angiogenesis.
    • Cardinal signs: rubor (redness), tumor (swelling), calor (heat), dolor (pain).
  • Proliferation:
    • Days 3-14: Fibroblasts produce collagen and extracellular matrix. Granulation tissue forms, and angiogenesis occurs.
    • Myofibroblasts help contract the wound and bring edges together.
  • Remodelling:
    • Weeks to months: Type III collagen is replaced by stronger type I collagen.
    • The wound reaches about 80% of normal skin strength by 12 weeks and continues to mature for up to a year.

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Jejunal atresia

Explanation:

  • Jejunal atresia is characterized by a triple bubble sign, as shown in the X-ray. It also shows an apple peel appearance.

 

Various Bubble signs of the abdomen:

Condition

Radiological Sign

Explanation

Normal Abdomen

Single bubble in the stomach

A single air bubble seen in the left upper quadrant corresponds to the fundus of the stomach. A large single bubble is seen in cases of pyloric atresia, GOO.

Pyloric Atresia (Option A)

A single distended stomach with no air in the small bowel or beyond, caused by obstruction at the pylorus.

(Option A)

Distended stomach and proximal duodenum; no distal bowel gas due to obstruction at the duodenum.

questions.text: How do you calculate the mid-parental height for a male child with a father who is 183 cm tall and a mother who is 175 cm tall?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 185.5

Explanation:

Mid-parental height for a male or female child is calculated using a specific formula: ​​​

  

Where:

  • FH = Father's height
  • MH = Mother's height
  • 13 = Correction factor for male children

Calculation for above clinical scenario:

  • Father's height = 183 cm
  • Mother's height = 175 cm
  • Using the formula: (183 + 175 + 13) ÷ 2 = 185.5 cm

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a “sure sign” of abdominal wound dehiscence in a post-operative hypotensive patient?

choices.text: Widening of the abdominal scar with palpable edges

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Serosanguinous drainage from the wound

Explanation:

Serosanguinous drainage from the wound is considered a "sure sign" of abdominal wound dehiscence in a post-operative hypotensive patient (Salmon fluid sign)

Wound dehiscence is the disruption of any or all layers of a wound. It occurs in up to 3% of abdominal wounds and is associated with an increased risk of postoperative mortality.

  • Timing and Presentation:
    • Wound dehiscence typically occurs 5 to 8 days postoperatively when the strength of the wound is at its weakest.
    • It often presents with serosanguinous discharge and may be preceded by a popping sensation felt by the patient, particularly during activities like straining or coughing.
    • The dehiscence may also indicate an underlying abscess.
  • Risk factors:
    • Poor wound closure or closure under tension
    • Infection, hematoma, or seroma at the wound site
    • Increased intra-abdominal pressure, e.g., in postoperative patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or excessive coughing
    • Malnourishment
    • Diabetes
    • Obesity
    • Renal failure
    • Jaundice
    • Sepsis
    • Cancer
    • Steroid use
    • Emergency surgery
  • Management:
    • Full-thickness dehiscence generally requires the patient to return to the operating room for resuturing.
    • In cases of infected tissues, poor-quality tissue, or wounds under excessive tension, the wound may be left open and managed with dressings or vacuum-assisted closure (VAC).

questions.text: An elderly chronic smoker male is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lower lip with no lymph node involvement. What is the treatment of choice?

choices.text: Wide local excision with negative borders
Wide local excision with frozen section

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Wide local excision with negative borders

Explanation:

Wide local excision with frozen section is the treatment of choice for early-stage squamous cell carcinoma of the lower lip in patients with no lymph node involvement. This technique ensures that the excision margins are clear in real-time, reducing the risk of recurrence.

Cutaneous Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC): SCC is a malignant tumor of keratinising cells in the epidermis, commonly arising from the stratum basalis. It is the second most common skin cancer, more prevalent in fair-skinned individuals with chronic sun exposure.

  • Risk factors:
    • UV radiation, chronic inflammation, immunosuppression, chemical carcinogens (e.g., arsenic), and HPV infection (types 5 and 16).
    • Tobacco use doubles the risk.
  • Precursor lesions:
    • Actinic Keratosis (AK): Dysplastic lesions from sun damage; 20% progress to SCC.
    • Keratin Horns: Raised keratinous surface from AK, 10% may have underlying SCC.
    • Keratoacanthomas: Rapidly growing, nodular tumors that resemble SCC and should be excised.
  • Clinical features:
    • SCC presents as nodular, verrucous, or ulcerating lesions with an everted edge and surrounding induration.
  • Differential diagnosis: AK, BCC, pyoderma gangrenosum, and warts.
  • Microscopic features: Irregular squamous epithelium invading the dermis, positive for cytokeratins 1 and 10. Broders' grading assesses tumor differentiation.
  • Management: The primary treatment for SCC is surgical excision, which provides accurate histological diagnosis and clear margins. The size of the SCC influences the required margin:
    • <2 cm SCC: 4 mm margin
    • >2 cm SCC: 1 cm margin
  • The recurrence rate is approximately 20%.
  • Surgical excision is the only reliable method for ensuring clear margins. Mohs’ micrographic surgery may be indicated for difficult-to-resect tumours or those with recurrent SCC.

questions.text: Identify the radiological image of the condition given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Paget's disease

Explanation:

  • The above-given skull X-ray shows a cotton wool appearance, which is suggestive of Paget's disease.

 

Paget's Disease of Bone:

Paget’s disease (osteitis deformans):

  • A non-neoplastic condition that is characterised by abnormal bone remodelling.
  • Clinical features:
    • Seen in elderly patients
    • Presents with bone pain, sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) (cranial nerve compression)
    • Cardiac failure (hyperdynamic circulation)
    • Raised alkaline phosphatase (ALP), but calcium and phosphorous levels are normal
  • Radiological features:

Osteoporosis circumscripta: A circumscribed patch of osteoporosis in the skull.

The cotton wool appearance of the skull (due to sclerosis)

Tam O'Shanter sign: The skull's expansion and flattened base create the appearance of the skull tilting over the facial structures (due to the thickening of the frontal bone).

 

Blade of grass appearance or candle flame sign: Flame-shaped lesion extending along the shaft of the bone.

Picture frame vertebra:

The vertebrae appear enlarged and have a thickened cortical bone due to excessive bone remodeling and disorganized osteoblastic activity.

 

Ivory vertebra:

The homogeneous, radiopaque appearance results from increased bone density caused by abnormal osteoblastic activity, leading to excessive bone formation.

 

Lincoln sign or Black Beard sign: Increased radiotracer uptake in the mandible gives it a distinctive black beard appearance that signifies abnormal bone metabolism in Paget’s disease.

Banana fractures: Occur in a region of abnormal bone.

 

Multiple Myeloma (Option B): Punched-out lytic lesions of the skull or Raindrop lesions are seen in Multiple myeloma.

Hyperparathyroidism (Option C): Salt and pepper appearance is seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Sickle cell anemia (Option D): Sickle cell anemia is characterized by hair-on-end appearance of skull on X-ray.

questions.text: Which chromosomal defect is suggested by the karyotyping results given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Trisomy 18

Explanation:

The karyotype analysis reveals Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) based on the following findings:

  • Total chromosome count: 47
  • Sex chromosomes: XY (male)
  • Extra chromosome: +18 (three copies of chromosome 18)

The presence of three copies of chromosome 18 confirms Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome).

Incorrect Options:

Trisomy 13 (Option B): Incorrect, as Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13) would show 47, XY, +13, not +18.

Trisomy 21 (Option C): Incorrect, as Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) is characterized by 47, XY, +21, not +18.

Trisomy 11 (Option D): Not a recognized viable trisomy in humans.

questions.text: In modified radical neck dissection, which of the following structures is NOT preserved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Submandibular gland

Explanation:

  • In a modified radical neck dissection, the sternocleidomastoid muscle, internal jugular vein, and spinal accessory nerve are typically preserved.

Types of Neck Dissections:

questions.text: During the procedure shown below which one of the following substances is uptaken by the cancer cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glucose

Explanation:

  • FDG-PET scans use a radiolabeled form of glucose, known as Fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG), to assess glucose metabolism.

 

Fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) positron-emission tomography (PET-FDG)

  • Uptake of 18F-FDG (Analogue of endogenous glucose) in large quantities by cancer cells as compared to normal cells

 

Application:

  • Quantification of tumor metabolic activity
  • Diagnosis (lung cancer) and Staging of cancer
  • Assessing distant metastasis
    • More sensitive in primary lung and oesophageal cancer metastatic disease
  • Assessment of response to treatment
    • A decrease in FDG uptake after chemotherapy indicates that the tumor is responding to treatment
  • Routine surveillance following treatment- not commonly preferred.

 

Not useful in the following situations:

  • High Glycolytic Metabolism tissues: Central nervous system tumors.
  • Inflammation vs. Cancer: Both conditions exhibit increased glucose metabolism.
  • Movement disorders
  • Coronary blood flow

 

Warburg Effect

  • Cancer cells prefer glycolysis over oxidative phosphorylation, even in the presence of oxygen.
  • This leads to increased glucose uptake and lactate production, common in many cancers.
  • 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (18F-FDG), a glucose analog used in PET imaging, helps study this effect.

 

Mechanisms of 18F-FDG Accumulation

Mechanism

Description

Aerobic Glycolysis

Cancer cells rely heavily on glycolysis, increasing glucose and 18F-FDG uptake, even with oxygen.

Transport & Trapping

GLUT-1 transporters mediate glucose entry. 18F-FDG is phosphorylated and trapped inside cells.

Tumor Heterogeneity

Differences in tumor subtype, size, and microvasculature affect 18F-FDG uptake.

 

Clinical Implications of 18F-FDG

Implication

Details

Prognostic Indicator

Higher 18F-FDG uptake correlates with worse prognosis (e.g., shorter DFS in invasive ductal carcinoma).

Reverse Warburg Effect

Cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) increase glycolysis in tumor cells via metabolic coupling.

Treatment Monitoring

PET imaging tracks changes in 18F-FDG uptake, reflecting therapy responses targeting glycolysis or mitochondria.

questions.text: Which ganglia is located in the marked area?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pterygopalatine ganglia

Explanation:

  • Pterygopalatine ganglia is present at the location marked in the given image.
  • The pterygopalatine ganglion is located in the pterygopalatine fossa, which is found behind the maxilla and near the sphenoid bone.

Various parasympathetic ganglia:

 

Otic ganglion (Option A): Located near the foramen ovale and associated with the mandibular nerve (V3), supplying the parotid gland.

Ciliary ganglion (Option B): Located in the orbit, associated with the oculomotor nerve (CN III), and controls pupil constriction & lens accommodation.

Submandibular ganglion (Option D): Located near the submandibular gland, associated with the facial nerve (CN VII) and controls salivation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a known history of beta-thalassemia undergoes a blood transfusion. During the transfusion, she develops symptoms of anxiety, hypotension, and fever. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Stop the blood transfusion and restart after stabilization
Continue the blood transfusion and perform an ECG
Investigate for clerical errors in the blood transfusion process
Administer corticosteroids and monitor vital signs

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Stop the blood transfusion and restart after stabilization

Explanation:

In a woman with beta-thalassemia experiencing anxiety, hypotension, and fever during transfusion, the immediate step is to stop the transfusion and ensure stabilization.

Transfusion Reactions:

It refers to an adverse response to blood components, which can be

  • Immunologically mediated (via WBC)
  • Related to infections.
  • It can either be immediate or delayed.

 

Aspect

Immediate Transfusion Reactions

Delayed Transfusion Reactions

Onset Time

Within hours of transfusion

Days to weeks after transfusion

Cause

Immunologic reactions, hemolytic or non-hemolytic

Immune-mediated, often involving minor antigen sensitization

Presentation

Fever, chills, Dyspnea (TRALI, TACO), Acute respiratory distress (TRALI), Pulmonary oedema (TACO), hypothermia, electrolyte abnormalities, coagulopathy, acid-base disorders and hyperkalemia

Fever, jaundice, Gradual decline in haemoglobin levels (hemolysis)

Severity

Can range from mild to life-threatening

Generally less severe than immediate reactions

Examples
  • Febrile non-hemolytic reaction (FNHTR)
  • Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)
  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)

Delayed hemolytic reaction

Management

  • Stop the blood transfusion.
  • Supportive care.
  • Three samples are to be collected
    • Blood
      • 1st sample: For BG/CM (blood grouping - cross matching) (EDTA vial)
      • 2nd sample: Biochemical test for hemolysis (plain red vial)
    • Urine
      • Test for hemoglobinuria (hemolysis).

Continue the blood transfusion and perform an ECG (Option B): Continuing the transfusion could worsen the reaction. The first step in managing a suspected transfusion reaction is stopping the transfusion.

Investigate for clerical errors in the blood transfusion process (Option C): While clerical errors (e.g., blood type mismatch) are important to rule out, the immediate priority is to stop the transfusion and stabilize the patient before investigating further.


Administer corticosteroids and monitor vital signs (Option D): Corticosteroids may be used in certain reactions (such as allergic reactions), but the first step should be stopping the transfusion and addressing any immediate complications (e.g., hypotension, fever). Corticosteroids are not the first-line treatment for most transfusion reactions.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with pain, redness, and swelling around his great toe. His serum uric acid level is 9.4 mg/dL. His mother also mentions that he frequently bites his lips and has symptoms of spasticity and dystonia. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations, such as combination of hyperuricemia (leading to gout-like symptoms), neurological manifestations including dystonia and spasticity, and self-mutilating behavior such as lip-biting indicate Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.
  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, an X-linked recessive disorder, is caused by a deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), which results in impaired purine metabolism.

Pathophysiology:

  • HGPRT deficiency leads to:
    • Accumulation of purine metabolites
    • Excessive uric acid production
    • Neurological complications (dystonia and spasticity)

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome

Cause

Deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT)

Inheritance

X-linked recessive

Variants
  • Classic Lesch-Nyhan syndrome: Undetectable HPRT levels.
  • Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome: Partial HPRT deficiency with variable neurological dysfunction.

Clinical Features
  • Self-injurious behaviour: Biting lips, fingers, tongue; begins with tooth eruption.
  • Cognitive impairment: Intellectual disability ranging from mild to severe.
  • Movement disorder: Starts with hypotonia, progresses to dystonia, choreoathetosis, oromandibular dystonia, and inspiratory stridor.
  • Oculomotor apraxia: Difficulty controlling eye movements.
  • Dysarthric speech: Difficulty speaking clearly.

Complications
  • Hyperuricemia: Causes gout and kidney stones.
  • Neurological symptoms: Abnormalities in the dopamine system, reduced dopamine transporters.

Treatment
  • Allopurinol: Reduces uric acid levels and manages hyperuricemia.
  • Symptom management: Controls movement disorders and self-injurious behaviours.

Incorrect Options:

Cystathionine beta-synthase (Option A): This enzyme is involved in homocysteine metabolism, and its deficiency would lead to homocystinuria with manifestations like lens dislocation, skeletal abnormalities, and thromboembolism. It does not cause hyperuricemia or self-mutilating behavior.

Dihydrothymidine oxidase (Option B): This enzyme is involved in pyrimidine metabolism, and its deficiency would not cause elevated uric acid levels or neurological symptoms seen in this case.

Xanthine oxidase (Option D): Deficiency of this enzyme causes xanthinuria, characterized by low uric acid levels, not elevation as seen in this case. Its manifestations include abdominal pain, recurrent UTI, hematuria & muscle cramping.

questions.text: A road traffic accident patient has presented to you with features of a nerve injury involving right upper limb. On examination, the patient is able to carry out flexion at metacarpo-phalangeal joint and extension at interphalangeal joint. The most likely nerve involved is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Radial nerve

Explanation:

  • The most likely nerve involved is the posterior interosseous nerve, which is a branch of the radial nerve.
  • The lumbricals and interossei can carry out flexion at MCP and extension at IP joints.

Features of Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN) Palsy:

(a branch of the radial nerve)

  • Wrist extension not affected because extensor carpi radialis longus and brevis are supplied by the radial nerve.
  • Only one extension lost in PIN is extension at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint. So, the patient has finger drop, not wrist drop.
  • No sensory loss, because it is a motor nerve.
  • common in Monteggia fracture dislocation

Median nerve & Ulnar nerve (Options A & C):

  • They supply the lumbricals and interossei, which are involved in flexion at metacarpophalangeal joint and extension at the interphalangeal joint
  • Since these actions are present, these nerves are intact

Anterior interosseous nerve (Options B):

  • The anterior interosseous nerve supplies the Flexor Digitorum Profundus muscle and involved in the flexion and extension of the index and middle finger.
  • Since the flexion of all the fingers is intact, this nerve is intact.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with complaints of abdominal pain; further investigations show elevated PTH levels and renal calculi. Which of the following investigations should be done next?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) TC 99m sestamibi scan

Explanation:

  • The above scenario is suggestive of hyperparathyroidism.
  • TC 99m sestamibi scan is used to confirm the diagnosis of hyperparathyroidism.

 

Hyperparathyroidism

Functions of the parathyroid gland
  • Increase the level of calcium in the body (Subperiosteal bone resorption).
  • Decrease the level of phosphorus in the body (Urinary excretion of phosphorus).

Types

  • Primary hyperparathyroidism (parathyroid adenoma and parathyroid hyperplasia)
  • Secondary hyperparathyroidism

Radiological features

  • Subperiosteal resorption usually starts in the middle phalanx of the index finger's radial side, leading to a concavity of bone (the earliest bone change).
  • The "salt and pepper" appearance, or pepper pot skull (lytic lesions in the skull).
  • Brown tumor or osteitis fibrosa cystica: Cystic lesions resulting from excessive osteoclastic resorption appear as low-density, multiloculated cysts that can cause bone expansion, often accompanied by hemorrhage and granulation tissue (more common in primary hyperparathyroidism).

 

  • Rugger jersey spine: Characterized by alternating black and white striations, with sclerosed white end plates and black vertebral bodies; commonly seen in renal osteodystrophy (secondary hyperparathyroidism).

 

USG thyroid, Dexa scan, and Radioactive iodine uptake tests (Options A, C, and D): are not used for Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: Which structure is located approximately 25 cm from the central incisor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Arch of Aorta

Explanation:

The arch of the aorta is positioned around the level of the T4 vertebra, which is roughly 23 cm from the central incisor.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child immediately cries after breastfeeding, followed by vomiting and diarrhea. Which enzyme deficiency might be responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Galactose-1-Phosphate Uridyl Transferase

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Galactosemia, a disorder caused by Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT) deficiency. The immediate symptoms after breast milk ingestion, including crying, vomiting, and diarrhea, are hallmark features of this condition.

Galactosemia

Enzyme Deficiency
  • Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase (GALT) - Classical type
  • Galactokinase - benign disease with only oil drop cataract.
  • Epimerase - SNHL + symptoms of classical type

(Low galactose-based diet can be given, which is contraindicated in the classical type)

Pathophysiology
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate (toxic causing jaundice, and liver damage)
  • Inability to metabolize galactose from milk
  • Damage to liver, kidney, and brain

Clinical Features
  • Hepatic: Jaundice, hepatomegaly
  • GI: Vomiting, diarrhea, failure to thrive
  • CNS: Seizures, intellectual disability
  • Eyes: Oil drop cataracts
  • Increased risk of E. coli sepsis

Diagnosis
  • Reducing substance in urine (positive) (Positive Benedict test but negative glucose oxidase test)
  • Direct enzyme (GALT) assay
  • Genetic testing (Perinatal diagnosis is possible)

Management
  • Lactose-free diet
  • Breast Milk contraindicated
  • Soy-based or elemental formulas
  • Calcium supplementation

Incorrect Options:

Aldolase B (Option A): This enzyme deficiency results in hereditary fructose intolerance, causing symptoms after fructose ingestion rather than milk consumption. The presenting symptoms would be triggered by fruits and sweet foods, not breast milk.

Phenylalanine Hydroxylase (Option B): Deficiency of this enzyme causes phenylketonuria (PKU), presenting with developmental delay and neurological symptoms rather than acute post-feeding distress. PKU symptoms are not immediately related to breast milk ingestion.

Glucocerebrosidase (Option D): This enzyme deficiency leads to Gaucher disease, characterized by hepatosplenomegaly, bone problems, and hematological abnormalities. It does not cause acute gastrointestinal symptoms after milk ingestion.

questions.text: Which of the following is the lining epithelium of the trachea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pseudostratified ciliated columnar

Explanation:

The trachea is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells. This specialized epithelium plays a key role in:

  • Mucociliary clearance: The cilia help move mucus and trapped particles upward toward the pharynx.
  • Protection: Goblet cells secrete mucus that traps dust, bacteria, and other particles.

Respiratory Epithelium: 

Features of the various parts of the respiratory passages:

Simple squamous epithelium (Option A): Found in alveoli, allowing gas exchange, not in the trachea.

Transitional epithelium (Option B): Found in the urinary system (bladder, ureters, renal pelvis), not in the trachea.

Stratified squamous epithelium (Option C): Found in the oropharynx, laryngopharynx, and vocal cords, but not in the normal trachea (except in chronic irritation like smoking, where metaplasia can occur).

questions.text: During the surgical procedure for Patent Ductus Arteriosus, the structure that is in close relation to it can be damaged. Which of the following can be the structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Left recurrent laryngeal nerve

Explanation:

  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve (a branch of the vagus nerve) loops around the arch of the aorta, near the ductus arteriosus (ligamentum arteriosum in adults).
  • Due to this close relationship, it is vulnerable to damage during PDA surgery.

Feature

Right Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (Option B)

Left Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve

Pathway

Loops around the right subclavian artery

Loops around the arch of the aorta

Relation to Inferior Thyroid Artery

Lies between the branches of the inferior thyroid artery (can be anterior or posterior)

Lies posterior to the inferior thyroid artery

Course

Shorter course in the neck

Longer course in the neck

Prone to Injury In

Thyroid surgeries (more prone to injury than left side)

Mediastinal pathologies (due to its longer course)

Affected by Mediastinal Pathologies

No, as it loops around the subclavian artery (outside the mediastinum)

Yes, as it loops around the aortic arch (within the mediastinum)

Clinical Condition

Less affected by cardiac pathologies

Ortner’s Syndrome (Mitral stenosis → Left atrial enlargement → Compression of left recurrent laryngeal nerve → Hoarseness of voice)

Thoracic duct (Option C): Located on the left side of the thorax, but it is not closely related to the PDA.

Hemiazygos vein (Option D): Lies posteriorly in the thorax and is not in direct contact with the PDA.

questions.text: Which of the following primitive reflexes do not disappear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Parachute reflex

Explanation:

The parachute reflex is unique among primitive reflexes because it:

  • Appears at 7-8 months of age
  • Persists throughout life and never disappears
  • It is elicited when a baby is held in ventral suspension and suddenly dropped, causing the baby to spread its upper and lower limbs to avoid falling on the face

Name of the reflex

Appears at (weeks of gestation)

Disappears at (Postnatal age)

Rooting Reflex (Option A)

32 weeks

1 month

Moro’s Reflex (Option C)

28-37 weeks

3-6months

Palmar/Plantar Grasp Reflex (Option D)

28 weeks

4 months

ATNR (Asymmetric Tonic Neck Reflex)

35 weeks

3 months

STNR (symmetric tonic neck reflex)

6-9 months

9-11 months

Parachute reflex

8-9 months

  

Landau reflex

3 months

1 year

Neck righting reflex

Birth

5 years of age

questions.text: A 20-year-old female who is a known case of sickle cell anaemia was rushed to the emergency department with a complaint of extreme pain in the legs and fingers for the past 4 hours. Further examination revealed pain and tenderness in the right upper quadrant, and investigations showed sickle cells on peripheral blood smear and high bilirubin(indirect). What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Sickle cell crisis

Explanation:

The patient, a known case of sickle cell anaemia, presenting with severe leg and finger pain for the past 4 hours, right upper quadrant tenderness, sickle cells on the peripheral blood smear, and elevated indirect bilirubin is likely undergoing a vaso-occlusive crisis (type of sickle cell crisis), a common complication of Sickle Cell Disease (SCD).

Complications

  • Acute Painful Episodes (Vaso-Occlusive Crisis)
    • Characterised by unprovoked, severe, symmetrical pain often requiring strong opioids
    • The most common acute event in sickle cell disease.
    • Lasting from days to weeks.
    • Sudden death during acute pain episodes can occur, possibly due to arrhythmias or pulmonary embolism.

  • Acute Chest Syndrome:
    • Symptoms include chest pain, cough, fever, hypoxia, and pulmonary infiltrates on x-ray.
    • It can be mild in children (e.g., due to viral infections) or severe with multiple lobes affected.
    • Thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis, and rapid anaemia suggest severe complications like acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and multiorgan failure.
  • Osteonecrosis:
    • Involves the hips bilaterally.
    • Chronic pain can progress to severe disability; MRI detects early stages, while X-rays are less sensitive.
  • Leg ulcer:
    • Ulcers range from small and superficial to deep, covering most of the lower leg.
    • Painful and difficult to treat if recurrent, long-standing and large ulcer.
  • Other Complications:
    • Priapism
    • Stroke and silent infarction
    • Gallstones/Surgery
    • Hepatic disease
    • Nephropathy
    • Lung/pulmonary hypertension
    • Retinopathy
    • Aplastic crisis: Caused by parvovirus B19 infection
    • Multiorgan failure

IDA (Iron Deficiency Anemia) (Option A) presents with microcytic hypochromic anaemia, not sickle cells on the smear. It also lacks acute pain crises and indirect hyperbilirubinemia.

Thalassemia (Option B) causes chronic anaemia with target cells, not acute vaso-occlusive pain. It is also associated with ineffective erythropoiesis rather than hemolysis-induced hyperbilirubinemia.

Anaemia of chronic disease (ACD) (Option C) is linked to chronic inflammation and cytokine-mediated iron sequestration, typically presenting with normocytic or microcytic anaemia without acute pain crises or hemolysis.

questions.text: A patient who has been treated for TB in the past now presented with hemoptysis. Make a diagnosis based on the given X-ray.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aspergilloma
 

Explanation:

  • The above image shows the air crescent sign or the monod sign and along with the clinical presentation of the patient suggests aspergilloma.
  • Aspergilloma is seen in conditions with pre-existing lung cavities, such as Tuberculosis.

 

Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA)

 

  • ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction affecting the major upper lobe airways leading to upper lobe bronchiectasis.
  • It is associated with Elevated serum IgE levels, Positive serum precipitins for Aspergillus, Respiratory symptoms similar to asthma, Skin reactivity to Aspergillus

 

Radiographic Findings:

  • Non-segmental opacities primarily in the upper lobes
  • Lobar collapse
  • Branching thick tubular opacities due to mucus and fungus (known as the "finger-in-glove sign" or "Y" shape)
  • Occasional pulmonary cavitation

Aspergillus Mycetomas/ Aspergilloma/ Fungal Ball

 

  • Aspergillus mycetomas are saprophytic growths that inhabit preexisting lung cavities,
  • These are predominantly found in the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes.

 

CT Characteristics:

  • Appears as a mass with soft-tissue attenuation within a lung cavity.
  • The mass is usually separated from the cavity wall by an airspace, known as the "Air crescent" or Monod sign.
  • The position of the mass may change between prone and supine orientations, demonstrating its mobility.

Angioinvasive Aspergillosis

Fig: Halo sign

 

  • Primarily occurs in immunocompromised individuals,
  • Involves invasion and blockage of small to medium pulmonary arteries.
  • Leads to the formation of necrotic hemorrhagic nodules or infarcts.

 

CT Findings:

  • Commonly presented as multiple nodules surrounded by a halo of ground-glass attenuation "halo sign" or pleural-based wedge-shaped consolidations. (Option A)
  • The bronchial cut-off sign indicates central necrosis.
  • Nodular opacities tend to be widespread across several lung lobes, unlike the clustered peribronchial opacities seen in bacterial infections.

 

Bronchogenic carcinoma (Option A):

  • Typically appears as a mass or nodule, often without the "fungus ball" appearance.
  • Hemoptysis can occur, but a history of TB and cavity formation points more to aspergilloma.

 

Hydatid cyst (Option C): Seen in echinococcosis, it presents as a well-defined cystic lesion, sometimes with the "water-lily sign," not a mobile fungus ball.

 

 

 

Lung abscess (Option D): Appears as a cavity with an air-fluid level, not a distinct fungus ball.

questions.text: Which type of intracranial hemorrhage is most likely depicted in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Subdural hematoma

Explanation:

  • The given image shows a crescent-shaped blood collection that follows the brain's contours and crosses suture lines, the most probable diagnosis is Subdural Hematoma.

Features

Subdural Hematoma

Extradural Hematoma (Option A)

Location

Between Dura and Arachnoid

Between Dura and Skull

CT Appearance
  • Crescent-shaped
  • Crosses suture lines
  • Biconvex or lens-shaped
  • Well-defined & Localized,
  • Won’t cross suture lines

Common Causes

Tearing of bridging veins, often due to blunt trauma / acceleration-deceleration injuries

Rupture of the middle meningeal artery or vein due to skull fracture or trauma

Onset

Develop over days to weeks; Acute SDH can occur rapidly

Usually develop rapidly

Management
  • Craniotomy / Craniectomy, if significant.
  • Conservative management for smaller, stable cases.
  • Burr hole drainage is preferred for significant chronic cases

Urgent surgical evacuation for significant or deteriorating cases.

 

Incorrect Options:

Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage (Option D) is a type of hemorrhage that involves bleeding within the brain tissue itself and is typically associated with conditions like hypertension, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, or direct traumatic brain injury.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (Option B) typically causes sudden severe headache, often described as a "thunderclap," and is seen on CT as blood in the subarachnoid space, often with associated hydrocephalus. It does not usually present with the crescent-shaped lesions seen in SDH.

questions.text: In a triage setting, which of the following categories requires the highest priority intervention?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Red

Explanation:

  • In triage, the Red category represents patients who have life-threatening injuries or conditions but can survive with immediate medical intervention. These patients are prioritised for treatment and intervention to prevent imminent death.

Triage colour coding systems:

Colour

Priority

Medical Need

Clinical Status

Examples

Red

 

First

Immediate

Critical, but likely to survive if treatment is given early
  • Severe facial trauma
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Profuse external bleeding
  • Haemothorax
  • Flail chest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed
  • Extradural haematomas

Yellow (Option B)

 

Second

Urgent

Critical, but likely to survive if treatment is given within hours
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Ruptured abdominal viscus
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries

Green (Option C)

 

Third

Non-Urgent

Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days
  • Simple fractures
  • Sprains
  • Minor lacerations

Black (Option D)

Last

Unsalvageable

Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help.
  • Severe brain damage
  • Very extensive burns
  • Major disruption/ loss of chest or abdominal wall structures

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child was brought to the OPD with complaints of low-grade fever, headache and mild upper respiratory tract symptoms for the last 4 days. On examination, an erythematous rash was found on the cheeks. The parents said the rash developed on the cheeks first and then spread out to involve his trunk and limbs. The causative agent of this disease has a single-stranded DNA. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Erythema infectiosum

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease), caused by Parvovirus B19, a single-stranded DNA virus (Parvoviridae family)
  • The disease presents with characteristic features, including low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory symptoms, followed by the distinctive "slapped cheek" appearance of facial erythema that spreads to involve the trunk and extremities in a lacy or reticulated pattern.
  • The progression of symptoms and the age of presentation (5 years) are classic for this self-limiting condition.

Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth disease)

Causative agent

Parvovirus B19

Age group affected

5 to 15 years (70% of cases)

Incubation period

4-28 days

Transmission

Respiratory droplets. Transmission rates among contacts are 15-30%.

Clinical features
  • Prodromal phase: Low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection symptoms.
  • The characteristic rash in this condition is a "slapped cheek appearance”, presenting as erythematous flushing on the face.
  • The erythematous rash spreads to the trunk and proximal extremities as a lacy or reticulated pattern.

 

Management

Self-limiting disease

Hand, foot and mouth disease (Option A): This condition is caused by Coxsackievirus A & Enterovirus71, types of ss-RNA virus from Picronaviridae family, and presents with vesicular lesions primarily on hands, feet, and mouth. The pattern and type of rash are different, and the causative agent is not a DNA virus.

Measles (Option B): Caused by a single-stranded RNA virus from Paramyxoviridae family, measles presents with high fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a rash that begins behind the ears and spreads downward. The characteristic lesion Koplik spots (on buccal mucosa) appear on 1 day before onset of rash and persist for 2-3 days.

Rubella (Option D): caused by an ss-RNA virus from Togaviridae family, it presents with a fine, pink-red maculopapular rash that follows a descending pattern. Characteristic Forchheimer spots are a fleeting enanthem seen as small petechiae on the soft palate in 20% of patients with rubella. However, the virus type and the characteristic "slapped cheek" appearance are not features of rubella.

Forchheimer spots
