questions.text: Which among the following is the most common parotid gland tumour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pleomorphic adenoma

Explanation:

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the parotid gland, accounting for about 60-70% of all parotid gland tumors. It is typically slow-growing and presents as a painless swelling.

  • Warthin’s tumor (Option B) is the second most common benign tumor of the parotid gland.
  • Adenoid cystic carcinoma (Option C) and mucoepidermoid carcinoma (Option D) are malignant tumors, but they are less common than pleomorphic adenomas.

Pleomorphic Adenoma:

  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Painless, well-defined, solitary, mobile masses.
    • Commonly located in the parotid glands (>80% of cases).
    • It can also occur in the submandibular gland and hard palate.
    • Sudden growth of facial nerve palsy may suggest malignant transformation (rare).
  • Imaging:
    • USG: Well-lobulated, hypoechoic lesions with possible calcifications.
    • CT: Provides detailed anatomical imaging along with the extent of the tumour.
    • MRI: Helps differentiate between benign and malignant tumours
  • Fine-Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC):
    • Differentiates between inflammatory conditions and tumour- high sensitivity and specificity
  • Histopathology:
    • Gross Examination:
      • Tumours are well-circumscribed, nodular, and firm, with a white to tan cut surface.
      • May show cartilaginous areas; large tumours may exhibit degeneration or cystic changes.
    • Microscopy:
      • A mixture of epithelial, myoepithelial, and stromal components.
      • Possible malignant changes: Ductal atypia, diffuse fibrosis, or necrosis

Treatment:

  • Surgical Excision of the tumour along with a cuff of normal tissue.
  • Enucleation is not recommended due to the risk of capsular breach, tumour spillage, and recurrence.

Salivary gland tumors

The most common benign tumour

Pleomorphic adenoma

The most common benign tumour of infants and young children

Hemangioma

The most common malignant tumour

Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

The most common malignant tumour in children and young adults

Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

The most common malignant tumour of Minor salivary glands

Adenoid cystic carcinoma

questions.text: A young patient in the first decade of life presents with grade II splenic injury with no active bleeding. What is the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Conservative

Explanation:

  • In the case of a grade II splenic injury without active bleeding, the management is generally conservative.
  • This involves admission to the ICU for close monitoring, with repeated clinical assessments and possibly serial imaging to ensure there is no progression of injury or delayed bleeding.
  • The goal is to preserve the spleen, thus avoiding the complications associated with splenectomy, such as OPSI (Overwhelming post-splenectomy infection)

American Association for the Surgery of Trauma - AAST Spleen Injury scale

Grade I (Minor Injury):
  • Subcapsular hematoma affects less than 10% of the splenic surface area.
  • Capsular tear that is less than 1 cm in depth without active bleeding.

Grade II:

 
  • Subcapsular hematoma involving 10-50% of the splenic surface area.
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma less than 5 cm in diameter.
  • Laceration between 1 and 3 cm in depth that doesn't involve trabecular vessels.

Grade III:

 
  • Subcapsular hematoma covering more than 50% of the splenic surface area or expanding hematoma.
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma greater than 5 cm or expanding.
  • Laceration is more than 3 cm in depth or involves trabecular vessels.

Grade IV:

 
  • Laceration affects segmental or hilar vessels, with evidence of devascularisation involving more than 25% of the spleen.
  • Injury to the splenic parenchyma that results in major blood loss.
  • Any injury in the presence of splenic vascular injury or active bleeding within the splenic capsule

Grade V (Severe Injury):
  • Completely shattered spleen.
  • Vascular injury involving the splenic hilum that results in complete devascularization of the spleen.

Management: Management of blunt trauma focuses on vigorous resuscitation.

  • For hemodynamically stable patients with minor splenic injuries, non-operative management (NOM) (conservative) is the preferred approach.
  • Splenectomy is recommended for severe injuries where bleeding control is prioritized over spleen preservation.
  • In cases with active bleeding, splenic angiography and embolization can be used to avoid splenectomy, but this should not delay laparotomy in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: A patient reports to the outpatient department with complaints of fatigue. Investigation results indicate a Hb of 5.9, increased RDW and TIBC, and low ferritin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) IDA

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with fatigue and investigations showing low haemoglobin, increased RDW, high TIBC, and low ferritin are consistent with a diagnosis of Iron Deficiency Anemia (IDA).
  • It results in inadequate haemoglobin synthesis.
  • Causes:
    • Dietary lack
    • Impaired absorption
    • Increased requirement
    • Chronic blood loss
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Iron deficiency initially depletes iron stores (low ferritin) while maintaining normal serum iron and transferrin saturation. As depletion progresses, serum iron declines, leading to reduced haemoglobin synthesis.
    • Hypochromic microcytic anaemia develops once iron stores are exhausted, with low serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation, while total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) increases.
  • Clinical features include koilonychia, alopecia, atrophic glossitis, esophageal webs, pica, malabsorption, fatigue, pale skin, shortness of breath, dizziness, headaches, tachycardia, cold extremities, and restless leg syndrome.
  • Histopathology:
    • Bone marrow aspiration: Increased erythroid progenitors and a lack of stainable iron in macrophages, best assessed by Prussian blue staining.
    • Peripheral blood smears: Red cells are small (microcytic) and pale (hypochromic).
  • Diagnosis:

Iron Study

Interpretation in Iron Deficiency Anemia

Serum Ferritin

Low (< 30 ng/mL) (depleted iron stores).

Serum Iron (Fe)

Low levels

Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)

Increased TIBC (increased capacity of transferrin to bind iron in response to low iron stores).

Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW)

Increased RDW (Red Cell Distribution Width)

Bone Marrow Aspiration and Iron Staining

Confirmatory test

Lab parameters in various anaemia:

 

Serum Iron

Transferrin saturation

Serum Ferritin

TIBC

Sideroblastic Anemia

(Option A ruled out)

High

High

High

Low

Iron Deficiency Anemia

(Option B)

Low

Low

Low

High

Anaemia of Chronic Disease

(Option C ruled out)

Low

Low

High

Low

Hemolytic Anemia

(Option D ruled out)

High

Low

High

Low

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a young patient under 5 years of age presenting with a painless, soft, fluctuating mass on the lateral side of the neck?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cystic hygroma

Explanation:

  • The child is most likely suffering from Cystic hygroma, which is soft, partially compressible swelling filled with clear lymph.

Features of Cystic Hygromas:

  • Definition: Lymphatic malformations in neonates or infants.

  • Appearance: Soft, partially compressible swellings filled with clear lymph. (Option C)

  • Size Variation: May increase in size when the child cries or coughs.

  • Common Locations: Neck (most common), face, submandibular region, tongue, floor of the mouth, cheek, axilla, groin, mediastinum.

  • Distinguishing Characteristics: Translucence.

Behavior and Complications:

  • Behavior: Unpredictable; can expand rapidly.

  • Complications:

    • Respiratory difficulties (may require aspiration or tracheostomy).

    • Risk of infection.

Treatment:

  • Preferred Treatment: Early complete surgical excision.

  • Alternative Treatment: Injection of sclerosing agents to reduce size.

  • Challenges: Complete resolution can be difficult due to its multicystic nature.

Incorrect Options:

Thyroglossal cysts (Option A) are usually present in the midline of the neck and may be associated with swallowing or tongue movements.

Cervical lymphadenopathy (Option C) typically involves lymph nodes and is often tender or associated with infection.

Ranula (Option D) is a type of mucous retention cyst in the floor of the mouth and would not present as a lateral neck mass.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for an adult male patient with a history of intermittent purulent discharge with a slight blood tinge from an external opening located in the perianal region?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fistula in ano

Explanation:

  • A fistula in ano is a common cause of intermittent purulent discharge with a slight blood tinge from an external opening near the perianal region. It often results from a previous perianal abscess that has developed into a chronic fistulous tract.

Fistula-in-Ano

A chronic abnormal communication between the anorectal lumen (internal opening) and an external opening on the skin of the perineum, buttock, or, rarely, the vagina in women.

 

 

Causes

  • Idiopathic/Cryptoglandular: The most common cause, often associated with prior anorectal sepsis.

  • Associated Conditions:

    • Crohn’s disease

    • Tuberculosis

    • Lymphogranuloma venereum

    • Actinomycosis

    • Rectal duplication

    • Foreign bodies

    • Malignancy (rare, can develop within a longstanding fistula)

 

Clinical features

  • Intermittent purulent discharge: This may be bloody and purulent. Discomfort typically increases until the pus discharges, providing temporary relief.

  • Previous history of Anorectal abscess

  • Passage of flatus or faeces: Through the external opening, (indicative of a rectal rather than an anal internal opening).

Classifications:

  • Low-level fistulas open into the anal canal below the internal ring.

  • High-level fistulas open into the anal canal at or above the internal ring.

  • Simple fistula without extensions

  • Complex fistula with extensions.

Parks classification

Type 1

Inter- sphincteric (most common, 70%)

Type 2

Trans- sphincteric (25%)

Type 3

Supra- sphincteric (4%)

Type 4

Extra- sphincteric (1%)

Incorrect Options:

Hemorrhoids (Option A) typically present with bleeding during defecation but do not produce purulent discharge.

Pilonidal sinus (Option B) typically presents in the sacrococcygeal region and may involve purulent discharge, but is not commonly associated with blood-tinged drainage.

Perianal abscess (Option C) is an acute condition characterized by pain, swelling, and often fever, with purulent drainage, but would not typically cause intermittent discharge over time without other symptoms of infection.

questions.text: All of the following are correct about NETs except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Phagocytosis

Explanation:

  • NETs (Neutrophil Extracellular Traps) do not directly engulf pathogens through phagocytosis but instead trap and immobilise them, allowing other immune cells to clear the infection.
  • They are extracellular fibrillar networks that concentrate antimicrobial substances at sites of infection and trap microbes, helping to prevent their spread.
  • They don’t directly phagocytose pathogens but trap and immobilise them, allowing immune cells like macrophages to eliminate them. (Option B)
  • They are produced by neutrophils in response to pathogens and inflammatory mediators.
  • NET formation begins with ROS-induced activation of arginine deaminase, leading to chromatin decondensation. (Option D ruled out)
  • They are composed of nuclear chromatin and granule proteins, including antimicrobial peptides and enzymes.
  • They are implicated in conditions like sepsis (Option C ruled out) and autoimmune diseases like lupus (Option A ruled out), where they may contribute to autoimmunity.

 

A neutrophil granulocyte (yellow) has ejected a NET (green) to capture bacteria (purple). A red blood cell (orange) is also trapped in the NET.​​

questions.text: Identify the most common pancreatic islet tumor associated with MEN-1 syndrome.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Gastrinoma

Explanation:

  • Gastrinoma is the most common pancreatic islet tumor associated with MEN-1 syndrome (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1). Gastrinomas are typically found in the pancreas or duodenum and cause Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, which is characterized by severe peptic ulcers due to excessive gastrin secretion.

Types of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia

 

MEN Type I

MEN Type II

MEN Type III

MEN Type IV

Cause
  • Defect of chromosome 11q13 causing MEN 1 gene mutation
  • Also called Wermer’s syndrome
  • Defect of chr.10 leading to mutation of RET gene
  • Also called Sipple’s syndrome

Also called MEN II B, it is a variant of Type 2 MEN

Defect of chr.12 causing CDKN1B gene

Tumors

Included

Parathyroid adenoma (most common)

  • It presents with primary hyperparathyroidism (↑ PTH and ↑ Ca)
  • All the 4 glands can be included.
  • Rx: Total/subtotal parathyroid resection

Parathyroid adenoma (most common, and calcium can be normal)

 

Medullary carcinoma thyroid (most common)

 

Parathyroid adenoma (Presents as hypercalcemia)

Pancreatic adenoma

  • Presents as Gastrinoma or Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
  • This leads to peptic ulcer disease in the duodenum, which is the leading cause of death in this type.

Pheochromocytoma.

 

Pheochromocytoma (Most important criterion for both MEN 2 and MEN 3): Presents with elevated blood pressure.

Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma

Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma, causing amenorrhea and Infertility

Medullary thyroid carcinoma

  • Calcitonin is the tumor marker present
  • Cold nodules are seen on the thyroid scan
  • Metastasis can be traced with PET scan
  • Visible neck mass, causing dysphagia
  • Rx- Prophylactic thyroidectomy

Reproductive tract tumors

  • Testicular tumors
  • Neuroendocrine tumor (Cervix)

Associated conditions
  • Angioﬁbroma
  • Collagenoma
  • Adrenocortical tumor
  • Carcinoid tumors/Argentaﬃnoma
  • Pheochromocytoma (only in 1%)
  • Congenital aganglionosis,
  • Hirschsprung disease
  • Marfanoid habitus
  • Medullated corneal nerve ﬁbers
  • Mucosal neuromas
  • Megacolon and Multiple diverticulae

Occasionally with

  • Renal tumor
  • Adrenal tumor

questions.text: A barium swallow radiographic image of a woman with dysphagia is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Achalasia

Explanation:

  • Achalasia is a disorder where the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) fails to relax properly, leading to a "bird-beak" appearance on a barium swallow, which is a classic finding in this condition. It causes difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) and often results in a progressive esophageal dilation above the constricted LES.

Achalasia cardia

Definition

It is characterised by the progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall. This leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing

Clinical Features

 
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations:

Esophageal Manometry

Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the esophagus. (Option A)

  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram)

Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance).

Endoscopy:

Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris, It is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia, such as tumors.

Distal Esophageal Spasm: This condition presents with characteristic "corkscrew" appearance on barium swallow, due to irregular, simultaneous contractions in the distal esophagus.

Jackhammer Esophagus: This condition involves excessive peristalsis with very strong contractions, resulting in a tight, hypercontractile esophagus. It can cause dysphagia but has a different radiographic appearance.

questions.text: What type of skin graft is used in the image shown?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Split thickness

Explanation:

  • The image in question depicts a split-thickness skin graft (STSG), which consists of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis.
  • These grafts are typically harvested from areas such as the inner thigh.
  • Due to their ease of harvesting and ability to cover larger wounds, split-thickness grafts are commonly used for extensive skin coverage.

 

Feature

Thiersch Graft  (Split-Thickness Skin Graft)

Wolfe Graft  (Full-Thickness Skin Graft)

Type of Skin Grafting

Split-thickness

Full-thickness

Composition

Epidermis + part of dermis

Epidermis + full thickness of dermis

Graft Size

Large grafts can be taken

Only small grafts can be taken

Graft Survival

Easier

More difficult

Donor Site Healing

Heals spontaneously, allowing repeated grafts

Permanent defect develops, preventing repeated grafts

Graft Contraction

Significant contraction, leading to poor cosmetic appearance

Lesser contraction, better cosmetic appearance

Common Donor Sites

Inner thigh, upper arm, flexor aspect of forearm, abdominal wall

Upper eyelid, retro auricular skin, supraclavicular skin, antecubital skin, inframammary skin, inguinal skin, genital skin, gluteal skin

Donor Site Exclusions

None

Axilla is not used as a donor site

Advantages of Harvesting

Allows calibration of thickness and large area coverage

Calibration of thickness for small but thick grafts

questions.text: A patient underwent bronchoscopy, during the procedure a perforation occurred at 25 cm. Which structure is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Arch of aorta

Explanation:

  • In the given scenario of perforation at 25 cm, the arch of the aorta is most likely to be damaged, as this is the region where the esophagus is compressed by the aorta and left bronchus.

Constrictions of Esophagus:

  • 0 cm - Incisor teeth (start of the esophagus).
  • 15 cm - Cricopharyngeal constriction (upper esophageal sphincter).
  • 25 cm - Aortic and bronchial constriction (due to the aorta and left bronchus).
  • 40 cm - Diaphragmatic constriction (at the esophageal hiatus, lower esophageal sphincter).

questions.text: Identify the operative procedure shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Resection and Anastomosis

Explanation:

The given image shows Resection and Anastomosis. This procedure involves the removal of a diseased or damaged segment of the bowel (resection) and then surgically joining the healthy ends of the remaining bowel (anastomosis). It's commonly performed in cases such as:

  • Meckel’s diverticulum with an unhealthy base
  • Transverse mesentery tear
  • Small intestinal duplication
  • Enterogenous cysts

 

Primary closure of perforation: Typically involves suturing a hole or perforation in the gastrointestinal tract, usually performed in cases of bowel perforation.

Ileostomy: A surgical procedure where the end of the ileum (small intestine) is brought to the surface of the abdomen to create an opening (stoma) for waste to exit. It may be used in cases of inflammatory bowel disease or after bowel resections.

Resection alone: This refers to the removal of part of the gastrointestinal tract without performing an anastomosis. It might be used when a portion of the bowel is removed due to a tumor, but reconnection isn't necessary or feasible at the time.

questions.text: What is the condition depicted in the given image, and what is the next investigation required for management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Erythroplakia and biopsy

 

Explanation:

The condition here is erythroplakia. Erythroplakia is a red, velvety lesion that is often highly suspicious for malignancy, and biopsy is indicated to rule out cancer.

 

Erythroplakia is a bright red velvety plaque that cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease.

  • Has a higher malignant potential than leukoplakia.

 

Types:

  • Homogenous
  • Speckled
  • Granular
  • Erythroplakia interspersed with leukoplakia

 

Management:

  • Biopsy for diagnosis
  • Surgical excision
  • Strict follow-up

Leukoplakia is defined as a white patch or plaque that cannot be rubbed off, and cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease.

It is a premalignant lesion and is painless/non-tender.

Types:

  • Homogenous
  • Nodular
  • Speckled
  • Hairy: Associated with EBV. It is not actually hairy but appears so due to the corrugation caused by severe hyperkeratosis and acanthosis. Common in AIDS patients.

Management:

  • Biopsy to rule out carcinoma and confirm diagnosis.
  • Stop smoking/ alcohol/ betel quid.
  • Excision, skin grafting if needed.
  • Regular follow-up.
  • Isotretinoin, tocopherol, and beta-carotene.
  • CO2 laser.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the outpatient department 10 days postpartum with complaints of a fluctuant breast mass with tenderness, high-grade fever, and cracked nipples. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Breast abscess

Explanation:

  • A breast abscess is a localized collection of pus within the breast tissue, most commonly seen in lactating women. The patient's clinical presentation, including a fluctuant mass, high fever, and localized tenderness, strongly suggests this diagnosis.

Breast Abscess

Definition
  • Pus-filled cavity within breast tissue.

Types
  • Lactational Abscess: Associated with breastfeeding.
  • Non-Lactational Abscess: Occurs in non-lactating women, e.g., periductal mastitis.

Causes and Risk Factors
  • Lactation:
    • Incidence: 3% to 20% in lactating mothers.
    • Common pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-resistant strains in hospital settings).
    • Entry points: Cracked/retracted nipple, blocked lactiferous ducts.
  • Non-Lactation:
    • Often in nulliparous women or post-lactation.
    • Conditions: Periductal mastitis, idiopathic granulomatous mastitis, tubercular mastitis.
    • Smoking and diabetes as risk factors.

Signs and symptoms

Fever, leukocytosis, erythema, pain and tenderness, swelling, malaise, difficulty feeding, enlarged and tender axillary nodes

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography:
    • Detects cellulitis, liquefaction necrosis.
    • Confirms abscess size, location, and loculation.

Treatment
  • Lactational Mastitis:
    • Antibiotics: Anti-staphylococcal (e.g., cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, erythromycin).
    • Breast emptying: Frequent breastfeeding or pumping.
    • Support: Breast support garment, cold compresses, analgesia.
    • Drainage: Ultrasound-guided preferred over surgical incision.
    • Follow-up: Regular clinical and ultrasonographic reviews, culture-based antibiotic modification.
  • Non-Lactational Mastitis:
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics for subareolar infections.
    • Needle aspiration for abscess drainage.
    • Major milk duct excision for complications like sepsis or fistula.

Incorrect Options:

Breast engorgement (Option A) is not associated with a fluctuant mass, high fever, or localized pain.

Acute mastitis (Option C) can cause breast pain and swelling, but it typically does not present as a fluctuant mass.

Fibroadenoma (Option D) does not present with a fluctuant mass, high fever, or localized pain.
